Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, said Kennedy, a prosecutor since August, will be asked to resign from his $30,000-a-year post if he fails again. ``All assistants get three chances,'' Roche said. ``It's a longstanding office policy. He will take it again in July.'' Kennedy fell 11 points short of the passing score of 660 out of 1,000 points, said a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Kennedy, a graduate of the New York University Law School, first took the bar exam last July with 64 other new members of Morgenthau's staff, Roche said. Of the 65, she said, Kennedy was one of seven who flunked. He took the test again in February along with those who failed. Of the seven, at least two passed on the second go-round.

DOC.HEAD: Class of 1994 Must Perform Community Service To Graduate
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem has become the latest city to require high school students to perform community service in order to graduate. The school board voted 6-3 Monday to require the Class of 1994 to perform 60 hours of community service after school, on weekends and in the summer. At the meeting, school board President Joseph McCarthy said the proposal was ``poorly thought out.'' But board member Robert Thompson said the measure would encourage students to have an ``active concern'' for the community. ``With the coming generation of adults we need to enunciate clearly a new set of values, in contradiction to the consumer ideal of happiness and fulfillment,'' Thompson said. In approving the requirement, Bethlehem followed the lead of a growing number of cities that have adopted some form of community service standard in the past several years. In 1983, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching issued a report calling for students to perform at least 120 hours of community service during their four years in high school.

DOC.HEAD: Former Houston Police Officer Receives Seven-Year Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A former Houston police officer was sentenced to seven years in prison for shooting a black motorist to death, and the victim's sister said she was satistifed with the outcome of the racially charged case. Alex Gonzales, 25, was sentenced Monday in the Oct. 31 killing of Ida Lee Delaney, a 50-year-old newspaper janitor. He was convicted Friday of voluntary manslaughter and could have faced up to 20 years in prison. Janice Myles, Ms. Delaney's sister, said she was pleased with the sentence. But she said Gonzales is still better off than her sister. ``You know she's gone,'' Ms. Myles said. ``The only thing I can do is go talk to her at her grave. But they can go visit him.'' Mike Howard, president of the Houston Police Patrolman's Union, said he was disgusted by the jury's verdict. ``It's an indictment on the whole police department,'' Howard said. ``The line has been drawn and we're going to fight this.'' Gonzales' attorney, Mike Hinton said: ``This is not good for off-duty officers to now be thinking that they can be confronted with the sort of ordeal that Alex Gonzales encountered.'' Gonzales, who is free on bond, will appeal the verdict. He and fellow off-duty officers Robert Gonzales, who is unrelated, and Alexander Romero were returning from a birthday celebration when they encountered Ms. Delaney on a freeway about 5:30 a.m. They said Ms. Delaney cut in front of their unmarked car and later fired shots at them. During a 12-mile chase, Ms. Delaney pulled her truck over to the side of the road, near a highway department vehicle, apparently seeking help. She fired at Gonzales after he ran to her truck, gun in hand, and punched her in the face, a road maintenance worker testified. Critically wounded, he returned gunfire, killing her. Gonzales was intoxicated at the time of the shooting. Tests showed he had a blood-alcohol level of .19, nearly twice the amount to be considered legally drunk in Texas. The case sparked protests from blacks and other community leaders both in Houston and in Dallas who said they did not think an all-white jury would convict Gonzales. Charlotte Ragsdale, a member of the Ida Delaney Justice Committee, said the sentence ``is at least a step in Dallas.'' ``Obviously, there was enough information and evidence to bring some form of justice and that was critical in my opinion,'' Ms. Ragsdale said. ``The family was looking for hope in the system in they were able to find it.''

DOC.HEAD: Dalai Lama: Lifting of Martial Law Was Public Relations Ploy
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama said today that China's lifting of martial law in his homeland was a ``public relations exercise.'' In a statement issued by his New Delhi office, the Tibetan spiritual leader said the problems of Tibet will never be resolved ``through intimidation and superficial changes.'' He called for a fundamental change in how Chinese leaders view Tibet. China imposed martial law in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa on March 8, 1989, after three days of anti-Chinese rioting. The government claimed 16 people died, but Tibetan and Western travelers said about 30 were killed. The rioting marked the fourth time since 1987 that Communist Chinese security forces moved to crush anti-Chinese uprisings. The Dalai Lama, who won the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize for his advocacy of peaceful resistance in Tibet, said the lifing of the martial law Monday ``was a public relations exercise in view of the growing international criticism'' of China. He said that over the weekend, a large public trial was held in Lhasa. Quoting an official Radio Lhasa report, he said 43 Tibetans were publicly tried and sentenced on ``vague criminal charges.'' He claimed the trial was conducted to intimidate Tibetans before the lifting of martial law. Human rights agencies, including the London-based Amnesty International and the U.S.-based Asia Watch, have condemned China for alleged human rights abuses in Tibet. China has been accused of torturing Tibetans and denying them basic rights, such as that of free assembly and religion. Countries have limited themselves to urging restraint on the Chinese because all of them back China's claims to sovereignty over the vast Himalayan region. Many Tibetans resent Chinese rule and reject China's claims that Tibet has been part of China since the 13th century. The Dalai Lama, who fled to India after an aborted uprising in 1959, has called for an autonomous Tibet where Beijing would still control defense and foreign relations. China has rejected the proposal, saying the Dalai Lama is trying to subvert national unity. In his statement, the Dalai Lama urged Beijing to negotiate with Tibetans on the future of Tibet.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Mark May Day by Protesting Joblessness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Border guards...' with 1 graf to remove redundancy. Pick up 3rd pvs, `Nearly 6,000...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of East Germans marked their first free May Day with protests against the widespread joblessness they fear will be the price of unification with West Germany. Border guards dispensed with passport checks as crowds of people carrying balloons, beer and bratwurst swarmed back and forth through new openings in the Berlin Wall. Nearly 60,000 Germans from both sides of the border crowded around the Reichstag, the former parliament building on the West German side of the Wall. They heard speakers demand employment and social service protection as East Germany moves from a socialist economy to the free market. Economists have predicted that 500,000 to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs as inefficient state-owned enterprises are closed and others are forced to compete with Western businesses. But West Germans as well have expressed fears about the economic impact of unification. ``Unemployment will be bad in both countries. As factories close in the East, the East Germans will come here and compete for jobs with West Germans,'' said Claudia Gerlach, a 27-year-old West Berliner. West German labor leaders, meanwhile, warned that Western businesses may seek to move to the East to take advantage of lower wages. While some Germans rallied against unemployment, hundreds of thousands of others enjoyed the warm spring day at a huge May Day festival on East Berlin's main avenue, Unter den Linden. Only a few thousand gathered in another part of town for a rally held by the former Communist Party, a retooled group now calling for democratic socialism. Thousands of extra police were put on duty in both East and West Berlin to guard against the rampages by radicals and hooligans that occur annually in West Berlin on May Day evening. With the newly opened borders, authorities feared the mayhem would spread to the East. No violence was reported. May Day rallies were held in cities in both Germanys, with calls for job protection the central theme of each gathering.

DOC.HEAD: Schoolchildren Get Inside Glimpse of 1812-Era Wrecks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `The Hamilton . ..' to CORRECT that British were NOT invading forces in Canada.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists using a robot diver to explore two War of 1812-era wrecks let schoolchildren across North America in on the expedition. The underwater look Monday at the merchant schooner Hamilton and its sister ship, the Scourge, was televised live to 13 museums. Four youngsters watching got to operate the robot using a computer joystick hooked up by satellite. The cold, fresh water of Lake Ontario and the 300-foot depth of the wrecks helped preserve the two ships, which were pressed into battle service by the United States during the War of 1812. Cannons, railings and an elegantly carved figurehead could be seen as the black-and-white television image panned slowly. Robert D. Ballard, the expedition's leader, and other scientists gave a running narration and took questions from viewers at the museums in the United States and Canada and at the Canadian Football Hall of Fame in Hamilton, a city 25 miles west of St. Catharines that has title to the wrecks. ``The ship is in immaculate condition. We can see the caulking in the planks,'' Ballard said. ``There's no suggestion that they suffered any damage due to the sinking itself. They just got flooded and went down very gently.'' The Hamilton and the Scourge sank during a storm Aug. 8, 1813, killing 53 sailors. They had taken part in several battles against British forces in southern Canada. However, the wrecks narrowly escaped damage from large ships that dragged their anchors across the lake bottom, Ballard said. He said the furrows caused by the anchors were plainly visible near the wrecks. The wrecks remained undisturbed six miles off St. Catharines, 30 miles south of Toronto on the lake's southern shore, until their discovery in 1975. Since then, scientists such as French underwater explorer Jacques Cousteau have used submarines and remote cameras to explore them, but Ballard's expedition was the most technologically sophisticated yet. In an interview by ship-to-shore telephone, Ballard said the children's participation was the most significant part of the program. He said the remote control setup had never been used before. Ballard said the two-week expedition would produce a detailed map of the wrecks that Hamilton officials could use in deciding whether to raise them someday. Ballard, director of the Center for Marine Exploration at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, led the 1985 expedition that discovered the wreck of the Titanic. The storied ocean liner sank in the North Atlantic after ramming an iceberg in 1912. The museums taking part in the program were in Boston; Chicago; Dallas; Detroit; Memphis, Tenn.; Minneapolis; Rochester, N.Y.; Salt Lake City; Sarasota, Fla.; Toronto; Victoria, British Columbia; Washington; and Woods Hole, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Three Plead Innocent in St. John's Sex Attack
DOC.TEXT: Three St. John's University students pleaded innocent to charges of sexually assaulting a female student who said she passed out after being forced to down spiked drinks. Walter Gabrinowitz, 21, a senior; Andrew Draghi, 20, a junior; and Michael Calandrillo, 20, a junior, all of Bethpage were arraigned Monday on charges of sodomy, sexual abuse, sexual misconduct and unlawful imprisonment. They were released to the custody of their parents and suspended by the university on the same day. Gabrinowitz and Draghi are on the university's lacrosse team. Calandrillo is in the rifle club, as is the alleged victim. Assistant District Attorney Peter Reese said the incident occurred March 1, after the woman accepted a ride with Calandrillo from evening target practice. Calandrillo stopped at the house he shared with the other two, asked the victim in to meet his roommates, then forced her to have two drinks despite her insistence that she needed to get home to study, Reese said. The woman said she passed out and found Calandrillo and his housemates sexually abusing her when she intermittently regained consciousness. Reese said the woman was carried from the house and driven to a second home where she was further abused until a witness intervened and drove her home. Martin J. Healy, a spokesman for St. John's, said the woman on March 5 confided to a campus minister, who eventually persuaded her to speak with police on March 30. The university contacted the police for her, Healy said. The woman has withdrawn from classes and continues to receive counseling, he said. The school, with 19,000 students, is run by the Vincentian Fathers, a Roman Catholic order. Healy said the school would continue its investigation as part of normal disciplinary procedure against the suspended students. Reese said the district attorney's investigation also would continue. ``It doesn't end with these defendants. Others were involved,'' he said. Sodomy is punishable by eight and one-third to 25 years in prison. Mark Alfred, head of the university's largest black students' group, Haraya, said the issue was suppressed out of concern for the school's image as well as the victim's wishes. The woman is black and the accused men are white. Alfred was quoted as saying, ``As far as we are concerned, the school is handling it in an adequate manner.''

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow from Kilauea Continues Unabated
DOC.TEXT: A river of lava flowing from the Kilauea Volcano destroyed another house today and seemed certain to engulf the rest of a deserted subdivision. Residents, tourists and reporters have gathered in Kalapana, a beautiful coastal community on the big island of Hawaii, to watch the town's last days. The 2,000-foot-wide lava flow claimed two houses Monday, and today's casualty brought the total to 122 since Kilauea began its current eruption in 1983. ``This is a massive glacier of lava, at least a quarter of a mile wide, at least 10 to 40 feet high behind the front of the flow,'' said Hawaii County civil defense administrator Harry Kim. Only 17 houses remain in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision, and three were within 50 feet of the lava at dawn today, according to civil defense spokesman Craig Hindle. In addition, several buildings outside the subdivision lie within the path of the lava flow, including the Kalapana Store and Drive-In and the Star of the Sea Church. Parishioners were making plans to move the church, which sits on an oceanfront lot in the lava's path. A trucking company is moving the church for free, and workers removed the church pews, altar and other items Monday. Civil defense officials are worried that if the lava hits the ocean, it will release toxic sulfuric acid-tainted mist, known as ``laze.'' No one is still living in Kalapana Gardens. Residents are allowed in during the day, but are prohibited at night. Most have their belongings out, but come to say goodbye.

DOC.HEAD: Intra-Christian Fighting, Currency Deteriorates
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces again dueled with mortars and machine guns in east Beirut today, and police said one person was killed and six wounded. The nation's currency, meanwhile, declined to a 30-month low, reflecting the war-shattered economy. The clashes between troops of Gen. Michel Aoun and fighters of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia broke out around midnight, then subsided into intermittent machine gun exchanges by this morning. In the three-month-old fight for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave 920 people have died and 2,448 have been wounded, by police count. The conflict, the worst battle between Christians in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, has inflicted damage estimated at $1 billion and blocked plans by the Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi to unite the divided capital. A limited truce was declared Saturday to allow residents of Kesrouan province north of Beirut to salvage what they could from their homes. That truce was extended to 6 p.m. today, the Maronite Catholic Church announced. The Central Bank, meanwhile, announced in a currency exchange list published today that the Lebanese pound cosed Monday at 605 to the dollar, thge lowest exchange rate since the summer of 1987, when it hit 735 to the dollar. The currency regained some strength in 1988 and continued its gradual climb in 1989, reaching a rate of 334 to the dollar in February 1989. But when Aoun declared his ``war of liberation'' against the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon in March 1989 the currency again went into decline. Before the civil war broke out in April 1975 the Lebanese pound was one of the Middle East's most stable currencies, at 3.5 to the dollar. Hrawi's government, sworn in on Nov. 24, on April 21 announced a budget for fiscal 1990 with a record deficit of 64.83 percent. Government spending was estimated at $1 billion and revenues at $355 million. The government did not say how the deficit would be covered. Government authority has disintegrated throughout the war. Several sectors are controlled by the warring militias, which levy their own taxes on imports and income and impose fees for municipal services, electricity and protection. Aoun has refused to recognize Hrawi as head of state, preventing the president's Syrian-backed government from spreading its authority to the Christian enclave. The government has been reluctant to try to control other areas of Lebanon, dominated by Moslem and leftist militias, without gaining control of the Christian enclave first.

DOC.HEAD: List Sentenced to Five Life Terms For Killing His Family
DOC.TEXT: John E. List, the Sunday school teacher who methodically murdered his family 18 years ago, was sentenced today to five life terms to be served consecutively _ the maximum penalty. List, who did not take the stand during his trial, broke his silence, but refused to take responsibility for his crimes. ``I wish to inform the court I remain truly sorry for the tragic events of 1971,'' List said in a strong voice, staring straight ahead. ``I feel that because of my mental state at the time, I was unaccountable for what happened. I ask all affected by this, for their forgiveness, understanding and prayer.'' Superior Court Judge William L'E. Wertheimer, however, said that in the names of the murdered family, he was giving List the stiffest sentence he could. ``John Emil List is without remorse and without honor,'' Wertheimer said. ``After 18 years, five months and 22 days, it is now time for the voices of Helen, Alma, Patricia, Frederick and John F. List to rise from the grave.'' As the judge left the bench, the courtroom, filled with about 125 people, erupted in applause. List was convicted April 12 of murdering his wife, Helen, 46; mother Alma, 84; daughter, Patricia, 16; and sons John, 15, and Frederick, 13. Because of the former accountant's attention to detail in carrying out the slayings, the bodies remained in their 18-room Westfield home for almost a full month before they were discovered _ from Nov. 9, 1971, until Dec. 7. In the interim, List left New Jersey, changed his name and began a new life as Robert P. Clark. He eventually remarried, and worked as an accountant first in the Denver area and later near Richmond, Va. His second wife, Delores Clark, said she was unaware of his past. List was arrested last year after a television show re-enacted the crime. ``I think the case speaks for itself,'' prosecutor Eleanor Clark said Monday. ``We're asking for the maximum.'' Witnesses during the trial said List had written notes excusing his children from school and had the newspaper stopped. He turned down the thermostat to slow decomposition of the bodies, paid all his bills, cashed all his checks and left a note for the milkman telling him he wouldn't be needed for a while. Then he shot his family, one by one: his wife over breakfast, his mother when she asked what the noise was, and then each child as they returned from school. He left a note for his pastor and fled. His attorney's admitted List killed his family, but said he was mentally deficient at the time, a product of a strict Lutheran upbringing with the ``values and ethics of the 19th century.'' List had written to his pastor that he killed the family out of fear for their souls and out of economic distress. His attorney told jurors that on the day List killed his family, he ``entered hell with his eyes open.'' Defense attorney Elijah Miller wanted Wertheimer to allow the 64-year-old List to serve any sentences simultaneously. Miller said another option would be for Wertheimer to sentence List to life imprisonment on just one of the five murder convictions. Under penalties in place when List killed his family in 1971, the maximum sentence for List is five consecutive life sentences, which will keep him in jail for the rest of his life. If he had been sentenced to five concurrent life terms, however, he would be eligible for parole in 14 years, 11 months.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Settlers Leave Compound in Christian Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to move up settler being sentenced and add details. Pick up 3rd pvs, `They evacuated...' Deletes final graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Armed Jewish settlers honored a Supreme Court deadline today and left the compound they occupied for almost three weeks in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City. A district court judge, meanwhile, sentenced settler leader Rabbi Moshe Levinger to five months in prison for killing a Palestinian. Levinger shot and killed Kayed Hassan Salah, 42, on Sept. 30, 1988. He was initially charged with manslaughter, which carries a maximum jail term of 20 years. As part of a plea bargain he admitted to the lesser charge of causing death by negligence. Salah, a shoestore owner, was standing at the entrance to his shop when he was shot during a stone-throwing incident in the West Bank town of Hebron. At least 29 Palestinians have been slain by settlers since the start of the uprising nearly 29 months ago, according to Israeli human rights advocates. Besides Levinger, only one other settler has been sentenced to jail. In the Christian quarter, after heated arguments between settlers and clergymen, a six-member church delegation was allowed to inspect the complex to confirm that all the settlers who were supposed to leave had done so. ``They evacuated the settlement, except for 20 people,'' said Avraham Sochovolsky, an attorney for the Greek Orthodox Church, which owns the 72-room complex near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher. The 20 Israelis who stayed after the noon deadline were acting as caretakers for the Panama-based SBC company, which holds the lease that the church contends is invalid. The Supreme Court ruled last Thursday that 20 of the 150 settlers could stay pending settlement of the tenancy dispute. The settlement in the four-building St. John's Hospice provoked outcry from church groups, Washington and other governments when it was established April 11. It also fueled protest among Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem. The Old City is divided into zealously guarded Christian, Moslem, Jewish and Armenian quarters, and the slightest changes have historically resulted in conflict. In the past few days, reporters and photographers saw settlers leave the building in small groups _ apparently to avoid a mass exit that would look like a retreat. Earlier today, the settlers turned back a half-dozen priests who tried to enter the compound to confirm the evacuation claim, and also barred reporters. Dan Avi-Yitzhak, a lawyer for the 50 families who took over the building during Easter Week celebrations, said the settlers also gave a declaration to police that they had left the building. Shmuel Eviatar, a settler spokesman, read a statement as bells from the Church of the Holy Sepulcher and other nearby churches pealed loudly. ``No, there is no feeling of failure,'' Eviatar insisted. ``Honor for the court and a desire to fulfill not only the letter but the spirit of the law have led us to maintain only 20 tenants in the building holding the keys.'' Minutes after the noon deadline expired, a half-dozen bearded clergymen dressed in black cloaks came to the settlement and engaged in a 10-minute shouting match with the settlers' spokesman. Informed that the settlers had left, they pointed to a woman who could be seen through a window inside the building. Settlers said she was a cook. On Friday, Christian clergy closed holy sites throughout the Holy Land to protest the settlement. There have also been protests from the United States, Greece and Arab countries over the move into the Old City, which was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War and annexed by Israel. The settlers had sublet the property from an Armenian Christian. They argued Jews should be allowed to live anywhere, especially in the capital of the Jewish state. The move into the Christian quarter was seen as part of a broader campaign by right-wingers to push new settlement activity in the Israeli-occupied lands, taking advantage of a political vacuum. On March 15 the Labor Party left the government led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in a dispute over U.S. peace proposals. Shamir now leads the caretaker government and is trying to form a Cabinet. The U.S. government has criticized settlements as an obstacle to peace.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Set in Playboy Twin's Tax-Evasion Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former Playboy model, accused of evading taxes on money she received for having sex with an elderly millionaire, was a ``kept'' woman, a former accountant who prepared her tax returns said today. Prosecutors say Lynnette Harris, 35, and her twin sister accepted more than $1 million in cash and goods from businessman David Kritzik of suburban Shorewood. He died last year at age 89. Her sister, Leigh Ann Conley of Milwaukee, is charged with four counts of failing to file federal income tax returns in the same alleged scheme. She is scheduled to stand trial in June. The government alleged the money was paid in exchange for sex. Dennis Coffey, Ms. Harris' attorney, said Kritzik gave the money as gifts. Former accountant William G. Domer, who now operates a wholesale bakery, said he met Ms. Harris in February 1985 when she consulted with him about her taxes, showing him four 1983 checks from Kritzik totaling $100,000 and 1984 checks totaling $25,000 to $30,000. The 1983 checks were not reported to the Internal Revenue Service as income, Domer said. ``I had assumed and I had a conversation with Mr. Kritzik that led me to feel those amounts were a gift,'' he said. Domer said Ms. Harris told him the money was for a facial reconstruction she underwent in California. The 1984 checks were listed on Ms. Harris's tax return as ``other income,'' Domer said. He said he had no reason to think the checks in 1984 were gifts. When asked what he thought of Ms. Harris' relationship with Kritzik, Domer said, ``The word `kept' pops into my mind.'' Before Ms. Harris' jury was selected Monday, U.S. District Judge Thomas Curran rejected an Internal Revenue Service affidavit in which Kritzik characterized her as a prostitute was inadmissable. Loss of the affidavit as evidence may make the government's case more difficult to prove, because it is believed to be the only statement from Kritzik implicating the twins in the sex-for-money arrangement. Ms. Harris, a former actress and model, faces two counts of tax evasion and two counts of failure to file income tax returns. The charges carry a maximum penalty of 12 years in prison and $625,000 in fines. In opening statements, U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson said government documents and witnesses would show that ``the payments were taxable, she knew it and willfully evaded it.'' Coffey told the jury the evidence would prove that many of the government's witnesses ``are serving their own interests by testifying.'' The identical blonde twins, who appeared nude together in two movies and in a 1981 edition of Playboy, allegedly spent alternate nights with Kritzik for more than five years until June 1987. IRS agent James Ansier, who interviewed Kritzik in December 1987 at his Palm Springs, Calif., home, testified Monday that Kritzik told him the checks he wrote to Ms. Harris were payments for services. ``He said it was not a gift,'' Ansier said. ``He was clear and convincing in everything he said.'' In throwing out the affidavit, Curran said he believed an unexpected visit by an IRS agent ``strikes fear in the heart of any reasonable person.'' Curran said it was safe to assume Kritzik thought the IRS was investigating his own financial affairs and had ``sufficient motivation,'' to ``claim these payments were for services rendered.'' ``The court is of the position that Mr. Kritzik found himself between the proverbial rock and a hard place,'' the judge said. Curran also said he suspected Kritzik answered the questions without ``realizing he might place Ms. Harris in a difficult position.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Extends Freeze on Military Contracts
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has extended a three-month freeze on new military building contracts by 45 days and suggested cutting nearly $750 million in other defense construction, sources said today. The moratorium, which took effect Jan. 24, expired Monday. But in a memorandum to Pentagon officials, Cheney said the freeze should continue until June 15. The Associated Press obtained a copy of the memo in advance of a briefing Cheney scheduled to discuss the moratorium extension. In he memo, Cheney directs Deputy Secretary of Defense Donald J. Atwood to prepare a list of proposed military construction projects that merit cancellation and submit that list to him by June 1. Cheney attached his own candidates for such a list, suggesting $322 million in overseas construction projects and $427 million in domestic projects that might well be cut. In preparing a recission list, Cheney said Pentagon officials should consider ``base closures and realignments, changes in the force structure and disposition of the armed forces, including fiscal constraints on resources for national defense, and any other matters that affect the Department's need for military construction.'' The moratorium, part of a series of belt-tightening moves, includes contracts for architectural and engineering design services. The only exceptions to the freeze are those permitted by Atwood ``to meet urgent requirements,'' according to the memo. The Pentagon's 1990 fiscal military construction budget as approved by Congress was about $8.5 billion. The budget made cuts in foreign bases, but added money for domestic installations. Cheney's recission list recommends cutting all Navy homeport projects in the Gulf of Mexico, a suggestion that drew immediate criticism from Sen. Lloyd Bentsen. ``I urge you to reverse those decisions,'' said Bentsen, D-Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says U.S. to Consider Adding Iraq to Terrorism List
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs Baker testimony; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The report,...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will consider returning Iraq to its list of countries that sponsor international terrorism, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Congress today. Baker said Iraq's efforts to develop a nuclear program was ``particularly disturbing.'' Iraq was removed from the list in 1984. ``I think we have to take a look at this issue, and we will be taking a look at this issue,'' Baker told a Senate appropriations subcommittee a day after the State Department's annual report to Congress on terrorism. That report cited six nations for sponsoring international terrorism, including Syria and Iran, which won praise from President Bush on Monday for their help in the release of American hostage Frank H. Reed in Lebanon. Countries on the list are denied advanced American technology and U.S. support for various international bank loans. In addition to Syria and Iran, the list includes Libya, Cuba, North Korea and South Yeman. Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., told Baker that whatever the administration's decision, he would promote legislation in Congress to put Iraq on the terrorism list. Baker said the administration was considering several sanctions against the Iraqi government, including a denial of credits for agricultural purchases. But he cautioned, ``We ought to be at least conscious if we take that action, our allies will be very quick to pick up our market there,'' he said. The State Department terrorism report credited Syria and Libya with showing some improvement. And it said Iran had a slight decline _ from 32 incidents of supporting terrorism in 1988 to 28 last year. The report, released Monday, recorded a sharp drop worldwide as well as among American victims. Sixteen U.S. citizens were killed and 19 wounded, compared with 192 killed and 40 wounded in 1988; the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, accounted for most of the 1988 deaths. Overall, the number of terrorist incidents fell off nearly 38 percent _ from 856 in 1988 to 528 last year. Syria and Iran remain on the State Department's list of supporters of terrorism, though Syria's willingness to help liberate Western hostages and a pledge by President Hafez Assad to punish perpetrators were noted. On the other hand, Syria continued to provide support and safe haven for a wide variety of groups engaged in terrorism, the report said. Among them is the militant Hezbollah group, with which holders of the six remaining American hostages in Lebanon are considered linked. Iran, meanwhile, was accused in the report of continuing to use terrorism after the death of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in June in pursuit of its foreign policy goals. Examples cited by the report included a call for the death of Salman Rushdie, author of ``The Satanic Verses,'' and increased attacks against interests of Saudi Arabia, including explosion of two bombs during the Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca. President Hashemi Rafsanjani, sometimes credited with taking a moderate stance, was criticized for exhorting Palestinians to kill Americans and other Westerners in order to avenge Palestinians killed during the rebellion against Israel on the West Bank and in Gaza. Rafsanjani also publicly encouraged the hijacking of airplanes and the blowing up of factories, the report said. Libya, while listed as a sponsor of terrorism, was credited in the report with continuing to show public signs of moderation. There were no incidents throughout the year directly attributable to the North African country led by Col. Moammar Gadhafi, the report said. With the level of terrorism in sharp decline worldwide, the only spectacular operation was the bombing of a French airliner over Niger last September, causing 171 deaths. Also, the Afghan government curtailed its terrorist campaign in neighboring Pakistan and operations by groups associated with the Palestine Liberation Organization sharply declined after Chairman Yasser Arafat publicly renounced terrorism in December 1988, the report said. A change in accounting by the State Department's Counter-Terrorism Office also contributed to the dropoff. For the first time, violence by Palestinians against Palestinians on the West Bank and in Gaza is not considered an act of international terrorism. The reason, the report said in a footnote, is that the attacks are a form of ``intra-ethnic violence,'' meaning within the same group. This helped bring the overall total down. The 528 incidents of terrorism recorded by the State Department resulted in 390 victims killed and 397 wounded. Fourteen terrorists were killed and 23 wounded. In 1988, by contrast, 638 victims were killed and 1,125 were wounded. Most of the attacks occurred in the Middle East, followed by Latin America and Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: `Lost' Lucille Ball Pilot Wins CBS Top Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Television viewers continue to show how much they love Lucy. The 39-year-old pilot for what became CBS' classic ``I Love Lucy'' series got higher ratings than the combined ratings of two new shows opposing it, prelminary audience estimates showed today. Hosted by Lucie Arnaz, daughter of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, the one-hour CBS special, ``I Love Lucy: The Very First Show,'' averaged a 21.7 rating and a 37 percent share of the audience in 24 cities Monday night. That easily outpaced the 9.6 rating and 16 percent audience share of NBC's ``Shannon's Deal'' and the 6.3 rating and 11 percent audience share of ABC's ``Capital News'' in the same time period. The Ball show got its largest audiences in Cincinnati and Minneapolis, where it attracted 46 percent and 45 percent of the audience in its time period, respectively. Monday's CBS special was the premiere of the 34-minute ``I Love Lucy'' pilot, made on kinescope on March 10, 1951, when Ball, who died last year, was five months pregnant with her daughter. The pilot, produced by Ball and her husband with $5,000 of their own money, never was broadcast until Monday. CBS preferred a different opening episode when the series began. CBS televised ``I Love Lucy'' from 1951 to 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Panaman's President Endara Visits Capitol Hill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs on Endara meeting with congressional leaders and ADDS Baker comment; picks up 4th grafs pvs, Prospects for
DOC.TEXT: Panamanian President Guillermo Endara went today to Capitol Hill, where a bill containing $420 million for his country inched its way through a tangle of unrelated amendments in the Senate. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he hoped to complete the supplemental money bill today and send it to a conference with the House to work out differences between competing versions. Endara, who met with President Bush on Monday, conferred with House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. He planned later meetings with Mitchell and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. At the same time, Secretary of State James A. Baker III chastised Congress for delaying the aid package. ``I really worry that we have succumbed to the temptation to play politics with the future of freedom and democracy in Central America,'' he told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee. Prospects for the bill brightened late Monday when the Senate accepted by voice vote two provisions that had been road blocks, dealing with abortions and the death penalty in the District of Columbia. Senators agreed to allow use of D.C. funds to pay for abortions for poor women, and permit the death penalty for drug-related murders in the district, with the understanding that final wording would be worked out in negotiations with the House. They also agreed to limit additional amendments to a list including Lithuania, Cuba, and aid to South American countries trying to halt drug production. But if the abortion payment provision remains in the bill, Bush has vowed to veto it, which would lead to further delay. ``I've asked and asked again that our aid package to the newly liberated people of Panama be passed and passed swiftly. And still it waits, and with it the future of the fledgling democracy,'' Bush said, Endara at his side, after the two leaders met for 2{ hours on Monday. Endara was installed as president last Dec. 20 after U.S. invasion forces toppled the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush is seeking a quick infusion of U.S. aid to help restart the country's economy, stalled by U.S. economic sanctions and damage from the invasion. The aid measure also includes $300 million that Bush requested for the new democratic government of Nicaragua, along with hundreds of millions in spending added by Congress for domestic programs ranging from food stamps to veterans' benefits and pet local projects. During Endara's White House visit, Bush announced plans to nominate the first Panamanian to manage the Panama Canal: Gilberto Guardia Fabrega, 60, president of a Panama City architectural and engineering company. The 1978 Panama Canal treaties call for a Panamanian to be put n charge ths year, subject to Senate confirmation. The U.S.-built canal is to be turned over to Panama in the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Suarez Mason Ordered To Pay $8 Million Damage Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `He was ...' to ADD detail that Suarez Mason remains jailed, awaiting trial.
DOC.TEXT: A former Argentine general accused of ordering mass murders has been ordered to pay damages totaling $89 million in three lawsuits, but it's possible none of the money will ever be collected. Lawyers for plaintiffs who blame Carlos Suarez Mason for atrocities in Argentine military prisons believe he possesses hidden wealth, but they have been unable to find it. In a ruling made public Monday, U.S. District Judge Lowell Jensen ordered Suarez Mason, who was extradited to his homeland, to pay $8 million to two former Argentines whose relatives were tortured and killed in the 1970s. The plaintiffs, now residents of Alexandria, Va., sought a total of $40 million in damages. Two earlier damage awards included $21 million to a lawyer who was tortured repeatedly during four years' imprisonment and $60 million to the relatives of three men who were killed. Suarez Mason commanded the First Army Corps in Buenos Aires under the military government from 1976 to 1979. He was arrested in a San Francisco suburb in January 1987 and extradited to Argentina in May 1988 to face 39 murder charges, all involving the killing of prisoners by soldiers under his command. He remains jailed in Buenos Aires, awaiting trial. As Suarez Mason awaited extradition, several former Argentines living in the United States sued him for damages. Those complaints were filed under laws allowing suits for international human rights violations committed by a foreigner who has come under the jurisdiction of a U.S. court. Suarez Mason did not file answers to the suits and was held in default. Jensen said one of the plaintiffs in his ruling, Debora Benchoam, was held without charges from July 1977 to November 1981. He said she was tortured and sexually abused several times and robbed of her jewelry by forces under Suarez Mason's control. She also was forced to watch as the soldiers twice shot her brother Reuben, who was later beaten and murdered, according to the judge. Jensen awarded her $3 million for pain and suffering and $3 million in punitive damages. The second plaintiff, Alfredo Forti, and his mother and four brothers were abducted by Suarez Mason's soldiers, held for a week without charges and robbed of most of their belongings, Jensen said. He said Forti was separated from his mother, who was never seen or heard from again. In an earlier ruling in the case, Jensen ruled that causing the ``disappearance'' of Forti's mother was a violation of international law subject to a damage suit in this country. Forti's lawyer said it was the first such ruling by a U.S. court. Jensen awarded Forti $1 million for emotional distress and $1 million in punitive damages.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Freeze Extension on Military Construction; Homeports Reviewed
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout with additional detail
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney extended the Pentagon's freeze on military construction projects today and ordered that 207 projects _ including four controversial Navy ports in Texas, Alabama, Mississippi and New York _ be reviewed for possible cancellation. Cheney's action will cause consternation on Capitol Hill, which has been locked with Cheney in a tense debate over slashing the defense budget and some lawmaker's attempts to protect local jobs. Cheney, in a statement issued at the Pentagon, said the order affects ``more than $7 billion in new construction contracts'' in the United States, Western Europe and the Pacific. The 207 construction projects to be reviewed are valued at $1.2 billion and include four of the sites identified by the Navy as strategic home ports in Ingleside, Texas; Mobile, Ala.; Pascagoula, Miss.; and Staten Island, N.Y., the statement said. The secretary said he was forced to continue the freeze _ instituted in January _ through June 15th because of possible budget cutbacks ordered by Capitol Hill and the sweeping changes in international events. ``In light of the enormous uncertainty over the level of funding that Congress will approve for future defense budgets, including the budget for fiscal 1991, I have no choice but to extend the construction freeze,'' Cheney said. Citing changes in the world situation and increasing budget limitations, Cheney said, ``Signifcant opportunities exist to reduce the cost and size of the future infrastructure for the Department of Defense. ``Some of these actions may not be popular with members of Congress who want to cut the defense budget even as they plead to save the projects in their own states and districts,'' he said. ``But when tight budgets force dedicated soldiers to turn in their uniforms and leave the service, I cannot put construction projects ahead of people.'' The House was scheduled to vote today on a House Budget Committee proposal that would significantly reduce defense spending from President Bush's proposed $303.3 billion for fiscal 1991. The secretary's order directs that no new construction contracts be awarded for projects financed under the military construction budget approved by Congress. The 207 construction projects will be ``candidates for rescission,'' which means Cheney may recommend that Congress revoke the funding approve for earlier projects. The statement said Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood will review the Department's construction plans for possible cancellation and submit a proposed list of rescissions to Cheney by June 1. The statement said that besides the four ports, the review will also include the items: _$110 million for the large rocket test facility at Arnold, Tenn. _$60 millin in improvements at Fort Hood and Red River Army Depot in Texas. _$37 millino for the consolidated maintenance facility at Tooele, Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Just Call Her Sir, Female Sailor Says
DOC.TEXT: The first woman to go to sea on a Royal Navy ship says the enlisted men often call her ``sir'' by mistake. ``I get called sir probably half the time because the majority of the ratings (sailors) forget I'm female,'' Second Officer Chella Franklin said Tuesday. ``I'm there wearing trousers and a tie and doing a job and they don't really think about it.'' The 26-year-old officer should be called ``ma'am,'' but she says: ``I'm happy they accept me that easily.'' Ms. Franklin is assigned to the Royal Navy's newest ship, HMS Norfolk, where she is responsible for managing the people who maintain the frigate's sophisticated weapons equipment. A member of the Women's Royal Naval Reserve (Wrens), Ms. Franklin was with the ship when it was being built and officially joined her company in February when it was announced Wrens would be allowed to go to sea. As an officer she has her own cabin and shares one of the two showers for the 11 officers, hanging a sign outside reading ``Out of bounds, lady showering.''

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Bus Plunges Into Ravine, 13 Killed
DOC.TEXT: A passenger bus skidded off a slippery road and plunged into a 300-foot ravine in the Ilgaz mountains early Tuesday, killing 13 people and injuring 27, the state-run radio reported. The bus was traveling from the northern city of Kastamonu to Ankara when the accident happened in this township about 110 miles north of Ankara, the radio said. The 27 injured passengers were taken to state hospitals in Ilgaz, Cankiri and Kastamonu for treatment, the radio said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Weapons on White-Owned Farm
DOC.TEXT: Police uncovered a cache of weapons and explosives buried on a white-owned farm near Harare, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Officers found machine guns, anti-tank mines, mortar, rocket launchers, mostly of Soviet and Eastern European origin, and 19 AK-47 automatic assault rifles. The items were stashed in an old mine shaft at the farm about 12 miles north of Harare, The Herald reported. Police arrested the farm's owner, David Wheeler, according to The Herald, which is published by the state-owned Mass Media Trust. He was released on a $40,000 bond and was allowed to return to his $1.8 million property. There was no indication whether the arms were hidden during or after the seven-year guerrilla war that led to Zimbabwe's independence in 1980. Guerrillas had been equipped with Soviet and Chinese weapons in the independence war.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Government to Restart Savannah River Reactor in December
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 13 grafs on Watkins announcing resumption schedule; picks up 9th graf pvs, Lisa Crawford
DOC.TEXT: The government will restart the first of three tritium production reactors at its South Carolina atomic weapons plant in December and resume producing plutonium triggers by next July at a Colorado plant, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today. Watkins told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that four plants, including three reactors at its Savannah River complex in South Carolina, will resume producing nuclear weapons components by the end of 1991. The three reactors have been shut down since mid-1988 over environmental and safety-related concerns. U.S. nuclear weapons production has ground to a halt in the past several months because of that and suspension of operations at the Rocky Flats plant in Colorado last November over similar concerns, . Watkins said the K reactor at Savannah River is tentatively scheduled to reopen with low-power testing on Dec. 10, followed by full-power production in late December or early January. The P reactor at Savannah River is to be restarted next March, with production of weapons components scheduled to resume in April, he said. The L reactor at Savannah River will be restarted in September 1991, Watkins said. In addition, he said two facilities at the Rocky Flats plant for producing the plutonium triggers in atomic warheads will resume operations in June and July. ``At this time, there does not seem to be any alternative for the nation other than keeping Rocky Flats on line to deal with warhead management,'' Watkings told the strategic forces and nuclear deterrence subcommittee. Environmental and antinuclear groups and organizations of local residents living near the plants asked Watkins at a meeting Monday to request a moratorium on weapons production. But members of the Senate panel said the country cannot afford to go without weapons production indefinitely. ``I wish I could say we don't need any production of weapons material,'' said subcommittee Chairman J. James Exon, D-Neb. ``That is not the case. The Soviet Union is going to be relying on its nucelar deterrent as a strategy than ever before.'' Watkins repeated his Monday assertion to the coalition of environmental and antinuclear groups that the president, Congress and the secretary of defense determine the need for weapons production. ``It's my job to deliver the goods,'' he told the coalition, called the Military Production Network. Lisa Crawford of the Fernald Residents for Environmental Safety and Health, which recently won a $78 million court settlement against the Energy Department's former contractor at the Fernald uranium processing plant in Ohio, said the government must be more open about operations at nuclear weapons factories. ``The folks who live around these ... facilities are really disillusioned,'' she told Watkins. She said she and others who lived near the Fernald plant learned in 1985 they had been drinking from a uranium-contaminated well since 1981, and that the government had known but did not tell them. The department has agreed to a wide study of the environmental impact of weapons plant modernization, but has not said this would affect its schedule for getting the main production plants back on line after lengthy shutdowns. At a news conference before meeting Watkins, coalition leaders criticized him for failing to change the department's acknowledged record of improving weapons production at the expense of environmental protection and public health. On Watkins' list of priorities, like those of his predecessors, ``production of new nuclear weapons comes first, comes second and comes third; environmental protection comes after that,'' said Elizabeth Paul, director of the Snake River Alliance, an Idaho-based citizens group that opposes further arms production. Watkins has repeatedly declared his intention to put environmental protection on a par with weapons production. The group also presented what it called a report card on Watkins' performance since he took the helm of the Energy Department 14 months ago. They gave him an ``A'' for public relations, a ``D-plus'' for compliance with environmental laws, a ``C-minus'' for protecting worker and community health and a ``D'' for openness and accountability.

DOC.HEAD: Two French Doctors Expelled From Morocco
DOC.TEXT: The government has expelled two French doctors investigating alleged human-rights abuses in Moroccan jails, a French Embassy spokesman said Tuesday. Marie-Helene Beaujolin and Helene Jaffe were politely asked by police to leave the country Monday after they met last weekend with former prisoners, the embassy spokesman said. ``Everything happened very discreetly and the women were never mistreated,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. ``They were not arrested, nor detained in a commissariat or police post.'' The two doctors belong to the Paris-based Association for the Victims of Repression and were investigating conditions in the North African country's prisons and jails. The London-based human rights group Amnesty International has accused King Hassan II's police of torturing and mistreating suspects held in custody pending the filing of criminal charges. The government denies the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Government, ANC Play Down Upcoming Talks
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress and the white minority government on Tuesday cautioned against high expectations for their historic talks this week on removing obstacles to constitutional negotiations. ``The public should not be misled,'' the ANC's press liaison officer, Patrick Lekota, said at a news briefing on the eve of the scheduled three-day discussions. ``What is taking place tomorrow is talks about talks.'' Gerrit Viljoen, minister of constitutional development, said the government realized the urgency of the talks because of widespread violence in South Africa. ``But we also believe it will take time to build trust and understanding as a foundation for finding mutually satisfactory solutions and for them to have a good chance of working,'' he said. Both sides have predicted negotiations will be long and tedious with many major fundamental differences to be resolved. The ANC is demanding the government end a state of emergency and release all political prisoners as preconditions for full talks. The government is demanding the ANC renounce its ``armed struggle'' and help end political violence that has claimed hundreds of lives in recent weeks. The talks, scheduled to begin Wednesday at the government's luxurious Groote Schuur estate, will involve a Cabinet team led by President F.W. de Klerk and a delegation of exiled and internal ANC leaders headed by Deputy ANC President Nelson Mandela. The ANC has been seeking talks with the government since it was formed in 1918. De Klerk legalized the ANC, Communist Party and other opposition groups in February, when he also freed Mandela. At the time, he urged black leaders to negotiate the end of apartheid and help develop a new constitution that would give an equal voice in government to the voteless black majority while preserving the political, economic and cultural rights of whites and other minority groups. Both sides have taken pains to emphasize that this week's meetings are not negotiations, but only talks aimed at removing obstacles and creating a proper climate for eventual discussions on a new constitution. The government has promised its white constituency that it will negotiate only with groups that renounce violence. De Klerk has said the ANC leaders' continued calls for armed struggle hinder the chances for negotiations. The government and the ANC may not resolve all of their differences this week and further exploratory talks may be necessary, according to government officials. No date has been set for full-scale negotiations. Lekota said members of the ANC delegation _ protected at an exclusive hotel by security police and ANC marshals _ were busy Tuesday refining their approach to the talks. He read a statement in which the ANC delegation said its morale was high. ``The delegation is very enthusiastic and it is confident that it will match the government's side,'' Lekota said. About 2,000 people marched in mixed-race townships outside Cape Town Tuesday in the first legal May Day march at which the Communist Party flag was carried. Late last year the government declared May Day a workers' holiday in response to years of protests and illegal strikes by black trade unions. Police reported Tuesday that six people had died, seven were wounded and many houses and vehicles were damaged in unrest on Sunday and Monday. Police said four women, including an 80-year-old, were burned to death near Port Shepstone on the southern Natal coast, where black factions have been engaged in a power struggle for the past two weeks. Six people were injured when police fired at violent groups or defended themselves against mob attacks, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Butler Who Sued Ex-Boss Over Alleged AIDS Discrimination Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jose ``Tony'' Deleu, a butler who claimed he was fired by a Manhattan socialite because he had AIDS, has died. He was 47. Deleu died Friday at New York Hospital and a funeral was held Monday. Hours before his death, Deleu said he forgave his employer, saying: ``I don't have any hard feelings. I feel very bad about all this,'' according to Deleu's brother, Carlos. Deleu had filed a $1.5 million discrimination lawsuit against France Scaife, wife of an heir to the Mellon family fortune and a committeewoman on the Pittsburgh AIDS Task Force. Deleu's attorney, David Spears, said the discrimination claim was recently dropped because of a loophole in the state anti-discrimination law that exempts domestics. Spears said he planned to continue fighting Deleu's lawsuit on charges that Mrs. Scaife owed him overtime pay and Social Security and health insurance benefits. Deleu worked as Mrs. Scaife's butler at her Upper East Side apartment for seven years. Mrs. Scaife's lawyer, Bruce Kaplan, said his client, ``grieves for him and his loved ones.''

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Officially Announces Bid For Second Term
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mike Sullivan, who came into office four years ago on a campaign to spur Wyoming's economy, reiterated that pledge today in announcing his bid for a second term. Sullivan, 50, a Democrat who left his Casper law practice in 1986 to make his first bid for public office, said he had succeeded if for no other reason than that the economy hasn't been the ``economic wasteland'' some predicted. ``There is no question that we've made sacrifices, that it's been a lot of hard work, and it's been difficult times in Wyoming,'' Sullivan told a crowd of supporters who gathered at his office to hear his announcement. ``But some of the dire predictions, the doom and gloom that was predicted four years ago, has been averted.'' The governor said he expects his likely opponent, Republican Mary Mead, to challenge his claim that the economy has improved. She is a Jackson rancher, the daughter of former Gov. Cliff Hansen. Sullivan is expected to face only token opposition in the Aug. 21 Democratic primary. When Sullivan ran for his first term, Wyoming was in the depths of a recession induced by the slump in its oil industry. Oil prices are a bit more stable now, but remain low enough to discourage major exploration and production in Wyoming's oil fields. Without that production, the Sullivan administration has worked on increasing international trade and tourism. Among other things, the governor has thrown his support behind a $250 million low-interest loan for use in enticing companies to build a natural gas pipeline from Wyoming to California that will carry Wyoming gas.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Apparently Slays Self Hours After Classmate Shoots Self in School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with second suicide, quotes from classmate, further details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A second high school student fatally shot himself only hours after a fellow student professed his love for a girl and shot himself to death in front of her and classmates, officials say. Thomas M. Chidester, a 19-year-old senior who died Monday evening of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound, wasn't in the American history class where junior Thomas Smith, 17, killed himself. Chidester attended ``a class or two'' with Smith, said Steve Brown, assistant superintendent of the Sheridan School District. He referred questions about the second death to the Grant County sheriff's office. Police and sheriff's officials declined to comment immediately. The deaths were the second and third suicides by Sheridan High School students in the last month, and fourth suicide in five weeks in the community of 3,000 about 25 miles south of Little Rock, police said. Smith was pronounced dead about four hours after asking his teacher for permission to speak to his fifth-period class, Police Chief David Hooks said. ``I think he said he loved a girl, pulled the gun out and waved it around, put it to his forehead and pulled the trigger,'' Hooks said. Rhonda Damron, 17, of Sheridan said Smith was talking about her. ``He said he wanted to say two things about his weekend: One, he was in love with me, and ... then he pulled the gun from the front of his pants and shot himself,'' she said. Ms. Damron said she and Smith had been classmates since sixth grade and became ``very, very close friends'' last year. ``We would tell each other everything. That was all it was,'' she said. She said history teacher Rick Ward gave Smith permission to speak to the class for five minutes ``if he didn't say anything not proper for school.'' Ms. Damron said Smith ``was always interrupting the class.'' She said Smith took Ward's place behind the podium in the class. ``I put my head on my desk and when I looked up he had the gun out,'' she said. ``Everyone started screaming, `No. No.''' She said Ward moved toward the teen-ager and told Smith not to use the gun. ``He slowed down then because it seemed like the faster he went, the faster Thomas went,'' Ms. Damron said. ``Then he shot himself.'' Brown said mental health counselors were at the school this morning to help students cope. He said teachers were told before school began how to deal with the students, and classes began as normal at 8:10 a.m. Smith shot himself once in the head with a small-caliber handgun, police said. Authorities don't know where the student obtained the gun, which was recovered. An autopsy will be performed by the state medical examiner, Hook said. Smith, who teachers said was not a discipline problem, was the son of a Grant County auxiliary sheriff's deputy, Stanley Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Chefs Whip Up Huge 80,000-Egg Omelette
DOC.TEXT: A platoon of chefs Tuesday whipped up an 80,000-egg omelette filled with 1,763 pounds of mushrooms, then dished out portions with bread and drinks to 22,000 people. The omelette took 26 chefs three hours to cook on a pan 39 feet wide, organizers reported. The event was staged in this eastern French city to raise money for charities in France and West Germany. Other ingredients included 26 pounds of salt, 4.4 pounds of pepper and 20 gallons of oil.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Leaders Supporting Bush on Hostages
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES with Fitzwater quotes as new grafs 9-12, bgng, White House ...
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders today gave President Bush strong support for his refusal to bargain for the release of American hostages in Lebanon and expressed hope ``we're seeing the beginning of the end'' of their captivity. Bush met at the White House with Democratic and Republican leaders one day after educator Frank Reed was released following 43 months in captivity. He was the second American freed in eight days, following the April 22 release of Robert Polhill, who was held for 39 months. ``I think the president has strong support in his view that we can't bargain hostage-by-hostage,'' House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., said afterward. ``The basic position that we don't bargain for the release of hostages is one widely shared by the Congress as well as the executive branch,'' he said. Expressing hopes for freedom of the six Americans still in captivity, Foley said, ``We're seeing the beginning of the end of the hostage-taking and the hostage-holding.'' The speaker steered clear of discussing Congress' attitude toward the 400 Shiite prisoners held by Israel. Saying these are delicate matters, Foley said, ``I think we want to do whatever is useful in encouraging the release of people who have been held without cause or without reason.'' On Monday, Bush gently nudged Israel to release a Shiite cleric, Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, and others as demanded by a Tehran newspaper as a next step in the process. Bush said he had ``certainly no objection'' to such an action, adding, ``And that is a matter for others to determine.'' In the past, Israel has freed hundreds of Arab prisoners to attain the release of a handful of Israeli captives. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, pressed to elaborate on Bush's comment, said Israel is a sovereign nation and the United States will not tell it what to do. However, he said, ``Our policy is that all hostages should be released.'' He refused to say whether the United States considers the Shiites as hostages or prisoners of war. Meanwhile, Fitzwater said State Department legal adviser Abraham Sofaer was in the Netherlands at the Hague for a regularly scheduled meeting of the Iran-U.S. claims tribunal, which is arbitrating legal and financial disputes between the two countries. Fitzwater said the meeting was not connected with the hostages' release. As he met with congressional leaders today, Bush said ``it is joyous news'' that Reed was released. He also noted that Polhill had given him a secret message Monday from his captors but refused to comment further on the hostages. Bush publicly praised Syria and Iran for exerting pressure on the kidnappers. Yet, Bush also prodded Syria and Iran to work for the release of more hostages, emphasizing they should not expect normal relations or ``vast improvement until all Americans are freed.'' ``When a step is taken that goes toward that day when all hostages are released, I should say thank you,'' Bush said. ``But beyond that, I can't say that I can be happy. ``I've tried to put myself in the place of the other families and say, `Hey, what about my loved one?' So this is a tough business,'' the president said. Appearing before a Senate appropriations subcommittee, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was asked what the United States might be asked to due in return for assistance by Iran and Syria in gaining release of Polhill and Reed. ``I will not comment on what we are being asked to do, directly or indirectly,'' replied Baker. He went on to say that ``our policy is that we should not engage in deal-making'' over hostages. Ignoring the advice of some advisers, Bush took no steps to postpone the release of a State Department report on terrorism that criticized both Syria and Iran. The report, marring the two nations' efforts to improve their reputations, said Iran still uses terrorism in pursuit of foreign policy goals, and Syria continues to support a variety of terrorist groups. As Reed was relishing his first hours of freedom in Damascus, Syria, Bush met at the White House with Polhill, who has been undergoing treatment at Walter Reed Army Medical Center here. Polhill, suffering from a growth on his vocal cords, spoke in a raspy whisper. He said he could not offer much information about the other hostages. During an hour-long meeting with Bush, Polhill delivered a message from his kidnappers. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the contents would not be revealed publicly because Polhill had guaranteed his captors that it would be ``private and personal to President Bush only.'' The president's words of praise for Iran in Reed's release were in sharp contrast to his reluctance to give Tehran much credit when Polhill was freed. Iranian officials were said to have been furious over what was perceived as a slight. In the latest instance, Bush singled out Iran for ``using its influence to help bring about this humanitarian step.'' U.S. officials said privately the words were intended as a reward for Iran, which after years of isolation from the West, was seeking recognition for positive deeds. Iran, meanwhile, said no more Americans would be released unless the United States reciprocated with a gesture of Bush's oft-stated promise that ``goodwill begets goodwill.'' ``Now the ball is in the court of the U.S. and the Western countries,'' said the English-language Tehran Times, considered close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Asked if he was ready to make a goodwill gesture in return for the hostages' release, Bush said all must be freed. ``We're not in a piecemeal basis, bidding for one human life, holding out hopes, only to have them dashed for one American family or another,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Dangled From Bridge Sentenced to 100 Hours Community Service
DOC.TEXT: ``Mega Man,'' a disabled man who was arrested for dangling by ropes from the George Washington Bridge, has been ordered to perform 100 hours of community service in a hospital. ``Once I do my 100 hours, I'll do 100 more just for myself,'' Mega Man, whose real name is Raymond Muhammed, said at his sentencing Monday. To encourage other disabled people to reach their potential, Muhammed has pulled other stunts in and over the water, with and without his wheelchair. The 42-year-old Bronx resident, who was left disabled after being caught in a street shooting 13 years ago, was arrested at the bridge June 5 and charged with reckless endangerment, a felony. He pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of trespassing. Manhattan Criminal Court Judge Barbara Newman sentenced him to work with the physically disabled at St. Claire's Hospital. At the Brooklyn Bridge in August 1988, Mega Man suspended himself and his wheelchair from a rope over the East River. Soon after, he rolled himself off the Staten Island ferry into the water near the Statue of Liberty. ``People look at you in a wheelchair like you got to be homebound or on welfare,'' Muhammad complained. ``You are handicapped only in your mind.'' Muhammad, who now works as an actor and has appeared in the soap opera ``As the World Turns,'' told the judge his plans include water skiing in a chair around the southern end of Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Texas to Stop Funding Schools Until Financing Reformed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with judge granting state more time for reform plan. Picks up 8th graf pvs: `The Legislature .. .'
DOC.TEXT: A state district judge today gave state lawmakers an additional month to reform school finance, but said he also was appointing a special master to draw up an alternate plan in case legislators again fail. Earlier today, Judge Scott McCown ruled that nearly $500 million in state education aid can't be paid to local school districts as scheduled on May 25. In a second hearing, McCown gave the state an extension until June 1 to develop a new school finance plan. But, McCown said the court will work concurrently with the executive and legislative branches by appointing a special master to draw an equitable school finance plan. The court's plan will go into effect on Sept. 1 if the Legislature doesn't have its own finance plan ready by then, McCown said. ``The present scheme of public school finance is a great wrong,'' he said. ``The poor have waited for too long.'' State officials had asked for a 50-day delay to give lawmakers and Gov. Bill Clements more time to work out a school finance reform plan. With the state Legislature's 30-day session at an end, House Speaker Gib Lewis said Clements would call lawmakers into another special session _ the third on education _ at 2 p.m. Wednesday. The state's highest court last year called the $13.5 billion school system unfair to property-poor school districts and ordered a reform plan by today, but lawmakers and the governor are locked in a battle over increasing taxes to pay for reform. McCown's ruling doesn't apply to non-state sources of school funds, including local and federal aid. State officials have said they believe schools can remain open at least until May 25, when the $500 million monthly aid payment was due to go out. The judge also said the state can pay the $2.7 million payroll for Texas Education Agency employees that had been held up pending his ruling. State Comptroller Bob Bullock had said earlier that he intended to freeze education payments, including payroll checks. The Legislature proposed a $555 million reform plan and a half-cent sales tax increase to fund it and pump more money to poorer school districts. The proposal would boost the sales tax from 6 cents to 6{ cents on the dollar, but Clements said he would veto the bill, saying money is available elsewhere for a less expensive reform plan. Clements' veto vow prompted about 300 teachers to picket the governor's mansion Monday. He was out of town. ``We want to send a message to the people of the state of Texas, as well as the governor, that this is a serious issue that has reached a critical stage,'' said Shelley Potter, president of the San Antonio Federation of Teachers. Texas is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems deemed unfair to poor districts. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. Texas has 1,100 school districts. More than $400 million in April state aid payments went to schools last Wednesday. Bullock said the money he would withhold unless the judge intercedes included nearly $2.7 million in payroll checks due today for more than 1,000 employees of the Texas Education Agency. But Clements said Monday the matter likely would have no immediate impact. ``We don't really have a problem,'' he said. ``We have ample funds and the funds are in hand to pay the teachers until, I believe, it's the last two days of the school year.'' Some school districts would not be able to meet financial obligations if state funding stops, Ms. Potter said. ``That's a very serious situation. It hurts the employees. It hurts the kids,'' she said. ``They've been playing around with the issue and using the kids as political pawns, and we're tired of it.'' The predominantly Democratic Legislature and Republican governor have had seven months to deal with the court-ordered reform. The Supreme Court on Oct. 2, 1989, ruled the school finance system unconstitutional, but Clements didn't call the Legislature into session to consider the matter until Feb. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Mathematician With Brain Tumor Wants Head Frozen
DOC.TEXT: A mathematician who filed a lawsuit so he can freeze his own head before he dies from a brain tumor said Tuesday the odds of achieving immortality aren't as bad as one might think. ``We think that everyone should be immortal. The purpose of medicine should be to bring about that immortality,'' Thomas Donaldson said in a telephone interview from his home in Sunnyvale, a Silicon Valley town south of San Francisco. Donaldson, 46, said he wants his head quick-frozen while he is still alive, using a process known as cryonic suspension. He's betting that future scientists will discover a way to cure the tumor and attach his head to a healthy body. In a lawsuit filed Monday in Santa Barbara County Superior Court, Donaldson seeks to bar state and local officials from preventing his cryonic suspension before he is declared legally dead. Donaldson said the choice to file the suit in Santa Barbara, about 250 miles south of his home, was arbitrary. ``It's a nice area,'' he said. ``It's (really) a case against the state of California.'' Cryonic suspension is a procedure in which all or part of the body is supposedly preserved in a deep freeze. Advocates of cryonics say waiting for legal brain death hurts patients' chances of successful reawakening. To date, the procedure only has been performed after a patient has died of natural causes. Donaldson said he wants to secure the right to have the procedure before the tumor significantly damages his brain. ``I am dying and want to be cryonically suspended so that I might later be revived and continue to live,'' said Donaldson, a member of the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, based in Riverside. In California, legal death is defined as when a person would not show signs of brain activity as recorded by an electroencephalograph. Alcor gained national attention in 1987 when the head of an elderly woman was frozen after she died at the lab. Authorities questioned whether her head was removed before she died. Donaldson says radiation treatment has not affected his tumor, which was discovered in 1988. Court papers say that although the tumor is stable, he has only a 40 percent chance of living to August 1993. So he's filing suit now. ``The court system cannot be depended upon to decide these things very fast,'' he said. Donaldson, a senior mathematician at MIMD Systems in Belmont, hasn't decided where, if he succeeds, to have his cryonic suspension done. But he says the Alcor lab in Riverside, about 55 miles east of Los Angeles, would be a logical place for suspension and storage. In the procedure, he would be anesthetized while his body temperature is reduced. Alcor surgeons then would replace his blood with glycol and other chemicals to minimize tissue damage caused by freezing. Donaldson's head would be surgically removed at the end of the operation, then sealed in a vacuum container and maintained at minus 320 degrees Fahrenheit. The operation would cost him $35,000. A full-body suspension costs about $100,000. Donaldson said he's been planning on cryonic suspension since before he joined Alcor in 1975. His wife, Kathryn Woof, is all for it. ``She's a cryonicist, too,'' he said. ``This is not a ritual. We're trying to improve the (chances of) revival of the person we're suspending,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: LA Times Becomes Largest Weekday Newspaper in the United States
