DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles Times surpassed the New York Daily News as the metropolitan newspaper with the nation's largest weekday circulation, according to preliminary figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The Times weekday circulation for the six months ending March 31 rose by 90,237 to 1,210,077, according to ABC figures released Monday. The New York Daily News decreased in weekday circulation over the period by 50,047, to 1,180,139. Two national circulation newspapers, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today, have larger weekday circulation figures than the Times, registering 1,935,866 and 1,387,233, respectively. The Times' Sunday circulation rose by 81,230, to 1,504,540, making it second-largest in the nation behind The New York Times, which has a Sunday circulation of 1,706,013. The weekend edition of USA Today, published Fridays, sold 1,753,537 copies a week. About half the Times' circulation growth stemmed from the demise of the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Times publisher David Laventhol said. The Herald Examiner had a circulation of roughly 230,000 when it closed in November. Perhaps up to 100,000 Herald Examiner subscribers already bought a second newspaper, the ABC figures indicated. Of the remainder, an estimated 50,000 to 70,000 may have stopped reading a daily newspaper altogether, newspaper executives estimate. Of the rest, about two-thirds switched to the Los Angeles Times, Laventhol estimated. Another 20,000 may have taken other newspapers, particularly the Los Angeles Daily News. Daily News circulation rose by 19,044 on weekdays to 202,384, and by 12,682 to 212,205 on Sundays. The Times quoted circulation experts as saying the Daily News may have picked up about 10,000 former Herald Examiner readers. In Orange County, where the Times is locked in a readership battle with the Orange County Register, the Times' weekday circulation increased by 13,342 to 179,981. Total Register weekday circulation rose 4,054 to 349,019. The Long Beach Press-Telegram's weekday circulation rose 4,614 to 134,071. More than half the increase came from the Herald Examiner, said Dan Sidbury, vice president of circulation at the Press-Telegram. Other newspapers reporting circulation increases included the Copley Newspapers, which publishes the Daily Breeze in Torrance and The Outlook in Santa Monica. The Copley Newspapers' circulation rose 3,055 to 129,358.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Shot On Canadian Side of Reservation Dies in U.S. Hospital
LaserPhoto XML2
DOC.TEXT: Growing tensions between pro- and anti-gambling factions on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation erupted in sporadic gunfire overnight, and an Indian was fatally wounded on the Canadian side, officials said. Matthew Pyke, 22, was shot in the back about 6:30 a.m. in Snye, Quebec, and as he walked near a wooded area near the U.S.-Canadian border, said Joe Lazore, a companion who went with Pyke to Alice Hyde Hospital in Malone, N.Y. Pyke, who died about 11 a.m., was shot by gunfire from woods on the U.S. side of the border, near the Salmon River, Lazore said. New York State Police Capt. Robert Currier said the incident occurred on Canadian soil and his force will not participate in the formal investigation. Quebec Provincial Police investigators could not be reached by telephone. The reservation that straddles the border has been plagued in recent weeks by feuding between anti- and pro-gambling factions. The dispute has been heightened by questions of whether the reservation should be run by traditional or elected leaders and whether state and federal laws can be enforced on Mohawk land. On Monday, New York Gov. Mario Cuomo attempted to ease tensions by offering to renew negotiations over legalizing gambling on the reservation, provided that the existing casinos were closed down and the violence stopped. That proposal angered anti-gambling forces and pleased the pro-gambling side. Indians reported periodic gunfire late Monday and early Tuesday on the reservation.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 4 p.m. EDT; Time Set by Source
DOC.HEAD: Campaign Launched to Tell Old People Their Rights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT day to Tuesday sted Monday
DOC.TEXT: Celebrities joined forces Tuesday with the American Association of Retired Persons and the American Bar Association to launch a campaign urging the elderly to stand up for their rights. ``If you're told Medicare won't pay a bill, you don't have to take `No' for an answer,'' author Alex Haley declares in one of five 30-second TV public service announcements shown to reporters. The radio and television spots, each focusing on a legal right that many older Americans don't know they have, are the centerpiece of the ``Do Yourself Justice ... Know Your Rights'' program. In other segments, actors Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach discuss nursing home rights and Cliff Robertson tells of legal options to state guardianship in the event of incapacity. Actress Celeste Holm does double-duty as spokeswoman on spots describing legal protection against age discrimination in credit and employment. ``Older Americans who do not know their rights are often targets of abuse,'' Judith N. Brown, a member of the AARP's national board, said in a statement. ``This campaign encourages older people to stand up for themselves.'' Radio stations are being offered 30-second and 60-second public service announcements on the same five topics, plus three others: telephone service, funerals and health insurance. Spanish versions are available for both television and radio, all recorded by actress Rita Moreno. ``Generally speaking, older people are more vulnerable and less able to speak up for their rights,'' said John H. Pickering, chairman of the ABA's Commission on Legal Problems of the Elderly. ``We try to alert lawyers to the need to help the elderly. It's a growing field in the law,'' Pickering said in an interview. The AARP, an advocacy and research group for people 50 and older, is hoping the announcements will get extensive airplay for a year or more, said spokesman Ted Bobrow. The brief spots allow little time for detail, but each ends with the suggestion that anyone needing more information write for more information to: Do Yourself Justice, Washington, D.C. 20049.

DOC.HEAD: Official's Mood Indigo Turns Crimson
DOC.TEXT: Manhattan's borough president is in no sentimental mood about a proposed statue in which jazz great Duke Ellington and his piano are held aloft by naked women. Borough President Ruth Messinger asked Mayor David Dinkins on Monday to cancel city funds for the monument at the northeast corner of Central Park. ``We think we can find a better use for the $450,000,'' said Messinger's spokesman Andrew Breslau, who also called the statue ``aesthetically suspect.'' Dinkins said Tuesday the city actually planned to spend only $100,000 for installation. The rest is for improvements to a traffic island where the statue would be displayed. ``The current sculpture is the third version by Robert Graham. I don't know if this is the final one,'' he said. Statue supporters sniffed at their opponents, saying these are sophisticated ladies, not tramps. ``We chose the artist and we are very pleased with the statue,'' pianist Bobby Short said. ``I believe in it.'' Short helped to raise nearly $1 million in private funds for the monument. Graham's proposal is for a bronze staue nearly three stories high. Graham, whose works are at such places as the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum, attracted some controversy at the Olympic games in Los Angeles in 1984 with his two massive, headless male and female nude figures. The Duke Ellington Society issued a statement: ``Beautiful women were always an important component in the life and work of Duke Ellington, so naturally, the sculptor made them an integral component of his work.''

DOC.HEAD: First Soviet-U.S. Program for Jewish Studies Announced
DOC.TEXT: Jewish studies will soon be taught at a Soviet university for the first time in a half century, it was announced Tuesday. The program _ the result of an agreement to be signed on Wednesday _ is expected to start in the fall of 1991. Students will attend the Moscow State Institute of History and Archives for three years, and will spend a fourth year in New York at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research. Professors from the American institutions also will teach in Moscow. This is believed to be the first time a Soviet state university and American institutions have created a joint degree-granting program, according to Tammy Kornfeld, a spokeswoman for the seminary. Creators of the program hope that graduates will help catalog the vast amount of Jewish manuscripts that are now surfacing in the Soviet Union. The Moscow State Institute has launched an effort to locate those materials and make them available to scholars. Other graduates of the program are expected to become teachers and scholars of Judaica, as well as intellectual leaders of the Soviet Jewish community, according to David Fishman, who conceived of the program. The Moscow State Institute ``represents the best of the Soviet intelligentsia,'' said Fishman, an assistant professor of Jewish history at the seminary and research associate at YIVO. ``It is a pleasure to be in partnership with a faculty that has been at the forefront of the movement for democracy and is outspoken in its condemnation of anti-Semitism,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says ``Peace Dividend'' Should Go to Space Research
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle called Tuesday for savings from reduced defense spending to be channeled into space-related research. ``Investing in space is especially important in light of the decline in our military spending,'' he told the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics in a luncheon speech. The vice president recalled that much past investment in military research and development has had civilian benefits. ``Thanks to the promising trend toward a more peaceful and less threatening world, it does appear our defense spending will decline,'' said Quayle, who is the head of the National Space Council. ``To ensure that we continue to benefit from research and development in advanced technologies, we therefore need to continue and expand our investment in space-related research,'' he said. Quayle praised the government-private industry partnership that made possible the recent successful launch of the Pegasus. The Pegasus is a payload-carrying rocket launched from under the wing of an airplane. ``Soon, small commercial satellites will open a trillion dollar industry supplying additional new informatin services from space _ services such as cellular telephones, worldwide TV and computer services and much more,'' he said. ``Think what this could mean to a developing nation. It could skip the entire cost of stringing wires and other infrastructure expenses, and still develop state of the art communications services.'' The next century, said Quayle, will provide new medicines and medical understandings from research and manufacturing in space. ``Material from the moon could enable us to supply many of the Earth's energy needs safely and cleanly from space,'' he said. The reference apparently was to helium-3, in abundant supply on the moon, which, in gaseous form could be used to power fusion reactors on Earth.

DOC.BYLINE: Administration, Airlines Oppose Aging Airliner Bill ^By DAVID BRISCOE
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration and airline industry joined forces Tuesday to oppose legislation that would increase the federal role in inspecting aging airliners. Anthony Broderick, FAA associate administrator, told a House hearing that the bill would increase government liability and could cost between $1 million and $2 million per aircraft. It would take five years to hire and train the needed inspectors, he said. FAA inspectors oversee regular checks and maintenance conducted by the airlines but don't routinely dismantle and inspect airliners themselves. The hearing of the House Public Works aviation subcommittee came two years and two days after an 18-foot section of the roof ripped off an aging Aloha Airlines Boeing 737 in flight over Hawaii, sweeping a flight attendant to her death. That incident prompted new concern about aging airliners and led to a government-industry task force that planned FAA response to the problem. The average U.S. airliner is nearly 13 years old, and more than one-fourth of the planes are more than 20 years old. That's expected to increase as growing demand keeps aircraft from being retired. The bill proposed by Democratic and Republican leaders of the aviation subcommittee would require the FAA to thoroughly inspect each airliner during the last year of its economic design life, which could vary with each aircraft according to how it is used. Unless approved in an FAA inspection, planes would be grounded after they reach the pre-determined design life. The bill would fundamentally change the way FAA works to ensure aviation safety, replacing airline inspections with FAA inspections, Broderick told the panel. ``This proposed departure from traditional practices troubles us quite a bit,'' he said. He said the FAA workload in the first year would be something ``almost impossible to contemplate conducting, as we would be required to inspect over 1,000 aircraft _ a task that is simply unrealistic.'' Broderick said the FAA is already having a difficult time coping with its inspection duties because of rapid growth of the industry. Since the Aloha accident, the FAA has changed its approach to airline aging from one of requiring frequent inspections to mandating changes of critical parts of aircraft when they reach a set number of cycles, or takeoffs and landings. ``I feel strongly that the agency's aging aircraft program represents the best thinking and cooperative efforts of government and industry,'' Broderick said. Robert E. Doll, United Airlines vice president who heads the government-industry task force, said adding inspection duties for the FAA could impinge other safety efforts of both the airlines and the government. He said the possibility of increased liability for the government could bring extensive disassembly and exhaustive inspections of planes that would ``lead to repair costs so great as to provoke the premature retirement of airworthy airplanes.'' That, Doll said, could lead to a shortage of aircraft as the demand for air travel grows. He said it would also be very difficult to determine the design life of each aircraft because some parts are sensitive to flight hours, others to flight cycles and still others to calendar age. Doll proposed, however, that the FAA increase its attention to new air carriers to ensure that they have adequate inspection and maintenance programs.

A sampling of the official May Day slogans, approved by the Communist Party, and the unofficial slogans, shouted by demonstrators or appearing on their signs Tuesday:

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares War on `Couch Potatoes'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared ``war on couch potatoes'' Tuesday as he kicked off National Physical Fitness and Sports Month by golfing, pedaling, shooting baskets and tossing horseshoes on the White House grounds. It was all part of a celebrity-studded ``Great American Workout,'' as Bush called the event. The White House lawn was transformed into a virtual outdoor gymnasium as Bush took a turn at demonstrating sports activities with well-known athletes and his own national fitness chairman, muscleman Arnold Schwarzenegger. ``Read my hips, no more flab,'' Schwarzenegger said in a take-off on the president's ``Read my lips, no new taxes,'' pledge. He and Bush made the rounds of a series of sports stations on the South Lawn as sports stars and celebrities pumped iron, bounced in aerobic routines and demonstrated martial arts and cross-country skiing techniques. Among the sports boosters on hand were Olympic track stars Carl Lewis and Jackie Joyner Kersee; fitness veteran Jack LaLanne, in a skin-hugging purple jumpsuit, and `Saturday Night Live'' comedian Kevin Nealon, in tight sweatsuit over fake muscles from his ``pump you up'' comedy routine. ``Today we're declaring war on couch potatoes,'' Bush told the group. The president said he hoped his use of the potato analogy didn't get him in trouble with growers. He raised a furor in the broccoli industry recently when he said he hated the vegetable. Bush urged Americans to eat a better diet than his own. ``Let's pledge to eat a balanced and nutritional diet, avoid excessive alcohol use and of course, say no to drugs,'' Bush said. ``All you broccoli lovers, eat your heart out out there.'' He said that,``All of us have a stake in making exercise a part of America's fitness, and fitness a part of America every day. ``No matter what your age, sex or physical condition, the Great American Workout can enhance the quality and longevity of each American's life.'' The president, clad in sport jacket and open-necked shirt for the early-morning event, did not use the occasion for a full workout, instead stopping for token demonstrations. When he failed to make a basket, the hoop was lowered so he could dunk the basketball without jumping. The president tossed a wobbly football pass to Indianapolis Colts star Eric Dickerson, and tried his hand at a couple of chip shots, demonstrating his admitted weakness in golf. Turning to one of his better sports, he threw two horseshoes that landed close to the stake, then chided Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan for a weak throw the president dubbed a ``power outage.'' Bush and Schwarzenegger climbed aboard Life Cycles for a few minutes. He also hit some tennis balls with one of his favorite partners, professional Pam Shriver, and joined briefly in a volleyball game. Bush teased Schwarzenegger, whom he has appointed chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. ``He's stronger than I thought he was. He bench pressed the federal budget,'' the president said of the body builder turned actor. Also on hand were Special Olympics participants, local physical fitness and martial arts students and teams, and military fitness demonstrators. Among the celebrity participants were Olympic athletes Bruce Jenner and Rafer Johnson, golfer Sam Snead, ice skaters Scott Hamilton and Dorothy Hamill, Olympic gold medal gymnast Mary Lou Retton, Charles Mann of the Washington Redskins, country singer Randy Travis, and tennis stars Stan Smith and Arthur Ashe. Schwarzenegger warmed up the group with stretching exercises, mercilessly cheering on the laggards. ``OK, General Powell, much further,'' he needled the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Shakes South-Central Alaska
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook south-central Alaska on Tuesday. There were no immediate reports of any damage or injuries, authorities said. The quake measured 6.4 on the Richter scale and struck at 8:15 a.m., the Alaska Tsunami Center said. It was centered about 10 miles south of King Salmon, said Wayne Jorgenson, a spokesman for the center. King Salmon is a village of 530 people about 280 southwest of Anchorage. ``Everbody's felt it,'' Jorgenson said. ``We received calls from Homer, Kenai, Palmer and Anchorage.'' He said there was no danger of a tsunami _ tidal waves that can be generated by quakes. Lori Hyde, a spokeswoman for The Alaska State Troopers in Naknek, said she didn't feel the quake even though the epicenter was 25 miles away. ``There have been no damage reports,'' she said. ``People have been calling to say they were shook up, that their chandeliers were swaying. But there's nothing 10 miles south of King Salmon but tundra.'' The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Protesters Besiege Gorbachev at May Day Parade
LaserPhotos MOSB2,3,4,MOS19,25
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of protesters in Red Square unleashed their fury at Mikhail S. Gorbachev Tuesday, turning the traditional May Day parade into an outpouring of complaints about the economy and the blockade of Lithuania. The Soviet president has allowed free debate in the press and politics and endured public criticism. But never before has he had to personally face such an outburst of discontent over his policies, from both right and left. The criticism included jeers to the faces of Soviet leaders. Gorbachev, 59, tapped his fingers on the parapet of the red granite reviewing stand during the protest, showing his impatience, but otherwise was impassive. He and the other officials left after enduring the unofficial demonstrators for about 20 minutes, but it was unclear if they were leaving in response to the protests. Neither Gorbachev nor any of the other Communist or government leaders on the reviewing stand spoke to the crowd. Dozens of the demonstrators carried the yellow, red and green national flags of the breakaway Lithuanian republic and shouted ``Shame!'' and ``Freedom For Lithuania!'' Some waved their fists at the leaders, numbering about two dozen, and shouted ``Resign!'' over the holiday music blaring from loudspeakers. One caustic sign likened the Soviet leadership to Nicolae Ceausescu, the Romanian dictator executed in December after a popular uprising. ``Kremlin Ceausescus: From Armchairs to Prison Beds,'' it read. The leaders clearly expected some criticism. They authorized the unofficial demonstration, and took control of the traditional parade that preceded it from local Communist Party and government officials. But they likely did not expect the tone to be quite so angry or the scale quite so large. Gorbachev's popularity has waned during his five years in office because his reforms have failed to resolve chronic economic problems. Many people believe supplies of food, housing and consumer goods actually are worse under Gorbachev. He also is under fire for the blockade of oil, raw materials and other goods he imposed on Lithuania to force the Baltic republic to back off its March 11 declaration of independence. For decades, the Red Square rally on May Day has been an orchestrated show of support for official policies. Entry onto Red Square was rigidly controlled. This year, there was little of the usual polite praise. Just about anyone could join the march on the gray cobblestone stretching from the Historical Museum to the multi-colored St. Basil's Cathedral. ``We are all so very tired of these formal galas, when long before the holiday the lists of demonstration participants were put out,'' said the official news agency Tass. Soviet leaders went on record this year as preferring a parade like those before the 1917 revolution, when May Day was marked with smaller, spontaneous affairs aimed at voicing workers' grievances about the czarist regime. What they got instead were posters that declared, ``Down with the Empire of Red Fascism,'' and ``Today a Blockade of Lithuania, Tomorrow a Blockade of Moscow.'' The black flags of an anarchist group stood out in the sea of colors. The wave of protesters continued to file through Red Square, which holds about 50,000 marchers, for more than an hour after the leaders left. Police gradually, and apparently gently, moved them along. A few thousand trekked almost a mile to a square across from Gorky Park to renew their demonstration. The nightly newscast ``Vremya'' noted briefly the raucous nature of the unofficial protest and showed some of the marchers, including a woman who appeared to be shaking her fist at the Soviet leaders. ``The last minutes of the celebration were somewhat marred by the actions of certain people, actions which were dissonant with the general mood,'' the newscast said. There were also protests in Leningrad, the Soviet Union's second-largest city and birthplace of the revolution. Marchers on Palace Square waved banners that read, ``Communism is a Universal Shame'' and ``Freedom for Lithuania,'' according to Leningrad journalist Maxim Korzhov. They also demanded Gorbachev's resignation. Tass said marchers in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev expressed concern about the treatment of victims of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident. It said demonstrators in Alma Ata, the capital of Kazakhstan, urged officials to close the Semipalatinsk nuclear test site. A subway worker attending the Red Square parade as an official guest said he was stunned. ``A revolution is a revolution. What else can I say?'' said the worker, who identified himself only as Yuri. Even the official segment of the parade, which lasted 75 minutes, featured banners and speeches critical of the leadership's policy, especially its plans to introduce a market economy. ``Enough Experiments, Let's Work!'' and ``Democracy is not Demagoguery,'' two banners read. The conservative tone of some of the banners and speeches in the official segment indicated that Gorbachev faces criticism not only from reformers but from workers, who fear the transition to a market economy will worsen their lives. Labor leaders demanded attention to their worries that economic reforms will lead to price increases and unemployment. ``The basic reason for the crisis situation is that the leadership of the party and the government have been chronically late in putting into effect cardinal political and economic measures,'' said Yevgeny Kablov, a doctor of technology. He appealed for strengthening state-run businesses facing competition from cooperatives, the privately owned businesses that some accuse of black-marketeering and price-gouging. Among those on the reviewing stand was newly elected Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, a reform-minded economist who is critical of Gorbachev. Popov's supporters in the Moscow City Council are pushing to turn much of the capital's retail trade into private hands.

DOC.HEAD: Public Smoking Banned in Ireland
DOC.TEXT: The haze cleared from Ireland's buses and movie theaters Tuesday as the government cracked down on smoking. Authorities outlawed smoking in cinemas and buses and ordered segregated smoking areas to be set up in government buildings, trains, schools, libraries, hospitals, airports, supermarkets, restaurants and art galleries. Health inspectors will make spot checks throughout the country, with the power to fine offenders up to $160. Owners or managers failing to enforce the ban can be fined up to $800. Restaurateurs were angered that the ban does not apply to pubs or bars. ``There seem to be two laws,'' said Henry O'Neill, head of the Restaurant Owners Association. ``Publicans (pubkeepers) have gone into food in a major way yet they are not restricted. It is unfair.'' Ireland already bars tobacco advertising on radio and TV, and the Health Department said it hopes ``the new laws will be the final pieces in the jigsaw of the government's anti-smoking policy.'' Patrick MacNutt, a Galway University economics lecturer, said he does not smoke but sees the ban as government interference. ``An individual right has been relegated to an imposed rule,'' MacNutt said. Richard Miller, director of the Dublin-based Edmund Burke Institute which campaigns for individual rights, doubted the ban would be enforced. He said it was introduced ``to satisfy the demand for regulations and to enable Ireland to look modern, progressive and trendy.'' Irish smokers have declined to 27 percent of the population from 45 percent in 1975. A pack of 20 cigarettes costs $3.20, of which the government takes 67 percent in taxes.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Will Accept More Vietnamese for Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: Up to 700 Vietnamese children and young people living in Southeast Asian refugee camps will be granted political asylum in this country, Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Gene McNary announced Tuesday. The young people, described by immigration authorities as unaccompanied by parents or adult relatives, were all under age 18 when they arrived at refugee camps. Some are now in their early 20s. The INS will begin interviewing the applicants this month to screen them for political asylum, McNary said. The first refugees from the group are expected to arrive in the United States in July and the rest by year's end, McNary said in a statement. Immigration authorities said the young people were unable to qualify as political refugees when previously interviewed because they were too young or inarticulate at the time to provide evidence of political persecution. Many of these young people and children have families still living in Vietnam, including fathers who fought in the South Vietnamese army during the Vietnam War, which ended 15 years ago. ``Their lives are in suspension and it seemed like an appropriate time to go back and re-interview those people in the most generous manner,'' said Ralph Thomas, deputy assistant INS commissioner for refugee asylum and parole. ``We anticipate that the large bulk of them will be admitted as refugees,'' Thomas said. Most of the children and young people are living in refugee camps in Thailand; others are in the Philippines, Indonesia and Hong Kong. Since the war ended, more than 1 million Vietnamese refugees have been admitted to the United States. Some of the 700 young people have relatives living in this country, authorities said. McNary said he hopes the initiative will set an example for other nations to implement the Comprehensive Plan of Action, an international agreement for resettling Indochinese refugees.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Stops Small Cargo Ship, Finds 1,320 Pounds of Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: The Colombian navy found 1,320 pounds of cocaine stashed aboard a small freighter off the Caribbean coast, a newspaper reported Tuesday. The cocaine was found aboard the freighter Sandra, the newspaper El Tiempo quoted Adm. Angel Mejia as saying. The ship reportedly was stopped near the Rosario Islands about 50 miles north of Cartagena. It was not immediately possible to verify the story because Tuesday was a holiday in Colombia, May Day. The Defense Ministry in Bogota and the navy's public affairs offices at its main base in Cartagena were closed. El Tiempo did not say when the cocaine was found.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted HUD Swindler Sentenced to Six Years, Fined $2 Million
DOC.TEXT: A man who stole $2 million in federal housing funds and used the money to buy sports cars, furs and jewelry, was sentenced Tuesday to six years in prison and ordered to pay $4 million in fines and restitution. Cy Walker, a 50-year-old former Montgomery real estate broker, was ordered to report to prison June 1 for embezzling $2 million from an unwitting U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development during a 21-month period in 1986-87. U.S. Attorney Jim Wilson said Walker was not connected to high-level HUD officials in any kind of conspiracy. But, he said, ``the fact that Walker could have pulled this off is indicative of the weaknesses of the HUD program'' during the Reagan administration. ``It was a part of the HUD scandal, but it was done by an isolated operator,'' said Wilson. U.S. District Judge Joel Dubina sentenced Walker to five years in prison for one count of embezzlement of HUD funds. The judge sentenced Walker to an additional year, to run consecutively, on a count of failing to pay income tax on the stolen HUD money. Walker was fined $2 million on the first count and $25,000 on the second. The judge also ordered restitution to the government of $2,073,499 in HUD money, which Walker admitted using to bankroll lavish purchases, such as $180,000 worth of cars, including a $50,000 Mercedes-Benz, and an $18,000 Stingray speedboat. His attorney, David Byrne, said Walker isn't able to pay the $4 million: ``He doesn't have any present resources to make restitution.'' He said Walker had no comment about the six-year sentence, at an as yet undesignated prison. But he said Walker ``expressed his sorrow for what he had done and most of all for the disappointment he caused his parents and loved ones.'' Walker, a real estate broker who had a HUD contract to handle closings of agency property in the Montgomery region, admitted embezzling the money between February 1986 and October 1987. According to a HUD audit, he put agency property closing money in a personal bank account, then falsified a bank's wire transfer forms to make regional HUD officials think it had been sent for proper deposit in a HUD account. When HUD inspectors discovered the scheme, Walker depleted the account and closed down his office. Later, as investigators pursued him, he worked out a deal with prosecutors, agreeing to serve as an informant in a drug sting operation. His testimony led to the conviction of east Alabama racehorse trainer Freddie Hyatt. Before the Hyatt trial, prosecutors agreed to let Walker plead guilty to two counts in the HUD embezzlement case. The prosecutor said he felt the judge imposed a ``very fair and good sentence'' on Walker, particularly in requiring full restitution of the embezzled money and more than $2 million in fines. ``We're going to pursue these amounts,'' said Wilson. ``Whatever we can find and legally recover.''

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Bill to Raise Pay for Medical Personnel
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday approved a bill to raise the pay of doctors, dentists and nurses who work for the Veterans Affairs Department. The bill, approved by voice vote and sent to the Senate, is in response to problems the department has had in recruiting medical personnel. The legislation would increase typical physicians' pay from just under $100,000 to a maximum around $130,000, depending on experience and specialities. Dentists earning about $65,000 would see their pay increase to a range of $70,000 to $100,000, with most toward the lower end. Salaries for health executives could go up by $45,000. The pay structure governing the more than 10,000 nurses and 15,000 nursing assistants in the veterans' care system also would be revamped, including a provision allowing local area administrators to increase pay to attract adequate staff. The actual salaries would vary widely depending on experience, training and region. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the bill would add nearly $60 million in costs to the government in 1991, rising to $108 million in 1995. Instead of including some method for paying for the increases, the legislation includes a provision exempting the VA health care system from the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Prince previewed his forthcoming European tour by performing a benefit concert for the family of his former bodyguard, who died April 2 of heart failure. The 650-ticket sellout show Monday at the suburban nightclub Rupert's attracted fans who paid $100 a ticket and waited more than an hour in freezing temperatures to get inside. Proceeds will benefit the family of Charles ``Big Chick'' Huntsberry, who gained fame in the mid-'80s as Prince's bodyguard before turning to Christian evangelism. Jill Willis, a publicist for the rock star, said Prince decided to combine the benefit with a run-through of his forthcoming ``Nude'' tour of Europe. The name of the tour refers to its ``stripped-down rock 'n' roll,'' she said. Prince's tour is scheduled to open in Rotterdam June 2 and will continue through early August, including 15 sold-out dates at Wembley Arena in London.

Lady Bird Johnson says she is as dedicated as ever to the National Wildflower Research Center but plans to scale back some of her other activities. The former first lady has previously said she would do less work with the Texas Highway Department Beautification Awards, a project she has sponsored for 20 years. At a tree-planting ceremony Monday, Mrs. Johnson, 77, said she also intends to cut back on activities such as public speaking. ``I am scaling down, but not on the Wildflower Research Center,'' she said. ``But I will try to be a good citizen in the field of environment, with emphasis on plant, wildflower and tree beautification.''

Prince Aya, second son of Emperor Akihito, will marry graduate student Kiko Kawashima on June 29, the Imperial Household Agency said Tuesday. An agency official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a messenger from the emperor will call on Miss Kawashima, 23, and her parents at their home on May 11 to formally notify them of the wedding date. The government plans to spend about $1 million on the wedding of Miss Kawashima and the 24-year-old Aya, second in line to the throne after his elder brother, Crown Prince Naruhito. The crown prince, 30, is unmarried. Prince Aya, who graduated from Gakushuin University in 1988, is studying zoology at Oxford's St. John's college in Britain. He is expected to complete his studies there and return to Tokyo on June 20. Aya and Miss Kawashima met five years ago on the campus of Gakushuin University. Miss Kawashima, the daughter of a Gakushuin professor, is taking graduate courses in psychology at the Tokyo university. The couple announced their engagement in September.

Country music star Hank Williams Jr. has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to strike down ``feel-good jurisprudence'' that gave his half-sister a claim to the estate of their famous father. Williams' lawyers contended in the filing last month that the state Supreme Court gave a share of the late country music Hank Williams Sr.'s estate to his illegitimate daughter, Jett Williams, even though the estate had been closed since 1975. Williams also asked the court to hear an appeal of a New York appeals court that, relying on the Alabama case, gave Ms. Williams a share of continuing music royalties stemming from songs written by her father. Hank Williams Sr. died five days before his daughter was born in 1953 to Bobbie Jett. The Alabama court noted that her paternity was not suggested to her until 1974, when she was a 21-year-old University of Alabama student. For the next few years, her efforts to get documents from the state were thwarted because the case had been sealed, along with evidence that lawyers had been setting aside part of Hank Williams Sr.'s estate for her. She launched her music career under the name Jett Williams, although she is identified in court documents as Catherine Yvonne Stone.

Billionaire Warren Buffett took to the stage of an ornate, renovated theater and dispensed his financial philosophy to an audience of more than 1,200 shareholders gathered for their annual meeting. Buffett, who has overseen the growth of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. from $22 million in 1964 to its current $4.9 billion worth, concluded the business of re-electing officers Monday with nary a word of dissent or discussion. ``With the events of Eastern Europe, this may be the last bastion of undiluted authoritarianism left,'' said Buffett, 59, chairman of the Omaha-based investment company. The company, valued at $4.9 billion, has holdings that include Coca-Cola Inc., Gillette Co., Salomon Inc., Capital Cities-ABC Inc., insurance companies, a candy maker, an encyclopedia company and furniture and jewelry stores.

The hunk flunked ... again. John F. Kennedy Jr., who's made magazine covers touting him as sexy and an heir to the Kennedy dynasty, took the state bar examination for a second time. Again, he failed. ``I'm clearly not a major legal genius,'' he told reporters Monday. So Tuesday's city tabloids had headlines screaming about him going belly up on the bar exam. Undaunted, Kennedy said he would take the test again and again ``until I'm 95'' _ or until he passes. The 29-year-old son of the late President Kennedy has only one more chance to pass the grueling 12{-hour, two-day test if he wants to keep his job as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan. Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, said Kennedy, a prosecutor since August, will be asked to resign from his $30,000-a-year post if he fails again. ``All assistants get three chances,'' Roche said. ``It's a longstanding office policy. He will take it again in July.'' Kennedy fell 11 points short of the passing score of 660 out of 1,000 points, said a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Kennedy, a graduate of the New York University Law School, first took the bar exam last July with 64 other new members of Morgenthau's staff, Roche said. Of the 65, she said, Kennedy was one of seven who flunked. He took the test again in February along with those who failed. Of the seven, at least two passed on the second go-round.

Miss USA Carole Gist was welcomed back to Cass Technical High School, her alma mater, with a chorus of students' screams, whoops and a standing ovation. The reigning Miss USA, who graduated from Cass Tech in 1987, told the 1,600 students that hard work, academic excellence and determination are the keys to success. ``You have a beautiful road ahead of you; all you have to do is go out there and grab it,'' she said at Monday's appearance. Gist, who was first runner-up to Miss Norway in the Miss Universe pageant last month, appeared overwhelmed to be back at school, where her interests included singing, running track, dancing and modeling.

Simon Townshend thinks the day is coming when rock 'n' roll fans will have a Townshend other than his big brother Pete to admire. ``I did my work in the same way that Pete did,'' the 29-year-old guitarist said as he prepared for a club date in Nashville. ``A lot of people think that was a gift that Pete passed onto me,'' he said, noting it takes more sweat than favors to get a musical career off the ground. ``I intend to prove myself, however long it takes.'' His big brother is a tough act to follow. Pete is a guitarist for The Who and as composer of such rock classics as ``Tommy.'' Simon's mainstream rock band has an album partly recorded in Nashville nearing release. Simon was 14 when he began his music career by recording ``When I'm a Man'' for Warner Bros. in England. ``A friend of my Dad's said, `Why don't we put Simon in the studio and make a record?''' he recalled. ``I suppose in a way it was trying to cash in on the family name and make a quick buck.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in years, there's more than one person running for the lowly office of tree warden, but it's not exactly what you'd call a heated contest. A 66-year-old retiree and a 34-year-old construction worker say they think they've got the timber for the job. But neither seems to be overly concerned about winning the May 15 election for the $700-a-year job. ``I ain't running no campaign at all. The other fellow, he's not campaigning, either,'' said Edward Yagodzinski, a retired groundskeeper and truck driver. His opponent, Brent Higgins, took an equally dispassionate approach: ``A few people said `why don't you put your name in for it,' so I said `all right.''' Higgins said he has some experience cutting down trees in his 14 years as a construction worker, but he wasn't willing to say whether he'd make a better tree warden than Yagodzinski. ``Whoever wins, wins,'' he said. Trees are an important part of the rural charm of this town of 3,500 just outside Northampton in the western part of the state. The warden is responsible for maintaining trees along the streets and organizing public hearings before any cutting takes place. Like Higgins, Yagodzinski seemed ready to face the prospect of defeat. ``If I get in, all well and good. If I don't I'm not going to worry about it. I'll do more fishing up in Vermont,'' he said.

Didja hear the one about the cop who tried a little stand-up comedy routine before giving a motorist a speeding ticket? A Montana teen-ager wants you to. Michelle Kessinger of Columbia Falls offered a bill in a mock student legislature that would require police officers issuing speeding tickets to tell a little joke to break the tension. Or else. The bill mandates law officers ``start off with a joke to lighten the mood'' when issuing speeding tickets. That would alleviate tension and reduce the chance that a nervous motorist carrying a firearm will do something dangerous, she said. The bill would appropriate $5,000 ``to educate all law officers on comical anecdotes and humorous jokes that are in good taste, non-offending and somewhat pertinent to the situation.'' The humor could be a little forced, however. Officers who fail to tell jokes could be fined $10 and up per ticket.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say More Money May be Needed for Embassies
DOC.TEXT: The State Department's $1 billion program to upgrade embassies around the world could run into trouble with shrinking budgets and new demands in Eastern Europe and Central America, officials said Tuesday. ``Our biggest challenge in the 1990s may be working within the shrinking budget,'' Arthur Fort, assistant secretary of State for administration, told a congressional panel. ``We have identified an unfunded capital backlog in the program of approximately $2.5 billion for construction requirements to which we must add new demands in Central America and Eastern Europe,'' Forte said He said those changes ``will place increased demand on our facility requirements. We must respond to these new challenges with a fresh look at what we do and how we do it.'' Soaring maintenance costs, high land prices in some areas and construction problems in other areas are also straining the budget, officials told the panel. Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, asked, for instance, why the department is buying 14 acres of land in Kuwait for $32 million, a price she said seemed exorbitant. Fort agreed ``it's a staggering price,'' but said real estate prices in the oil-rich Persian Gulf nation dictated the cost. ``Costs of land in Kuwait are about the highest in the world,'' said Richard Dertadian, deputy assistant secretary for foreign buildings. And they said if the State Department fails to sign a contract by July, the price could soar to over $40 million. The United States can't remain where it is past 1996 because the current embassy site is leased Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on international operations, said the existing U.S. Embassy in Kuwait is a security risk. Dymally said he recently traveled to Kuwait and said that from his hotel room, he could have shot the No. 2 official in the embassy with a pistol. The embassy is a ``ripe target for terrorist activities,'' he said. The officials told the hearing that about half of the $1 billion that Congress allocated to the department for the worldwide embassy project remains unspent. But they said they expect that money to be in the pipeline by the end of 1991. After that the department faces a crunch, they said. The officials said the department has 47 construction projects underway around the world in a renovation program that began in the mid-1980s. Eighteen projects are in construction, 18 are being designed and 11 are in site aquisition. The program stemmed from a worldwide review of embassy sites by an advisory panel looked at the condition of buildings and their vulnerability to attack.

DOC.HEAD: Ticket Snub: Are Box-Office Figures Accurate?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, ``The box ... '' to CORRECT title to columnist sted editor; Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Weekly box-office figures supplied by movie studios are sometimes as accurate as an old-fashioned Chicago vote count, say insiders, including some who admit to fudging the numbers to get ahead. Making movies is more competitive than ever these days, and the charts that rank them as hot or flops represent free and, some think, persuasive advertising. So why not crunch the numbers extra hard? ``It's gotten really out of hand,'' said an executive at one major studio who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I used to think that the independents were the only people who (cheated). But that's not true anymore.'' Here's how it works: Big studioslike Paramount and Disney and independents such as Miramax and New Line base their weekend grosses on surveys of about 75 percent of North America's movie houses. The polling, for the most part, is conducted by telephone by Entertainment Data Inc. But drive-ins, Spanish-language theaters and some small theaters and movie houses in Hawaii are not surveyed _ and that's the key. Let's say ``Ghostbusters 27: The Revenge of Casper'' collected $4.5 million at the screens surveyed by EDI. ``Honey, I Enlarged the Kids'' made $4.3 million, EDI says. Estimating ticket sales from the 25 percent of theaters not surveyed by EDI, ``Ghostbusters'' could report a correct final take of $5 million. The makers of ``Honey,'' not wanting to land in second place, could rewrite the figures for the 25 percent for their movie to show it received $5.1 million. And just like that, ``Honey'' ads appearing in newspapers the next day read: ``The Nation's No. 1 Movie!'' ``There is a lot of temptation to want to be in the top five,'' said Art Murphy, who analyzes box-office figures for the trade publication Variety. He believes that tinkering has become commonplace but that any large-scale manipulation would be easily detected. Said an executive from one top studio: ``It's just a little game. ... You want to have a film in Top 10, but it's better to have it in the Top 5. ... It's an independent promotional vehicle.'' Said another studio number-cruncher: ``Sometimes the pressure is incredible.'' Every Monday, the studios figure up their admission estimates. The numbers are compiled by EDI and Exhibitor Relations Co., which relay them to a variety of news organizations, including The Associated Press. ``It's not our job to police the studio's (final) numbers,'' said Phil Garfinkle, EDI senior vice president. At the very least, a high box-office placement keeps a title in the public's eye. Oscar voters might forget a film that's no longer on the leader board. Ancillary markets can be affected, too. A producer pushing a film for home video can say to prospective video distributors: ``But `When Perry Met Polly ...' did $1 million its first weekend!'' ``The box office grosses are very important today as a promotional tool because there is a tremendous amount of public interest in what is hot,'' said Martin Grove, business columnist for the Hollywood Reporter. Creative accounting is a staple of Hollywood bookkeeping, but the box-office figures had always been somewhat sacred, like the Nielsen TV ratings or publishing's best-seller lists. When Taurus reported not long ago that the low-budget exploitation film ``Angel Town'' made $300,000 in its opening weekend, the figure looked strange: The movie was making more per-screen ($5,455) than ``Driving Miss Daisy'' or the Steven Seagal hit ``Hard to Kill.'' How did Taurus explain the film's gross? ``I added the numbers up seven times and I always got a different figure, so I just said $300,000,'' said a Taurus executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the film had done solid business in drive-ins and Spanish-language houses. Universal and Fox locked horns in late February when Universal's ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and Fox's ``Nightbreed'' nearly tied for fifth place, with ``Born'' winning on the final tally. Both studios insisted the numbers were fair and cried trickery. Explained one studio executive: ``Anybody in this end of the business can go down those numbers and tell you who's exaggerating and who's not and by how much they're exaggerating.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Links Salvadoran Aid to Human Rights Performance
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration opened the door to a new, more restrictive policy toward El Salvador on Tuesday, agreeing in principle to link future U.S. aid to specific progress toward peace and human rights. At a Senate hearing and later in private meetings with lawmakers, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the administration would be willing to attach strings to future aid, including progress toward bringing to justice the killers of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. ``This case has got to become a turning point in the history of El Salvador,'' Baker told the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign aid. ``Our assistance is going to be affected by the way this case is handled. It's fair to say the government of El Salvador understands that.'' The secretary expanded on that offer in later private meetings, participants said, opening talks with Congress aimed at crafting a bipartisan U.S. policy toward El Salvador, where a civil war with leftist rebels has raged for a decade. ``The administration is willing to involve themselves in applying some pressure to both the FMLN (rebels) and the government,'' said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., a member of the House majority leadership. ``That is heartening.'' ``I think the elements for an agreement are there,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., the senior GOP member of the Foreign Affairs Committee. ``We are very close to an agreement. There is agreement that conditionality is important.'' While participants said Baker offered no specific numbers, an administration source said he might agree to making 25 percent of military aid contingent on human rights and peace progress. Baker's gesture was an indication that the administration recognizes a growing movement on Capitol Hill to restrict aid to El Salvador, which amounts to $315.4 million this year. Of that, $85 million is military aid. Bush has asked for $375 million next year, $90 million of it in military assistance. A primary impetus has been the Jesuit slayings. Nine military officials have been charged in the Nov. 16 murders, but a House Democratic task force reported Monday that the investigation has come to a virtual standstill and that Salvadoran authorities are reluctant to follow leads that point to involvement of higher-ups in the military. The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted last week to withhold half the military aid. The aid could be restored if the FMLN fails to work in good faith toward peace at U.N.-sponsored negotiations. It could be cut out entirely if the government fails to make similar good-faith efforts. Bonior said that formula was ``generally agreeable'' to the administration and to members of Congress in both parties. ``We agree that pressure should be applied to both sides to keep them at the table,'' he said after an hour-long meeting with Baker. Both sides agreed that whatever is done, the U.S. policy must be compatible with the U.N.-sponsored peace talks and must lead to the creation of ``political space'' that would allow the FMLN to participate in national elections next march, Bonior said. Further meetings will be scheduled as the two sides seek to work out an agreement similar to the bipartisan accord that revamped U.S. policy toward Nicaragua a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Female Dispatcher Awarded $150,000 in Sexual Harassment Case
DOC.TEXT: A female police dispatcher has won $150,000 in damages for years of sexual harassment by a male superior, who once allegedly pulled down her clothing so another officer could photograph her bared breast. Sydney Brauer, 38, of Macomb County's Bruce Township, said the harassment by Sgt. Robert White began in 1981 with unwanted neck massages, then escalated into tickling, unhooking of her bra and the 1984 photo incident. ``I didn't do anything wrong,'' Brauer said. ``But I was trying to change things since 1981 when it started.'' An attorney for White said the incidents were ``good-spirited horseplay.'' The jury award Monday includes $90,000 from White for harassment and intentional infliction of emotional distress and $30,000 from Romeo for letting the incidents continue. The Macomb County Circuit Court jury also ordered retired Police Chief Paul Uerling to pay $30,000 for retaliating against her by criticizing her work when she filed a complaint in 1987. The jury also awarded $11,000 to Anne Graber, 25, of Romeo, a former dispatcher who testified that White threw coins down her blouse and that on her birthday in 1986, White grabbed her and tried to kiss her passionately. White, who refused to comment about the verdict, denied both women's charges. He said the photographing incident occurred when he had his hand on Brauer's shoulder and her blouse accidentally slipped, baring the woman's breast. Brauer, a 17-year employee, and another officer, Douglas Wills, testified White intentionally exposed Brauer's breast. Charles Gerlach, Brauer's attorney, said the ``physical'' sexual harassment stopped only after Brauer announced she was pregnant, but verbal harassment ensued. Gerlach said White, a 23-year veteran of the force who lives in Romeo, made crude remarks about Brauer's weight gain and eating habits and berated her for being a working mother. Defense attorney Mary Cauley characterized the alleged harassment as horseplay. ``The breast incident ended it because Sergeant White thought it was getting out of hand,'' Cauley said. ``It was good-spirited horseplay between friends. She didn't object.'' Romeo, a community of about 3,500 people, is about 30 miles north of Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: Israeli Prisoners Should be Part of Any Hostage Deal
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials on Tuesday offered to free Arab prisoners in exchange for three Israelis held captive in Lebanon, but indicated they would not make a deal for Western hostages alone. President Bush said Monday he had ``certainly no objection'' to Israel freeing some of the thousands of prisoners it holds, a goodwill gesture suggested by a Tehran newspaper. But Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said Israel had received no U.S. request for a prisoner release. He responded ``certainly not'' when asked if he viewed Bush's remarks as pressure. ``The United States has ways to convey its opinions to us. We are in close touch always. We haven't been told anything of this,'' he said. Asked if Israel refused to free Arab detainees unless captive Israelis were released, Pazner said he did not want to phrase his comments in a ``negative way.'' ``Our policy is to get our prisoners back and for that purpose we are ready to consider the release of people detained here,'' he said. Danny Naveh, spokesman for Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, said Israeli captives were Israel's first priority. ``Our interest is to release our hostages,'' he said. Three Israelis were captured in Lebanon in 1986 and are believed held by radical Shiites linked to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia. Six Americans and 10 other Westerners are held hostage in Lebanon. The Israelis are Ron Arad, a navigator shot down over Sidon, and soldiers Yossi Fink and Rahamim Alsheikh of the army's elite Givati brigade captured in an ambush in southern Lebanon. Privately, officials said they interpreted Bush's comments as an appeal, suggesting he could not make a more direct approach without appearing to violate his stated policy of not making deals with terrorists. Some also indicated Shamir was feeling increasing pressure to assist the United States in ending the hostage ordeal. The U.S. government gives Israel $3 billion a year in aid and they have a strategic cooperation agreement. But there was no sign Israel was prepared to make such a move. ``It is inconceivable that Israel would agree to give up on any of its assets in hand without Israeli prisoners being part of the deal,'' a senior Israeli official told the mas-circulation Yediot Ahronot. A decision to free Arab prisoners without getting Israelis in return could stir angry protests as Shamir tries to form a government that depends on right-wing nationalist and religious factions. Yediot Ahronot quoted an Arab weekly newspaper as saying Israel had told Washington there would be no release of Shiite prisoners without a package deal that includes the captured Israelis. The most prominent prisoner Israel holds is Sheikh Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Shiite Moslem cleric belonging to Hezbollah. Israel captured Obeid and two assistants on July 28. Israel holds more than 5,000 Palestinians detained during the 28-month uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied territories. About 1,300 are being held without trial in the Ketziot prison located in the Negev desert. In addition, more than 300 Arab prisoners are held by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army at al-Khiam just north of the Israeli-Lebanese border. Most of the al-Khiam inmates are Shiite Moslems. The best-known is Jawad Kaswi, captured in 1988. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity said Israel pressured SLA commander Antoine Lahd to cancel a planned release of prisoners for the Id al-Fitr holiday April 26 because of publicity linking it to the Western hostages. Apparently for the same reason, Israel refrained from freeing Palestinian prisoners. The release is customary during Moslem holidays. In recent years, Israel has engaged in lopsided prisoner releases to gain the freedom of captured soldiers. The most controversial was the May 1985 exchange worked out with the pro-Syrian Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. Israel won the release of three soldiers by freeing nearly 1,100 Arabs, many of them convicted terrorists who have since been re-arrested for anti-Israeli activism.

DOC.HEAD: Workers and Students Protest Police Raids
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of workers and students staged demonstrations throughout South Korea on Tuesday to protest police raids that crushed strikes at a state broadcast network and the nation's largest shipyard. Violent street protests broke out in Seoul and at least 17 provincial cities on the May Day labor holiday. Students and workers at auto plants, subways, shipyards and broadcast stations held rallies or clashed with riot police, hurling rocks and firebombs. More than 80,000 people took part in Tuesday's protests, the largest this year, news reports said. Police reported arrests and injuries but gave no overall figures. In Seoul alone, about 150 people were arrested, bringing to nearly 500 the number detained in the capital in the past four days, reports said. Across the nation in that same period, authorities said 80 policemen and 14 workers were injured and nine workers formally charged with instigating labor unrest. ``Crush (President) Roh Tae-woo who suppresses labor!'' yelled hundreds of radical students hurling firebombs and rocks at riot police outside Seoul's Yonsei University. The government said it perceived the current labor unrest as ``a crisis.'' ``We cannot help taking strong measures against the labor protests, which have political overtones,'' Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon said Tuesday after a meeting with aides and leaders of the governing Democratic Liberal Party. Kang and other officials expressed concern that the already slumping Korean economy might suffer further unless the unrest eases. A prolonged labor dispute in 1987 slowed exports and led to increased unemployment. Korean exports shrank 1.4 percent in the first quarter this year and share prices on the Korean stock market took the biggest single-day plunge ever on Monday, hitting an 18-month low. Wages are not a main issue in the current protests. Workers are demanding the release of jailed union leaders and more freedom to organize labor without government interference. Major protests were reported in the southeastern industrial city of Ulsan, where police stormed the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard, the nation's largest, over the weekend to end a three-day strike. The police action touched off four days of violent sympathy protests by workers in Ulsan and other industrial regions. On Tuesday, about 4,000 workers in Ulsan, hurling rocks and firebombs, fought police near the shipyard as an estimated 40,000 workers held rallies elsewhere in the city, reports said. A 41-year-old worker in Ulsan was seriously injured when he leaped from the second floor of a house while being chased by police. At the shipyard, about 50 militant workers were holding out atop a 240-foot crane for the fourth day Tuesday. The workers fled there when police raided the stike-bound shipyard last Saturday. At the nearby Hyundai Motor Co., the nation's largest car maker, about 20,000 workers decided to extend until Sunday a sympathy strike that began Monday and initially was scheduled for two days. The shipyard and the car plant are the main arms of the giant Hyundai group, one of the largest conglomerates in South Korea, which reported $4.8 billion in 1989 sales. In Seoul, hundreds of riot police guarded the state-run Korean Broadcasting System headquarters, where 2,400 police staged a midnight raid Monday to end a 19-day protest against the network's new president. Police arrested 333 workers. Workers at the nation's only other network, the Munwha Broadcasting Co., began a five-day sympathy strike on Tuesday, virtually crippling the nation's broadcasting industry. Programming was curtailed at the three networks, five stations and 19 local stations run by the two companies. The labor unrest spilled over to Citibank in Seoul, where tellers refused to wear bank uniforms, instead donning T-shirts and slacks to press their demand for freer labor activity. The capital's subway workers declared a two-day protest, refusing to sell tickets and giving passengers free rides. In southern Chonju, dozens of radical students armed with steel pipes and firebombs attacked a building where government party officials were to meet and smashed windows, said Yonhap, the South Korean news agency.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Will Press On Seeking Israeli-Palestinian Talks
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday that Palestinian Arabs would hold talks with Israel only with the acquiesence of the Palestine Liberation Organization. But Baker told a Senate appropriations subcommittee he was not trying to force Israel to deal with Yasser Arafat's group. ``We are not involved in a process to bring the Israeli government into a dialogue with the PLO,'' Baker said. Testifying on a wide range of foreign policy problems, Baker was questioned closely by Sens. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., and Arlen Specter, R-Pa., on whether he is trying to involve the PLO in Mideast negotiations. ``That is not the case,'' Baker said. However, he added: ``It is our view that a dialogue will not take place between Palestinians and Israel unless it is aquiesced in by the PLO.'' Baker's description of only limited PLO involvement in his efforts to arrange the talks apparently left Kasten and Specter, two of Israel's strongest supporters in Congress, unconvinced. ``If pressure were not applied on Israel on the PLO issue we could move ahead,'' Specter said. He also told Baker he believed the administration hoped the PLO could be involved in some way. ``I disagree,'' Baker said. At the same time, he said he intended to ``press on'' with his effort to arrange Israeli-Palestinian talks. On Monday, Baker criticized Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir for not accepting his formula for the talks. Through his spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, Baker said Shamir had missed an opportunity to promote peace and his own initiaitve. Shamir proposed last May to hold elections among Palestinians on the West Bank and in Gaza. The Baker formula the prime minister refused to endorse involved having Palestinians who were ousted from the West Bank or who resided in East Jerusalem in the delegation. The Israeli government split over Baker's approach, and then collapsed. Baker's vow to keep trying to find a solution coincides with a continuing attempt by Shamir to form a new government.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Congressman Says U.S. Pressured German Scientist to Leave Country
DOC.TEXT: Rep. James Traficant believes U.S. officials pressured a German rocket scientist to renounce his American citizenship rather than face charges of Nazi war crimes, a spokesman said Tuesday. Arthur Rudolph renounced his citizenship in 1984 under an agreement with the Justice Department. Rudolph said his citizenship was illegally obtained, agreeing to leave the country and never return. Traficant spokesman H. West Richards said the Ohio Democrat ``believes pressure was put on Rudolph to renounce his citizenship.'' Neal Sher, head of the Office of Special Investigations at the Justice Department, called the allegation absurd. Sher said Rudolph renounced his citizenship ``after much deliberation, after consulting at length with his lawyer and after signing an agreement in which he specifically conceded his involvement in Nazi persecution.'' The 84-year-old Ruldoph lives in Hamburg, West Germany. His supporters in Huntsville, Ala., have scheduled a May 12 event at which Traficant will speak. ``Traficant is the one man in Congress who has opened his eyes to the methods used by the OSI and called them into question,'' the Friends of Arthur Rudolph said in a statement. Rudolph was brought to the United States with more than 100 other German technicians and scientists after World War II to help the United States develop space and armament programs. He became the manager of the Saturn 5 rocket program at the NASA space center in Huntsville. The rocket was used to send astronauts to the moon in 1969. From 1943 to 1945, Rudolph was production manager of a V-2 rocket factory attached to the Dora-Nordhausen concentration camp. Slave labor from the camp was used in the factory. Rudolph told the OSI in 1983 that he knew that prisoners he chose to work in the underground factory died of maltreatment. The OSI contends Rudolph ``participated, under the direction of and on behalf of the Nazi government in Germany, in the persecution of unarmed civilians because of their race, religion, national origin or political opinion.'' The OSI is looking into the files of other former participants in the rocket program to see if any of them lied about their past. Supporters in Alabama, some of them former Nazi scientists, say Rudolph served the United States loyally and when he was no longer needed was intimidated and harassed until he left the country. Traficant also is championing the cause of John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland-area auto worker condemned to death in Israel after being convicted of committing Nazi atrocities.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmits a0609 to clear extraneous material in slugline
Retired Herald Managing Editor, Press Committee Founder Dies
DOC.TEXT: George H. Beebe, whose decades-long career helped guide The Miami Herald to a position of prominence and developed its role in coverage of Latin America, has died of cancer. He was 80. Beebe died Monday at the Miami Heart Institute. The Herald became a recognized chronicler of Latin America while Beebe served as managing editor. Some of the reporters he hired became Pulitzer Prize winners and Knight-Ridder executives. Beebe joined the Herald as a copy editor in 1944, served as managing editor in 1951-1966, then was senior managing editor until 1972, when he became an associate publisher and continued contributing travel articles. Beebe helped found the World Press Freedom Committee in 1976 and served as its executive director and chairman of the anti-censorship alliance of 32 journalistic organizations. He also served as president of the Inter American Press Association. ``George Beebe ran the news department the way he lived his life _ a caring, compassionate person who believed in letting the reader feel he was important,'' said Lee Hills, managing editor when Beebe arrived at the Herald and retired chairman of its parent Knight-Ridder group. The Pittsfield, Mass., native was managing editor of the Boston University News for 13 years before joining the Herald. Beebe prepared his own obituary for the newspaper, writing: ``If I have been successful, it is because I have had Helen at my side. She has been a patient, understanding and devoted newspaper wife.'' He is survived by his wife, three nieces and four nephews. A memorial service is planned Thursday at the First United Methodist Church of Coral Gables.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Settlers Quit Christian Quarter of Old Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Armed settlers left a compound in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City before a court deadline Tuesday, and a judge sentenced the settlement movement's founder to five months in jail for killing a Palestinian. Jerusalem District Court Judge Shalom Brenner also handed Rabbi Moshe Levinger a seven-month suspended sentence for fatally shooting shoestore owner Kayed Hassan Salah on Sept. 30, 1988. Levinger was initially charged with manslaughter, which carries a maximum term of 20 years in prison. As part of a plea bargain, he said he was guilty to the lesser charge of causing death by negligence. Salah, 42, was standing at the entrance to his shop when he was shot during a stone-throwing incident in the West Bank town of Hebron. Israeli human rights advocates say settlers have killed at least 29 Palestinians since the start of the uprising nearly 29 months ago. Only one other settler besides Levinger has been sentenced to jail since the insurrection began in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In Jerusalem's Old City, settler spokesmen said 50 Jewish families had complied with a Supreme Court order to vacate the 72-room St. John's Hospice, which is owned by the Greek Orthodox Church. ``I believe they will be back. I believe in justice,'' settler spokesman Shmuel Eviatar said, as bells from the Church of the Holy Sepulcher and other nearby churches pealed loudly. Greek Orthdox Bishop Areopulos Christodulos pledged to ``continue in all the courts until all the settlers get out of the building.'' After heated arguments between the settlers and clergymen in black cloaks, a six-member church delegation was allowed to inspect the complex to confirm that all settlers who were supposed to leave had done so. ``They evacuated the settlement, except for 20 people,'' said Avraham Sochovolsky, an attorney for the church. Reporters and photographers saw settlers leave the building in small groups over the past few days, apparently to avoid a mass exit that would look like a retreat. The Supreme Court ruled Thursday that all but 20 of the 150 settlers who moved into St. John's Hospice on April 11 should leave by noon Tuesday. The remaining settlers act as caretakers for the Panama-based SBC company, which acquired the lease that the church contends is invalid. The court let them stay until the tenancy dispute is decided. The caretakers were later seen in the windows, which were draped with the blue-and-white Israeli flags. They also unfurled one flag over the street. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek and senior police officials have warned that the settlers' presence threatened to provoke violence in the Old City, which is divided into jealously guarded Christian, Moslem, Jewish and Armenian quarters. The Old City was captured from Jordan in 1967 and annexed by Israel. Most nations, including the United States, do not recognize Israel's claim to sovereignty. Major Christian sects joined in an unprecedented closing of holy sites throughout Israel on Friday to protest the settlement. The move into the Old City was seen part of a broader campaign by right-wingers to exploit Israel's present political vacuum and push new settlement activity.

DOC.HEAD: Aviation Industry Ups Ante To $ 3 Million In Government Reward Program
DOC.TEXT: The airline industry boosted a government program to fight aviation terrorism Tuesday, increasing rewards for information that helps stop airliner sabotage to $3 million. The Air Transport Association, representing U.S. carriers, announced it would match any government reward up to $1 million if it involves a threat or attack against a U.S. airline. Morris D. Busby, State Department ambassador for counter-terrorism, said rewards already have been paid in the government's $2 million program, but he said details of the payments would not be disclosed. Anyone who provides information that leads to the arrest, conviction or thwarting of an aviation terrorist could get up to $3 million, officials said in a joint news conference with representatives of ATA, State Department, the Federal Aviation Administration and the FBI. The reward program also includes an offer of relocation and other protection for witnesses, officials said. ``This should be a powerful incentive for people within, or close to, terrorist organizations to reveal plots before they are hatched,'' said Robert J. Aaronson, ATA president. He said it would also apply to past acts, including information about the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people. Aaronson said U.S. airlines would each contribute a share of the reward that would be tied to the State Department reward program, which was increased by Congress last year from $500,000 to $2 million. The ATA's $1 million also would be available through the FBI to match rewards designed to combat domestic air terrorism, Aaronson said. James B. Busey, FAA administrator, said the increased rewards send a strong message to terrorists that ``the United States and the aviation community are fully committed to this battle against terrorism.'' Bruce Smith, a Pan American pilot whose wife, Ingrid, died in the Flight 103 bombing, had proposed the rewards. Smith said at the news conference more has to be done to stop state-sponsored terrorism and to get other countries to cooperate in anti-terrorist efforts. William Baker, FBI assistant director, said the bureau's investigators are meeting every day with foreign authorities in an effort to ``keep the pressure on'' to solve the Lockerbie bombing. There have been no arrests or charges in the incident, but authorities have said they believe Middle East terrorists planted the plastic explosives inside a radio cassette player that became part of checked-in luggage.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Improves Outlook For Winter Wheat
DOC.TEXT: Rain has improved the winter wheat outlook in the northern Great Plains and Pacific Northwest but more is needed, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. Soil moisture was said to be ``adequate or adequate to surplus'' in the central and southern plains, while in Arkansas, Missouri and parts of Texas rain continued to slow field work. Overall, the 1990 winter wheat crop was said to be in ``mostly good to fair'' condition during the week of April 23-29, with an estimated 15 percent of the crop headed, which was average for this time of the season. ``Winter wheat was mostly good in Colorado and Montana, good to fair in Nebraska, and fair to good in South Dakota,'' the report said. The crop was reported ``good to excellent'' in Kansas, good in Oklahoma, and ``fair to good'' in Texas. Planting of spring wheat was reported 54 percent completed, 9 percentage points ahead of normal. Corn planting was said to be 21 percent complete, five points behind the average for this time of year. Planting was under way in all of the major corn states.

DOC.HEAD: Government Raises Savings Bonds Rates
DOC.TEXT: U.S. savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.01 percent from May 1 through Oct. 31, up slightly from 6.98 percent the during the previous six months, the Treasury Department said Tuesday. Catalina V. Villalpando, treasurer of the United States, said the new rate ``will keep savings bonds in the competitive range with other market-sensitive instruments during the coming months.'' Savings bond interest rates are changed each May 1 and Nov. 1 to reflect open market rates.
