They are based on 85 percent of the yield on five-year Treasury securities, which have averaged 8.25 percent. Savings bond yields at redemption are the average of semiannual market-based rates during the time held, compounded semiannually or at a minimum rate, whichever is greater. The current minimum rate is 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Holding More Than 5,300 Arabs in Detention
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel holds thousands of Arab detainees captured in south Lebanon or the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. It offered a deal Tuesday to free many of them in exchange for three Israeli captives. Here at a glance is a breakdown on the Arab and Israeli captives:

HELD BY ISRAEL _ More than 5,300 Arab prisoners, including more than 5,000 Palestinians detained by Israeli during the uprising against military rule that began nearly 29 months ago in the occupied territories. About 1,300 of the Palestinians are under so-called administrative detention or jailed without trial in a tent prison camp in southern Israel. Sheikh Abdul-Karim Obeid, 33, a Shiite Moslem cleric of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah guerrilla group, is the most prominent prisoner. Israelis kidnapped him and two aides in Jibchit, south Lebanon, on July 28. They are believed held in Israel.

HELD BY THE ISRAELI-BACKED SOUTH LEBANON ARMY MILITIA _ More than 300 Lebanese detainees, most of them Shiites, held at a compound in Al-Khiam, just north of Israel's border with Lebanon. Jawad Kaswi, in captivity since 1988, is the best known. Kaswi is a onetime leader of a faction of the Amal Shiite militia group, which once had control of one of the Israeli prisoners.

HELD BY THE ARABS _ An Israeli air navigator and two Israeli infantrymen have been held since 1986. All three are believed held by Shiites linked to Hezbollah. Navigator Ron Arad was shot down during a bombing mission over Sidon, south Lebanon, in October 1986. Soldiers Yossi Fink and Rahamim Alsheikh of the Givati Infantry Brigade were captured in an ambush in south Lebanon in February 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Lehder Urges Noriega to Plead Guilty
DOC.TEXT: Convicted Colombian drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas has written Manuel Noriega urging the deposed Panamanian leader to plead guilty to drug charges, but pledging not to testify against him. ``Your lawyers are telling you stories to get your money. You would be wise to talk to your old friends and formalize a declaration of guilt, showing dignity and a sense of reality,'' the letter said. Lehder, 40, who prosecutors said worked with Colombia's Medellin drug cartel, was convicted of smuggling cocaine and is serving a life term plus 135 years at Marion Federal Prison in Illinois. Noriega, 51, is confined in the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center near Miami, facing drug charges which include accepting $4.6 million in bribes from the cartel. Lehder sent The Associated Press a copy of his letter to Noriega, dated April 18. The Spanish language letter, received Tuesday, bears his recognizable signature and a fingerprint, and the envelope bears a Marion, Ill., postmark and a prison stamp. An accompanying letter authorized release of the Noriega letter. However, Noriega might never see the letter. Mel Collins, an assistant warden at MCC, said that without authorization one federal prisoner may not write to another, and any such letter would be rejected at that prison. Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office in Miami, said prosecutors had nothing to say about the letter. ``It's personal correspondence from one person to another and we would have no comment,'' she said. Frank Rubino, Noriega's lead defense attorney, was in trial and not immediately available for comment, his receptionist said. The letter chastises Noriega for his one-time cooperation with the Drug Enforcement Administration. On several occasions, Noriega deported drug suspects to the United States, even though not required to under Panamanian law. ``It is a sign of greatness for a man to recognize his errors _ the sorrow of the men of your race whom you turned over to agents of the DEA, destined for the awaiting prisons of the U.S.A.,'' Lehder said. Despite the criticism, Lehder said he will not help Noriega's prosecutors. ``I will not testify against you because, despite your sins, we are of the same fraternal Latin race,'' the letter said. Lehder also cites federal penal codes to show Noriega he has no chance of escaping justice, saying the U.S. force that invaded Panama on Dec. 20 had the right to capture and prosecute him. ``You were arrested, not kidnapped as I was,'' wrote Lehder, who was seized by Colombian troops in February 1987 and immediately flown to Jacksonville to face drug-smuggling charges. Following a 7{-month-long trial, Lehder was convicted on all counts.

DOC.HEAD: Prisons Setting Up Anti-Drug Programs For Soon To Be Freed Inmates
DOC.TEXT: Education programs to discourage federal inmates from resuming drug habits after their release are being set up at eight federal prisons, the Justice Department said Tuesday. As many as 975 inmates at eight federal prison facilities will participate in the two programs that will also provide post-release supervision, said Michael Quinlan, director of the Bureau of Prisons. ``The only effective drug treatment is treatment that is offered toward the end of the sentence and is tied into the community integration process,'' Quinlan told reporters. The approach is being taken because prison officials decided ``we have a unique captive audience and we ought to take advantage of it'' Quinlan said. Additionally, all new federal prison inmates who have a history of drug abuse will be required to complete a drug education program, Quinlan said. New inmates who refuse to participate in this program will be denied privileges extended to other prisoners and will be eligible for only the lowest-paying jobs in work programs, Quinlan said. The number of federal inmates with a history of drug use has grown dramatically in the last decade, Quinlan said. Currently, 45 percent of the 56,200 federal inmates had drug abuse problems when they were sentenced to prison, he said. In all, the Bureau of Prisons expects to spend $6 million on drug-prevention programs during the current fiscal year, up from $2.25 million last year, Quinlan said. The new programs were announced at a press briefing a day before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee was scheduled to question Justice Department officials about a cutoff of $5 million in drug-treatment funds to state and local prison systems. The money, which was available last year in grants to state and local officials, was shifted to other programs during the current fiscal year. Clifford J. White III, deputy assistant attorney general in the Office of Justice Programs and Gerald Regier, acting director of the Bureau fo Justice Assistance, were scheduled to be questioned on Wednesday. The new programs for federal prison inmates completing their sentences are based on the notion that ``a person is addicted to drugs regardless of whether the sentence may interrupt the ability to get that substance,'' Quinlan said. ``If people do not learn to deal with that addiction, they are going to return to the same life style,'' Quinlan said. Intensive 1,000-hour drug-education programs have already been set up at federal facilities in Butner, N.C. and Lexington, Ky. An identical program is also planned for the federal prison in Tallahassee, Fla., Quinlan said. A total of 350 inmates in the last 15 to 24 months of their sentences will participate in the programs, he said. In September, 500-hour education programs will be offfered at prisons in Sheridan, Ore.; Seagoville, Texas; Rochester, Minn.; Oxford, Wis.; and Fairton, N.J. The programs at each of those facilities will serve 100 to 125 inmates each year with counseling and individual therapy.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Key Members of Congress to Back Space Program
DOC.TEXT: President Bush asked key members of Congress to support his $15.8-billion space exploration package Tuesday, but was told the money will be difficult to come by in the current fiscal squeeze. Leaders of the committees that deal most directly with the space budget were supportive of Bush's plans to develop the Space Station and send missions to the moon and Mars, but were less positive about prospects for the money to finance such missions, participants said. One said Bush was told, ``We can't make you any promises.'' ``We have got to find a way to finance space,'' Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., told reporters after the meeting. ``You're going to have to have some identifiable, sustainable source of revenue. ... People are strongly supportive of space, but next year and the year after they might not be.'' Heflin said that space exploration should not have to compete, as it does now, for funds that also are sought for environmental, housing and veterans programs. Heflin mentioned user fees as one way to raise money for an expanded space program. Participants said Bush was noncommittal about that idea. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater characterized the suggestions as a way ``to provide long-term, continuous support for the space program as opposed to the annual appropriations process.'' Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md. and chairman of the appropriations subcommittee covering space exploration, called on Bush to ``go beyond bumper stickers and big promises'' to support the space initiative. She said congressional leaders want to meet with Bush's key budget personnel to look for ``a sustainable revenue source'' that would keep the space program from having to compete in the budget battle every year. ``In a budget that is funded year to year, it's very hard to allocate those resources that are for Mission To Planet Earth, the Space Station and then a Moon-Mars initiative, which could take 30 years of funding,'' she said. Bush called the meeting, the first such presidential gathering of all the congressional leaders on financing the space program. Congress next month begins the process of writing the fiscal 1991 federal budget. Bush made a pitch for support of his proposal to increase this fiscal year's financing for space activities by $2.9 billion to $15.8 billion. Vice President Dan Quayle, the chairman of the president's Space Council, spoke with the congressional delegation about Bush's proposal to return Americans to the moon and then send a manned mission to Mars. Separately, Quayle said in a speech in Arlington, Va., that savings from lowered defense spending should go for space-related research. ``Investing in space is especially important in light of the decline in our military spending,'' he told the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Contain 5,500-Acre Everglades Blaze
DOC.TEXT: A drought-fed brush fire was contained Tuesday after it blackened 5,500 acres of Everglades grassland, a park spokeswoman said. ``It looks good,'' said Pat Tolle of Everglades National Park. ``It's been confined to a few isolated areas, and there are no active flames.'' Afternoon winds were light, aiding forestry officials' efforts to dump water from helicopters on the hot spots. Firefighters also were building firebreaks around the burned area. Most of the acreage burned outside the park in south Dade County, but about 1,600 acres of parkland were blackened by the lightning-sparked blaze, she said. ``Periodic fire is critical to maintain the marsh habitat,'' she said. ``Without periodic fire, the hardwood trees encroach and it no longer functions as a wading bird habitat.'' But this fire alarmed park officials because a two-year drought has left vast stretches of the wetlands almost bone dry. ``Conditions are so extreme, we want to confine it,'' she said. ``If it gets into the pinelands, a fire would be very damaging because it's so dry.'' Drought conditions have left the Everglades so dry that alligators and wading birds are traveling far from their natural habitats to find water. Most residents in central and south Florida face restrictions on lawn watering and home car washing, and water levels in Lake Okeechobee, which supplies much of the region's water, have hit record lows.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Secretary Dedicates Sprawling Wildlife Refuge In New Orleans
LaserPhotoNU3
DOC.TEXT: More than 18,000 acres of lush marshes and thick forests _ rich in wildlife and all within the city limits _ were dedicated as a national wildlife refuge Tuesday by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan. ``We have some other wildlife on Bourbon Street, but this is the wildlife we want to protect,'' joked Mayor Sidney Barthelemy in ceremonies marking creation of the Bayou Sauvage National Wildlife Refuge. Bayou Sauvage will be a premier education center for wildlife preservation, Lujan said. The sprawling site is a haven for alligators, nutria, otters, rabbits and many varieties of fish and migratory birds. And, Lujan added, it will make unspoiled wetlands and forests accessible to city dwellers and New Orleans tourists. ``The refuge is right in the middle of New Orleans, only nine miles from Jackson Square'' said Lujan, referring to a popular French Quarter landmark. The refuge is near the site of a proposed eastern New Orleans landfill that is drawing strong opposition from residents of the area. State Sen. Ben Bagert of New Orleans, , Gov. Buddy Roemer's representative at the ceremony, asked approximately 100 dignitaries attending to support his bill in the Legislature that would prohibit landfills within a mile of wildlife refuges. Lujan said later it was the first time he'd heard about plans for a landfill. ``I can tell you that we're not sympathetic at all about having a refuge next to a landfill,'' Lujan said. It was purchased from South Point Inc., a subsidiary of the Merrill Lynch investment firm, for $7.75 million. Estimates of the cost of developing the refuge run as high as $19 million. It would include an administrative building, visitor center and environmental education complex, and officials hope to finish it in two to three years. Legislation creating the refuge was introduced in 1986 by Reps. Lindy Boggs, D-La., and John Breaux, D-La., today Louisiana's junior senator.

DOC.HEAD: Skeleton of Harvard Woman Found After Nine Years
DOC.TEXT: Three psychics and a $50,000 reward didn't work. In the end, it was a veterinarian walking her dog who found the bones of a Harvard student who vanished in 1981. The discovery of the remains of Joan Webster also renewed questions about the role of the infamous Leonard ``The Quahog'' Paradiso, a small-time hood doing time for another slaying. Paradiso never was charged in the Webster case, in which Essex County District Attorney Kevin Burke said he ``became a suspect almost immediately'' after Webster disappeared from Logan International Airport. The case was revived after veterinarian Karen Wolf last month stumbled across part of a skull in the woods in Hamilton, a wealthy community 25 miles north of Boston. More bones were found after that. Confirmation that the remains were Webster's was made Monday. Authorities said the cause of death was ``blunt trauma to the head,'' and that Webster was a homicide victim. ``That is some measure of relief,'' George Webster said of the identification. He said he and his wife, Terry, had long believed their daughter had been slain. Joan Webster was last seen at the airport on Nov. 28, 1981. The native of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Syracuse University graduate was headed back to the Harvard's School of Design after a Thanksgiving visit with her parents. Webster was a successful and active student who had made the dean's list at Syracuse. She liked skiing, sailing, tennis and photography and had traveled widely, her parents said. The search for Webster turned up her wallet 300 feet from where 20-year-old Marie Ianuzzi's body was dumped in 1979 in Saugus. Saugus is 15 miles from where the bones were found. Paradiso was convicted of Ianuzzi's murder in 1984. After Webster vanished, her family and friends offered a $50,000 reward. Shortly after the disappearance, three psychics came forward, including one who said he envisioned her body was in a pond in Manchester, about five miles from where her bones were later found. ``It was close,'' said Beverly Police Capt. Gordon Richards, who was among the investigators in 1982. In 1985, attention focused on Paradiso after a former cellmate alleged that the one-time fish merchant claimed involvement in killing Webster. Timothy Burke, who was Suffolk County prosecutor at the time, said in an affidavit that Paradiso told an informant he forced Webster onto his 26-foot cabin cruiser, the Malafemmina _ Italian for ``bad woman'' _ with a fake .357-caliber Magnum. According to the account, he hit her on the head with a whiskey bottle and dumped her body in Boston Harbor. Many people now want to talk to Paradiso, 45, formerly from Revere. Paradiso, who has defended himself in the media in the past, is not talking much. He did not return a phone call Tuesday, and a spokesman for the Department of Correction said the Walpole inmate refuses to speak to reporters. It could not be immediately determined if he was currently being represented by an attorney. His convictions include rape and attempted murder of a hitchhiker in 1975, as well as the strangulation of Ianuzzi in 1979. He was also found guilty on federal bankruptcy fraud charges for claiming to be worth $10 when he was working at a lobster company and had $10,000 in the bank. When the prison informant linked him to Webster's disappearance, Paradiso denied the allegations. He protested his innocence in writing to newspapers, the district attorney, police and even Webster's parents. ``Now do you think a high-class smart girl like Joan Webster from a good family, with money, is going to get into a car with a guy like me smelling of fish?'' he told a newspaper six years ago. He sued Boston magazine for $3 million, saying he was libeled in a story linking him to the Webster case. That suit was dismissed in 1987 by a judge who said Paradiso's reputation was so bad he was ``libel-proof.'' Kevin Burke, the Essex County prosecutor, indicated Paradiso wasn't ruled out even though finding the bones in the woods seems to discount the Boston Harbor theory. Shards of metal and glass stuck in Paradiso's index finger, thought to be part of the fake gun, became the subject of a protracted and much publicized legal battle over the inmate's right to keep the contents of his injured finger secret. He underwent forced surgery but it yielded no new evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Newborn Sister Holds Only Hope for Sick 4-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old boy is facing a tricky procedure of using umbilical cord blood from the birth of his sister on Tuesday to help treat his rare form of leukemia, doctors said. Michael Sancilio's form of leukemia afflicts less than 1 percent of childhood leukemia victims. ``Children with this disease generally survive less than a year after diagnosis,'' said Stephen Rodgers, the family's pediatrician. Michael was diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia in mid-March. Normal treatment is a bone marrow transplant, Rodgers said, but the chance of quickly finding a bone marrow match from a donor is statistically slim. With so little time, doctors are gambling on the umbilical blood transfusion. That's where Christina Grace Sancilio comes in. She was born by Caesarian section Tuesday morning at Virginia Beach General Hospital. Dr. Leslie L. Wasserman, who delivered both Christina and Michael, said the newborn is healthy and doing well. Using a syringe, Wasserman made two collections of umbilical blood _ one with the placenta still attached, the other with the placenta delivered. The one cup of blood is en route to Indiana University scientists who will check to see if Christina's blood matches Michael's. Wasserman said the procedure was difficult because the surgery team had to ensure that none of the mother's blood contaminated the umbilical cord blood. Wasserman said a Caesarian section was performed because of 33-year-old Denise Sancilio's difficulties in delivering Michael. Physicians put the chances for a match at 1-in-4, far better than the 1-in-20,000 chance of a match in the general population. Rodgers said this was the first time the experimental procedure would be tried for a leukemia patient. Umbilical blood contains special cells called stem cells, which develop bone marrow in babies in their first nine months. Rodgers said Christina already has the necessary stem cells to develop bone marrow. If the blood matches Michael's, the cells will be grown in a laboratory at the university, which pioneered the procedure for the treatment of some forms of anemia. Once scientists have grown the cells, they will be transfused into Michael after all his diseased bone marrow has been killed by radiation. The cells are injected into the patient's heart and act as if they were in a newborn, heading straight for the bone to produce bone marrow. `We don't know what all the problems might be at this point,'' said Rodgers. ``It's all going to take several months, and Michael will be close to the end of his disease when we try the transfusion.'' Even if the procedure is successful, Rodgers said the child faces a lifetime of treatment to ensure the body does not reject the new bone marrow. With sons Michael and Tony in his arms, Anthony Sancilio, 35, tried to express his joy and hope at seeing his daughter. ``I'm speechless ... I'm thankful the baby is healthy and hopeful that we will have a match,'' he said. Tests of 7-year-old Tony showed he was not a compatible donor for his brother.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Freeze Military Construction; Review Homeports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs with home port legislation, detail
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney raised the ante in the Pentagon budget battle Tuesday by extending a worldwide freeze on military construction and ordering 207 projects _ including Navy ports in Texas, Alabama, Mississippi and New York _ be reviewed for possible cancellation. ``There's serious doubt about whether or not we will get the levels of funding from Congress that will allow us to go forward with these programs,'' Cheney said. The move is expected to fuel the debate between those in Congress who want to squeeze Pentagon spending and lawmakers who want to protect local jobs. Cheney said the freeze order, which he imposed in January and now will last until June 15, affects more than $7 billion in new contracts. The 207 construction projects to be reviewed are valued at $1.2 billion, he said. At a news conference, Cheney accused some members of Congress of ``a certain amount of hypocrisy'' because they publicly advocate smaller Pentagon budgets even as they lobby him in private to protect home-state military programs. ``Some of these actions may not be popular with members of Congress who want to cut the defense budget even as they plead to save the projects in their own states and districts,'' Cheney said. ``But when tight budgets force dedicated soldiers to turn in their uniforms and leave the service, I cannot put construction projects ahead of people.'' The 207 sites under study include strategic home ports in Ingleside, Texas; Mobile, Ala.; Pascagoula, Miss.; and Staten Island, N.Y. The majority of the projects under review are overseas, many in West Germany. Planned improvements or construction of hangars, maintenance facilities, family housing projects, schools for military dependents and medical units are among the items targeted. But several of the domestic sites targeted for study carry big-money pricetags. The statement said that besides the four ports, the review will also include a $110 million project at a rocket test facility at Arnold, Tenn.; $60 million in improvements at Fort Hood and Red River Army Depot in Texas; and a $37 million project at a consolidated maintenance facility at Tooele, Utah. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., chairwoman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on military installations and facilities, said she was pleased with Cheney's announcement because he targeted overseas work she has opposed. In recent weeks, Cheney has taken steps to pare the defense budget, including cutting from 132 to 75 the number of B-2 Stealth bombers it proposes buying and sharply reducing other warplane programs. Citing changes in the world situation and increasing budget limitations, Cheney said ``significant opportunities exist'' to reduce the cost and size of the DOD's infrastructure. Cheney's order directs that no new construction contracts be awarded for projects financed under the military construction budget approved by Congress. The 207 construction projects will be ``candidates for rescission,'' which means Cheney may recommend that Congress revoke the funding approved for earlier projects. A DOD statement said Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood will review construction plans for possible cancellation and submit a proposed list of rescissions to Cheney by June 1. Cheney said that if those lawmakers who are advocating slashing $20 billion from President Bush's $306.9 billion request for budget authority get their way, more than 207 projects would have to be canceled. Cheney said he took the action because the freeze ran out Monday night, not because the House had scheduled a vote on a Budget Committee proposal to reduce Bush's defense budget request. On Capitol Hill, Schroeder and Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., introduced legislation that would close the home port on Staten Island and freeze funds for construction at five other home ports in Everett, Wash.; Ingleside, Texas; Pascagoula, Miss.; Mobile, Ala.; and Pensacola, Fla. The ports in Everett and Pensacola weren't included in Cheney's review because they are nearly completed, Pentagon officials said. The GAO, in testimony last month before the House Armed Services subcommittee on seapower and strategic and critical materials that Bennett chairs, recommended freezing spending on new home ports until the Navy decides what it needs. At the hearing, New York Mayor David Dinkins said his city does not want the home port and cannot afford it. Eleven of the 14-member New York City congressional delegation and 16 members of the New York City Council also opposed the project.

DOC.HEAD: Five-Year Economic War Against Nicaragua Cost $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave Congress the final report Tuesday on the now-lifted U.S. sanctions against Nicaragua, calculating down to the last penny how much it cost to wage economic war against Managua's former leftist government. Bush said it cost taxpayers exactly $1,309,783.48 for salaries for personnel at the Departments of State and Treasury and the National Security Council who administered a state of national emergency against Nicaragua from May 1, 1985 through March 13, 1990. The national emergency was declared by then-President Ronald Reagan, who imposed tough economic sanctions against Nicaragua, including a ban on all U.S. imports to Managua and exports from there. The action helped cripple the country's economy and spawn dissatisfaction with the regime of Daniel Ortega. Bush removed the sanctions and lifted the declaration of national emergency on March 13 following the upset victory of U.S.-backed candidate Violeta Chamorro in presidential balloting. Bush said her election ``ended the unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States previously posed by the policies and actions of the Sandinista government'' headed by Ortega.

DOC.HEAD: Court Gives State Reprieve in School Finance Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: A state judge on Tuesday gave Texas until June to enact a plan to overhaul the financing of its poorer schools _ or have a plan written for it. The 30-day reprieve by District Judge Scott McCown freed $500 million in state aid to schools in May and guarantees schools will stay open through the school year. But McCown said time is running out. He said the state must help the property-poor school districts that challenged the current $13.5 billion a year system as unfair and won a 9-0 ruling from the Texas Supreme Court. ``The present scheme of public school finance is a great wrong. ... The poor have waited for too long,'' McCown said as he extended the state Supreme Court's May 1 deadline for action until June 1. State Education Commissioner William Kirby said the ruling gives the Legislature and the governor ``one last opportunity to get together'' and come up with a plan. Kirby said he feared another legislative failure would lead to a court-written plan. ``I don't think the court has the ability to put additional revenue into the system,'' Kirby said. ``There's no question that we're looking at Robin Hood _ you're really talking about taking from the rich, giving to the poor.'' Lawmakers and Gov. Bill Clements failed in the second attempt to overhaul the current system. The lawmakers proposed a half-cent sales tax increase to finance the overhaul; and Clements plans to veto it. The Legislature's second, 30-day special session on education ended Tuesday. Clements immediately called another session to convene Wednesday afternoon. The Democratic-controlled Legislature approved a $555 million reform plan. To pay for it, they proposed $114 million in budget cuts and raising the state sales tax from 6 cents to 6{ cents on the dollar. Clements, a Republican, said money should be taken from other state programs to fund school finance reform. Since the state failed to enact a new school system, McCown could have stopped state payments to schools on Tuesday. Instead, he extended the deadline. Should Clements and lawmakers fail a third time, McCown also issued a complex set of instructions that guarantee that a new system of school finance is operating by Sept. 1. Those instructions included: _ Appointment by the judge of a special master who will begin work this month on a finance plan of his own. _ A requirement that the judge approve any state spending for schools after June 1 if no reform plan has been approved by Clements and the Legislature. _ A June 25 judicial review of either the state's plan or the special master's plan. After McCown's ruling, Clements said he was more confident than ever that budget cuts, not a tax increase, will be used to pay for the plan. ``I think the legislators have a different view of the situation than they did before, because they know they can't override my veto,'' Clements said. But some lawmakers sharply criticized the governor, who is retiring. Sen. Carl Parker said Clements was passing the buck so he can leave office at the end of the year without approving a tax increase. ``It passes the real buck, the out-of-pocket buck, to the local taxpayer. Because what we don't spend at the state level right now will come out of the hides of the homeowners and small business owners,'' said Parker, chairman of the Senate Education Committee. Texas, with 1,100 school districts, is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems deemed unfair to poor districts. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Demonstrate to Demand Removal of U.S. Bases
With AM-World May Day-Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people rallied nationwide Tuesday to demand the removal of U.S. military bases, and more than 30 people were injured and scores arrested in clashes with police. The protests, organized by the leftist May First Movement, were the most extensive against the U.S. bases since President Corazon Aquino took power in a popular uprising that ousted President Ferdinand Marcos in 1985. The largest gathering was near the U.S. Embassy in Manila and attracted 50,000 protesters. ``There will be no peace and democracy in the country as long as the U.S. bases are here,'' Crispin Beltran, the movement's chairman, told the cheering crowd. After the rally, police blocked about 4,000 protesters who tried to march on the embassy to serve a ``notice of termination'' for the bases. Manila Mayor Mel Lopez defused the situation by persuading protest leaders to allow him to deliver the eviction notice. Two people were arrested before Lopez intervened. Opposition to the bases has been growing because many Filipinos view them as an infringement on national sovereignty. Mrs. Aquino says she has not yet decided whether to support extending the lease after it expires in September 1991. U.S. and Filipino negotiators will begin talks May 14 on extending the lease on the bases. In Angeles, 50 miles north of Manila, Filipino troops charged into a crowd of nearly 5,000 protesters who tried to enter the gate at Clark Air Base to deliver a termination notice. Protesters hurled stones at the troops who charged with truncheons. Witnesses said troops beat dozens of reporters, protesters and bystanders and at least 10 people were hospitalized for injuries. In Tacloban, 360 miles southeast of Manila, police fired water cannons at about 1,000 workers, students and other protesters. Police said 20 protesters and one policeman were injured and eight people arrested. In Cebu, 350 miles southeast of Manila, about 2,000 militants marched on the U.S. Consulate, where they burned and stomped on an American flag after hurling tomatoes at it. In Iloilo, 290 miles south of the capital, about 800 militant workers marched, denouncing Mrs. Aquino as a ``puppet of the Americans'' and demanding her resignation. Five people were arrested in the demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Official Shows No Interest In `Food Truce'
DOC.TEXT: The head of Ethiopia's relief agency showed no interest in a military truce that would allow food supplies to reach starving people in his country, according to a congressman who met with him Tuesday. Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of a congressional hunger committee, said he was disappointed by his meeting with Yilima Kassaye, head of Ethiopia's relief and rehabilitation committee. ``I got the impression they care very little about their own people,'' Hall said in an interview. ``It was not a good report. ... Clearly they put military victory above saving the lives of people.'' Kassaye told Hall the Soviet-backed Ethiopian government initiated air raids on the port of Massawa, where food supplies have been blocked after rebels captured the city on Feb. 11. The rebel Eritrean People's Liberation Front has been fighting for independence from Ethiopia for 29 eyars. A series of seemingly random attacks on Massawa by the Ethiopian air force began April 4. Hall said he proposed to Kassaye that there be a ``food truce'' for three weeks so relief agencies to bring food to starving people in the north. Kassaye responded, in essence, that there was ``no wiggle room to get food through the port.'' ``It was not a good report,'' Hall said.

DOC.HEAD: List Sentenced to Five Consecutive Life Terms For 1971 Family Killings
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday rejected John E. List's plea for forgiveness, and ordered the former Sunday school teacher imprisoned for life, saying the voices of his slaughtered family were demanding justice. ``For what he did to his wife, his mother, his daughter, his two sons and for how he traumatized an entire community, (the) defendant should have no hope of breathing the free air that graces the lives of law abiding citizens,'' said Superior Court Judge William Wertheimer. The judge sentenced List, 64, to the maximum five consecutive life sentences. List was convicted April 12 of murdering his wife, Helen, 46; mother Alma, 84; daughter, Patricia, 16; and sons John, 15, and Frederick, 13, in 1971 in their 18-room mansion in Westfield, 25 miles from New York City. ``John Emil List is without remorse and without honor,'' Wertheimer said. ``After 18 years, 5 months and 22 days, it is now time for the voices of Helen, Alma, Patricia, Frederick and John F. List to rise from the grave, for it is the criminal justice system, through its trial courts, that speaks for all victims of crime.'' As the judge left, spectators who packed the courtroom broke into applause. List, who eluded authorities for 18 years before a television show led to his capture in Virginia in June, must serve 14 years and 11 months of each life sentence. There was no death penalty in New Jersey at the time of the killings. ``I wish to inform the court I remain truly sorry for the tragic events of 1971,'' List said in his first public statement on the slayings. ``I feel that because of my mental state at the time, I was unaccountable for what happened. I ask all affected by this for their forgiveness, understanding and prayer.'' Prosecutor Eleanor Clark mocked List's plea for mercy, saying he showed none to his family and did not deserve to see the light of day. ``The state of New Jersey and the citizens of Union County want to say to John E. List that just because you had financial problems, just because your wife was ill and just because your children were adolescents, we do not understand and will not understand what you did,'' she said. Wertheimer agreed, noting that experts in the trial said List still suffers from a compulsive-obsessive personality and might repeat his crimes if he ever returned to the community. Public defender Elijah Miller had argued for concurrent life sentences, saying the murders were a one-time act by a troubled man. He said he would appeal the sentence and conviction. Miller said List was mentally deficient at the time, a product of a strict Lutheran upbringing with the ``values and ethics of the 19th century.'' Because of the former accountant's attention to detail, the bodies remained in the home for almost a full month before they were discovered _ from Nov. 9, 1971, until Dec. 7. Witnesses testified List had written notes excusing the children from school and had the newspaper stopped. He turned down the thermostat to slow decomposition of the bodies, paid all his bills, cashed all his checks and left a note for the milkman telling him he wouldn't be needed for a while. Then he shot his wife over breakfast, his mother in her bed when she asked what the noise was, and then each child as they came home from school. He left a note for his pastor and fled, taking on the alias Robert P. Clark, an accountant first in metropolitan Denver and then near Richmond, Va. He remarried and again became active in his church. His second wife, Delores Clark, has remained out of the public spotlight since his arrest. List was arrested on a tip generated after the television anti-crime show, ``America's Most Wanted,'' re-enacted the slayings.

DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs Aid for Nicaragua, Panama
DOC.TEXT: After a week of delays, the Senate on Tuesday approved a $3.4 billion ``emergency'' spending bill that includes $720 million in aid President Bush wants to help the new democracies in Panama and Nicaragua. The action, on a voice vote, sent the spending package to a conference to work out differences with a $2.4 billion House-passed version. Bush has threatened to veto the measure if negotiators leave intact a Senate provision that would allow the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. Most of the new foreign aid would be offset by cuts in this year's Pentagon budget, representing the first major application of a ``peace dividend'' from reduced East-West tensions. Bush complained again Tuesday about Congress' failure to enact his aid package, saying both the House and Senate had padded the bill with irrelevant pet spending projects and controversial matters. ``None of it related to Nicaragua, none of it related to Panama; all of it related to other priorities they had,'' the president told a group of small business owners at the White House. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara, in a speech at the National Press Club, was more understanding. ``This is the price we pay for democracy,'' he said of the delays. ``It's the best system ... and we want a democracy, (even) with all the delays.'' Endara said his country would use the $420 million in aid to rebuild its battered economy and repair damage from the December U.S. invasion, which installed him in power. But, answering a question, he said Panama will not ask for more U.S. economic aid next year. By using part of the money to pay off past-due loans to international banks, Panama would again become eligible to meet future financial needs through new development loans, he said. Endara strongly defended the U.S. invasion, saying that human rights abuses by former dictator Manuel Noriega justified the intervention. And he harshly criticized members of the Organization of American States, saying ``we were really let down'' when they did not stand up to Noriega. ``They were intimidated by outmoded doctrines of non-intervention. There's a more important principle ... that a nation should be determined by the will of the people,'' Endara said. During the final day of consideration, the Senate adopted a series of amendments adding $5 million to the U.N. Environment Program, $4 million to an education program for gifted and talented students, and $5 million for the Agriculture Department's Food Safety Inspection Service. Senators also voted 73 to 24 for a non-binding provision urging Bush not to send to Congress for approval a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement until Moscow rescinds economic sanctions it has leveled at the independence-minded republic of Lithuania. In addition to the $300 million for Nicaragua and the $70 million for refugee programs Bush had sought, the bill already had become the vehicle for a host of unrelated provisions. Lawmakers added hundreds of millions for disaster relief, fighting forest fires, food stamps, veterans benefits and other domestic programs. The package also included authorization for $400 million in loan guarantees for Israel to build housing for newly arriving Soviet emigres. Before the measure was approved, however, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., raised a series of questions about the housing program, which he said he supported but needed to be justified for taxpayers. He noted that Israel already receives $3 billion a year in direct aid, making it the largest recipient of U.S. largesse, and in addition gets more than $600 million in other ``side benefits.'' Dole asked whether Israel should get a break on fees for the loan guarantees, which would save the Israeli government an estimated $25 million or more over the 30-year life of the loans; whether requirements for eligibility for the housing should be waived, as proposed in the bill; and whether the money also would be used to build roads and parks and pay consultants.

DOC.HEAD: Army Seeking Next of Kin
DOC.TEXT: The Army wants to find the next of kin for six crewmen who died when their B-17 was lost on a 1942 patrol over the Coral Sea, officials said Tuesday. Although the aircraft was found and the crew list confirmed after several research missions to Papua, New Guinea, in 1986 and 1987, relatives of six of the eight crewmen haven't been found, said Shari Lawrence, spokeswoman for the U.S. Total Army Personnel Command. ``The many years since the incident have made the locations difficult,'' she said in a statement. The plane disappeared after leaving from Townsville in Queensland, Australia. The Army believes the crew encountered the enemy because the Battle of the Coral Sea occurred in the days immediately after its disappearance, the statement said. The six unidentified crewmen are: _2nd Lt. Jim Sam Grant, born Jan. 28, 1918. Last known next of kin: father Walter C. Grant, Malvern, Ark., and mother Marian P. Grant, Tuscon, Ariz. _2nd Lt. Robert R. Meyer, Jr., birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin was father Robert R. Meyer, Birmingham, Ala. _Staff Sgt. Elton J. Rose, birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin was wife Gladys Strickland Rose, Coleman, Texas. _Sgt. Joe A. Carter, born May 10, 1910. Last known next of kin was mother Hazel Williams, La Jolla, Calif. _Sgt. Edward L. Hargrove, birthdate unknown. Last known next of kin were wife Evelyn W. Hargrove, Albuquerque, N.M., and grandfather, Manuel E. Flores, El Centro, Calif. _Sgt. Paul Reimer, born June 21, 1918. Last known next of kin was mother Eva Reimer, Reedley, Calif. Anyone with information may call Doug Howard collect at (703) 325-7960 or (703) 325-0811.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms In Southeast, Winter in Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow fell on the mountains of southern Colorado early Tuesday and Wyoming chilled to a record low, and thunderstorms were scattered from the southern Plains across parts of the South. A heavy snow warning was in effect into early Wednesday over the mountains of southern Colorado. A winter storm watch was in effect into Wednesday across higher elevations of northern New Mexico. Snow accumulated up to 2 feet overnight in Colorado's southern foothills and southern mountains, and 6 to 10 inches over the San Luis Valley. Alamosa had 7 inches of snow on the ground and Colorado Springs got 5 inches. At higher elevations, snow cover included 24 inches at Canon City, 26 at Westcliffe, 27 at Penrose, and 38 at Coaldale, the National Weather Service said. Rain was scattered over east-central Colorado, western Kansas and north-central New Mexico. South of the snow belt, wind gusted to more than 50 mph at Albuquerque, N.M., during the morning. Casper, Wyo., cooled to a record low of 19 degrees Tuesday morning. Tuesday's official low for the Lower 48 was 5 degrees at Yellowstone National Park in northwestern Wyoming. Showers and thunderstorms reached from the Texas Panhandle and northwestern Texas across western Oklahoma, the southeastern third of Oklahoma, northeastern Texas, Arkansas, northern Mississippi, northern Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky and southwestern West Virginia. Elsewhere, snow also extended from northeastern Minnesota across northwestern Wisconsin and western and central Upper Michigan. Rain was scattered across northeastern South Dakota. Jacksonville, Fla., reached a record high for the date of 94. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 25 at Colorado Springs to 98 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Backs Increasing Civil OSHA Fines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CORRECT that administration backs partial expansion of criminal penalties sted opposes the entire plan; edits throughout to conform
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration backed a measure Tuesday that would triple civil fines for employers who violate workplace safety laws, but gave only limited support to legislation that creates new criminal offenses. If enacted, the higher civil penalties for Occupational Safety and Health Administration violations would be the first increase in OSHA fines in the agency's 20-year history. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole's call for higher fines was viewed by organized labor supporters as a sign she's committed to worker safety and that the Bush administration is improving OSHA. Organized labor considered the agency neglected under the Reagan administration. It was the first time OSHA has taken a stand on increased penalties. At a Senate hearing on proposed OSHA changes, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, urged assistant labor secretary Gerard Scannell to reconsider the agency's opposition to his plan that creates new felonies for willful violations that result in ``serious bodily injury'' or ``recklessly endanger human life.'' Metzenbaum's plan also increases from six months to 10 years the jail term for willful violations that result in a worker's death. Metzenbaum, chairman of the Senate labor subcommittee, called the current six-month jail term an ``absurdly low'' penalty that sends a message to potential violators. ``It says do not worry _ treat worker deaths and injuries as just another cost of doing business,'' Metzenbaum said. OSHA supports changing the crime for a violation that results in a death from a misdemeanor to a felony, but agency officials believe sentencing should be left to the courts, Scannell said. In addition, OSHA objects to the two new felonies Metzenbaum's measure creates because civil penalties _ which often result in employers' quickly correcting workplace hazards _ are easier to settle than criminal penalties, Scannell said. The creation of two new felonies, he said, would damage the department's ability to get businesses to quickly correct those hazards because more employers would appeal. ``Expansion of the criminal provisions will come at a very high price, not only the price of diminished civil enforcement, but even more tragic, the higher price of delayed'' elimination of the hazards, Scannell said. OSHA also announced support for helping state and local prosecutors in enforcing state criminal statues in relation to workplace injury or deaths. Scannell said OSHA supports a three-fold increase in civil penalties to bring them in line with inflation. Under a plan by Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., the $10,000 fine for knowingly violating OSHA laws would increase to $30,000 while a lesser violation set at $1,000 would increase to $3,000. Business groups testified against the measures to strengthen OSHA laws, saying they were vague and would harm innocent businessmen. ``Decent and respectable employers will have greater exposure to criminal penalties ... than bank robbers, drug dealers and common criminals,'' said Kirk Fordice, president of the Associated General Contractors of America. Fordice complained that the legislation did not address drug use by employees or acknowledge the need for workers to ``be accountable for meeting minimum standards of responsibility.'' An estimated 10,000 workers are killed each year on the job and about 70,000 others are permanently disabled by workplace accidents, according to AFL-CIO figures.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostage Celebrates His Freedom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Reed's daughter saying he had spent time in capitvity with Anderson, Sutherland. Pickup 6th pvs, `They added...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WIE3, FRA5
DOC.TEXT: Frank Reed, malnourished but energetic after his 3{-year ordeal as a hostage in Lebanon, celebrated his freedom Tuesday with a beer, a large steak and a long-awaited reunion with his wife and son. A special State Department team began questioning the 57-year-old educator at the U.S. Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden, hoping for clues about the 16 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon. Six American hostages are still held. Reed, who said he spent much of his captivity blindfolded, is the second American hostage freed since April 22. In Malden, Mass., Reed's daughter said he told her he had been held with American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland but was separated from them about a year ago. Anderson and Sutherland are among the six remaining U.S. hostages in Lebanon. ``He was disturbed that they weren't out. He thought for sure they would have been released,'' said Marilyn Langston, 33. She said Reed called her early Tuesday from the military hospital in West Germany. Mrs. Langston said her father said he lost 60 pounds during his 43 months in captivity. At the hospital, Reed's doctors performed X-rays and blood tests and said the former captive showed no initial signs of serious medical problems. Reed lost ``significant weight and muscle mass from a lack of exercise and a marginal diet,'' the doctors said in a statement. They added Reed is ``weak and tired,'' but ``otherwise feels well and is talking with family and medical staff.'' The hospital said Reed had indicated he did not want to meet with reporters Tuesday. Reed was reunited at the hospital Tuesday morning with his Syrian Moslem wife, Fahima, 39, and their 9-year-old son, Tarek, who had arrived from the United States, where they had been staying in his hometown of Malden, Mass. Military officials said Reed's wife and son went on a quick shopping tour to buy new clothes for him at the nearby U.S. Lindsey Air Base. Reed displayed a healthy appetite and a strong thirst for beer, according to the hospital staff. For lunch, Reed requested a ``Heineken (beer) and a large steak cooked medium rare,'' and the freed hostage ``got what he asked for,'' the hospital statement said. He spent the afternoon sleeping and was to have dinner with his family, hospital officials said. In Washington, President Bush called Reed's release ``joyous news,'' but said he wouldn't be satisifed until all the remaining hostages are freed. Bush, who met at the White House Tuesday with Democratic and Republican leaders, praised Syria and Iran for exerting pressure on the Shiite Moslem fundamentalist hostage-takers. But the president also prodded the two countries to work for the release of more hostages, emphasizing they should not expect normal relations or ``vast improvement until all Americans are freed.'' ``When a step is taken that goes toward that day when all hostages are released, I should say thank you,'' Bush said. ``But beyond that, I can't say that I can be happy.'' Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Bush said he would not object if Israel were to release Shiite prisoners as the Lebanese hostage-takers have demanded. Israeli officials, reacting to the indirect U.S. appeal, insisted that Israel wanted three Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon in 1986 to be part of any deal. The three are believed held by radical Shiites linked to the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia. A leading Iranian newspaper, the Tehran Times, said Tuesday that Iran's leaders expect a reciprocal gesture of good will from Washington if another U.S. hostage is to be freed. The newspaper said Iran and the Lebanese militants expect Washington and its allies to pressure Israel into releasing ``a significant number of detainees,'' specifically Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, a Shiite cleric abducted by Israel in southern Lebanon in July. Bush met Monday with former hostage Robert Polhill, who was freed on April 22. The president said Polhill had given him a secret message from his captors, but refused to disclose its contents. Reed's kidnappers, who called themselves the Organization of the Islamic Dawn, announced before Reed's release that he would be carrying a message to President Bush. Reed, who had been principal of a private school in Beirut since 1977, refused to comment on any message. He was kidnapped Sept. 9, 1986. He was released Monday night into Syrian hands in west Beirut and then escorted to Damascus, just as Polhill was last week. Reed blew kisses, flashed a ``V'' for victory sign to well-wishers and touched the ground in undisguised elation after arriving in brilliant, sunny weather Tuesday at Rhein-Main Air Base from Syria on a U.S. Air Force C-141 transport plane. He was then flown by Army helicopter to the hospital in nearby Wiesbaden. Reed, still bearded and wearing a dark suit and white shirt, walked with relatively brisk steps from the helicopter, smiling broadly. He gave a thumbs-up to reporters and about 170 military and medical personnel waiting for him at the hospital. Banners draped over the hospital balconies proclaimed ``Welcome Back to the Free World'' and ``Welcome Home, Mr. Reed.'' At the hospital, Reed was provided with a new pair of reading glasses, officials said. After his release, Reed said that during his ``lonely and boring'' captivity he had been shut off from news of the outside world and sometimes ``didn't even know what month it was.'' Officials said Reed would probably remain at the hospital for the next two to three days before returning to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Report Links Agent Orange to Cancer, Other Diseases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, `About 35,000 ...,' to CLARIFY that those deal with all illnesses, not just non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `About 240,000 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Three kinds of cancer and five other diseases among Vietnam veterans can be traced to exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange, according to a scientific report released Tuesday by veterans groups. The report, released on the eve of a congressional hearing on a bill to pay benefits to Agent Orange victims, produced no new evidence. Rather, it reviewed existing studies. Lawmakers pushing the benefits praised the study by the Agent Orange Task Force, seven scientists assembled by the American Legion, Vietnam Veterans of America and the National Veterans Legal Services Program. ``It is not only appropriate but it is scientifically correct'' to award compensation to Vietnam veterans exposed to the dioxin-containing defoliant, said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., a Vietnam veteran and sponsor of Senate legislation to award compensation. The report said proof exists of a ``significant statistical association'' between herbicide exposure and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma; soft-tissue sarcoma; chloracne and other skin disorders; early liver disease; and porphyria cutanea tarda, a metabolic disorder. The scientists also said there was enough evidence to give the benefit of the doubt in awarding compensation to veterans who were exposed and suffer from Hodgkin's disease, neurologic and reproductive problems and developmental problems with their offspring. They say there's limited evidence of an association between exposure and a large number of cancers, as well as immunological abnormalities and psychological problems. A Senate bill has been passed and a House bill introduced to provide benefits to veterans who claim their diseases were a result of exposure. The bills differ in cost _ $36 million for the Senate version and $89 million for the House version _ length of coverage and number of diseases covered. A Veterans Affairs subcommittee was scheduled to hear testimony Wednesday on the House bill sponsored by Rep. Lane Evans, D-Ill., a co-chairman of the Vietnam-Era Veterans in Congress. Both bills would create an independent panel of scientists under the auspices of the independent National Academy of Sciences to review herbicide studies. Critics say the government has intentionally tried to influence the evidence on Agent Orange to avoid paying benefits. VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski has decided to award benefits to non-Hodgkin's lymphoma sufferers who served in Vietnam. That decision was made March 29 as the result of a study by the Centers for Disease Control. About 35,000 veterans have filed claims asserting a connection between exposure and a variety of ailments. Only a handful _ those for chloracne _ have been granted. About 240,000 veterans believe they may have been exposed to the herbicide and have requested physical examinations, VA says. A total of 12 million gallons of Agent Orange was sprayed during the war to remove ground cover and crops. Agent Orange is a phenoxyacetic herbicide contaminated with dioxin during manufacture. Dioxin is the main disease-causing suspect. The Environmental Protection Agency has labeled dioxin a ``probable human carcinogen.'' The scientists on the panel say an influential private study of Nitro, W.Va., Monsanto workers exposed to dioxin has been discredited because of allegations of scientific fraud. So has an important study of industrial workers in Ludwigshafen, West Germany, they said. The scientists were especially critical of the VA and CDC for ignoring animal studies, especially because agencies such as the EPA gives them such strong consideration. VA scientists say the animal dioxin studies are less reliable because of the variety of reactions from species to species, and because there is documented human exposure, said VA spokeswoman Donna St. John. The two bills cover only a few of the ailments: non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, soft-tissue sarcoma, melanoma and chloracne. The House version adds melanoma and basal cell carcinoma. Oliver Meadows, the chairman of the VA's outside Environmental Hazards Advisory Committee, dismissed criticism in the new report that it ignored a large number of studies and that it used a ``simplistic tallying system'' to weigh data. The panel has only examined the connection between Agent Orange and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The new report covers all the possible ailments. The panel found in November that an association cannot be proved or disproved. The VA panel meets later this month to consider other cancer studies. The CDC study of six kinds kinds of cancer found an increased risk of only one _ non-Hodgkin's lymphoma _ among Vietnam veterans. It found no such increase in soft tissue sarcoma, Hodgkin's disease, and nasal, nasopharyngeal and primary liver cancer. The study looked only indirectly at Agent Orange exposure.

DOC.HEAD: Mounted Police Battle May Day Marchers in Mexico City
With AM-World May Day, Bjt
LaserPhoto MO1
DOC.TEXT: Riot police on horseback and on foot charged a May Day march near the center of Mexico City with clubs swinging, leaving several demonstrators bleeding with head wounds. The marchers represented a group of independent unions headed for the main plaza, or Zocalo, as a larger demonstration by pro-government unions was dispersing. Police held up the march, apparently waiting for the other groups to leave, then charged. It was not clear what set off the attack, during which some marchers hurled bricks and rocks at police. The procession later left for the plaza as demonstrators carried away the wounded. The number of injured was not immediately clear. The Mexican government news agency Notimex said three policemen and four journalists, mostly Mexican photographers, were injured but Associated Press reporters saw several others who had been beaten. In the plaza, the marchers hauled down from a building a huge banner from a pro-government labor group and set it afire. At least three major labor groups declined to join the official rally of the Mexican Labor Federation in the Zocalo. Several independent unions held separate marches to the plaza. Among the chants shouted was ``Aware worker, don't give up, don't sell out!'' Ranks of members of pro-government unions had marched around the huge square past the National Palace to greet the President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, then marched out. Unofficial estimates put the number of marchers at around 200,000. Some in the Mexican Labor Federation demonstration said they had to attend. ``It is forced,'' said a worker from an automobile brake plant, who demanded anonymity. ``If you don't go they will discount two days from your salary.'' About 10,000 other marchers from non-government-aligned unions headed for the Zocalo as the Mexican Labor Federation demonstration dispersed. Two groups marched past the U.S. Embassy shouting ``Gringo thieves, to the firing squad!'' ``We are hungry'' read a banner carried by workers in the Treasury Department. The Mexican Electrical Workers' Union said it would not take part in the CTM rally because it did not want to risk incidents ``resulting from the unrest there is among the workers,'' the weekly Proceso said Monday. The Revolutionary Workers' Federation was boycotting to protest what it said were low wages. The teachers' union, Mexico's largest, said it would stay home, but a dissident movement that claims support of about half the more than 1 million members called one of the three separate demonstrations. Behind the demonstrations walked 10 city sanitation workers with brooms and bright orange uniforms. One of them, Domingo Rendon, sighed, ``The day of the worker means more work for us.'' For decades, Fidel Velazquez, the 90-year-old head of the Mexican Labor Federation and a stalwart of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, defused labor unrest and turned out the vote for the party. With national economic crisis, workers have lost ground and with it patience with their leaders and the system. The labor federation has at various times claimed a membership of as many as 5 million. Labor analysts estimate it at about half of that.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Would Forgive Billions in Food Aid Debt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration wants to forgive some of the $11.7 billion owed by more than 70 countries for U.S. food aid, officials told Congress Tuesday. It has still to decide how much would be forgiven and which countries would benefit. William C. Ramsay, deputy assistant secretary of state for energy, resources and food policy, said they would be the poorest countries, if they have promised the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund to undertake new policies. The last requirement would exclude Egypt, for example, which owes the most, $2.6 billion. Egypt has been negotiating with the fund for years, but has so far found its terms too difficult. South Korea, which still owes over $600 million, is too well off for debt forgiveness, according to an official of the U.S. Agency for International Development. Most of the beneficiaries would be African countries, to which Bush has already promised forgiveness of $1 billion worth of other debt. Ramsay said poor countries outside Africa, such as Bangladesh and Haiti, may also win forgiveness of the food debt. Bangladesh owes over $1 billion for food aid, as do Indonesia and Pakistan. Ramsay also asked for authority to make more grants of food aid instead of loans on generous terms. ``Many countries in urgent need of food aid have such large debt service burdens and weak economies that they can no longer afford even these generous terms,'' he said. Ramsay testified before the subcommittee on international economic policy of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, which is considering bills that would allow the debt forgiveness envisioned by Ramsay. The chairman of the subcommittee, Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn, said he was sympathetic to the administration's plans for debt forgiveness,

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Advance Team Member Accused of Sexual Assault
DOC.TEXT: A member of Vice President Dan Quayle's advance team has been accused of sexually assaulting a Baylor University student, and Quayle's press secretary said Tuesday the man has been relieved of his duties. Police said Tuesday no warrant has been issued and the man has not been charged with a crime. The 18-year-old student was uncertain whether she wanted to press charges, police said. Waco policeman Lionel McGee said the woman, a freshman, told police Sunday that the man raped her in his hotel room. The man said he had sex with the woman but that she consented, according to a police report. Waco lawyer Charles McDonald, who has been retained by the man, said his client is innocent. ``Nothing has been shown that would justify the complaint,'' he said. A statement issued Tuesday by Quayle's press secretary, David Beckwith, said the man would retain his consulting position with the Republican National Committee pending an investigation but volunteered to step down from his duties planning an upcoming trip to Texas by Quayle. ``This is a most deplorable incident. We extend our sympathy to the young lady, her friends and her family,'' the statement said. ``We are asking the local authorities to show no favoritism and to deal with this according to their standard procedures.'' The man has had a consulting agreement with the Republican National Committee since April 23, said committee press secretary Leslie Goodman. His work at the RNC involves special projects, including political trips for candidates. Quayle is scheduled to visit Waco on Wednesday for a private fund-raiser to benefit state Rep. Hugh Shine, a GOP nominee for Congress. Prosecutor Ralph Strother of the McLennan County district attorney's office said Tuesday that without the woman's cooperation, there would be little prospect of prosecuting the man. ``I cannot tell you at this point whether there will be any formal charges filed,'' Strother said.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE BUDGET ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Government Offers to Meet Parties Threatening Election Boycott
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto BEL1, LaserColor BEL2
DOC.TEXT: The government Tuesday offered to meet opposition parties threatening to boycott Romania's first free elctions in more than 50 years. The move follows the accusation by five major opposition parties that the National Salvation Front, which dominates the provisional governing coalition, is monopolizing power. The opposition parties on Monday threatened to boycott the May 20 elections. The government offer also comes as a round-the-clock anti-government protest in Bucharest entered its 10th day. The goverment said claims that the National Salvation Front was harassing opposition activists and using facilities left by the deposed Communist Party ``can be discussed with representatives of the government to eliminate any kind of suspicions and to ... improve some organizational aspects'' of the elections. The statement said the goverment would guarantee ``the equality of chances from a technical point of view'' for all parties contesting the election. The five opposition parties that are threatening to boycott the elections are the National Peasants' Party, the National Liberal Party, the Social Democrat Party, the Free Democrat Party and the Socialist Liberal Party. There was no immediate response from the parties to the goverment statement. In Bucharest 8,000 protesters gathered in downtown University Square to protest against the government of interim President Ion Iliescu, which they claim favors preserving Communism. Iliescu is a former Communist official who became a critic of Ceausescu's in recent years. Organizers of the anti-Communist protest said they have collected 4 million signatures for a petition to exclude all former Communists from politics and government. There was no way to independently verify their claim. The National Salvation Front began ruling as an interim government shortly after the December revolution that deposed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It then brought in opposition figures to form a coalition government but remained the dominant force. On Tuesday, the crowed stood singing and chanting under a giant banner that read, ``Iliescu _ go back to where you came from.'' Twenty-one people said they had started a fast to enforce the rally's demands. Nicolae Trifu, a bank official from Ploeisti, 30 miles north of Bucharest, said the government should end its control of the state-run network. ``Television should no longer be subordinated to the government and to Iliescu in particular,'' he told the crowd. His comments were greeted with a sea of ``V'' for victory signs and chants of ``Resign, Resign'' and ``Down with Iliescu.'' Opposition parties have long complained that the National Salvation Front has an unfair advantage in the elections because of its domination of the television network. Reporters in the western city of Timisoara, where the revolution began, said about 1,000 anti-Iliescu demonstrators assembled Tuesday for a protest. There were no other details.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 8 p.m. EDT; Time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Darman Warns Against Centralized Economy For Environmentalism
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of a centralized, command-and-control economy, hiding behind the ``green mask'' of environmentalism, are threatening to undermine Americans' self confidence and pioneering spirit, Budget Director Richard Darman warned Tuesday. Even though the conflict between Western democracies and Communist bloc nations is in decline, different economic ideologies _ both labeled environmentalism _ will continue to compete for dominance, Darman said in a speech at Harvard University, a text of which was released in Washington. He identified two kinds of environmentalism _ ``pro-growth, market-oriented, pluralistic environmentalism'' and ``anti-growth, command-and-control, centralistic enviromentalism.'' ``Because so many people are self-proclaimed `environmentalists,' the label is no longer a meaningful characteristic. It is a green mask under which different faces of politico-economic ideology can hide,'' he added. The budget director said Americans ``must counter the tendency to become a risk-o-phobic society'' because prudent risk-taking is central to the U.S. spirit and standard of living. ``If we were to regulate houses with the same principles we now apply to our food and air, for example, we would all have to live in single-story homes _ for fear of falling down stairs,'' he said. Darman, along with White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, are viewed as the two senior White House aides most skeptical of strengthening regulation of the environment and have argued in support of toning down presidental statements on global warming and other environmental problems.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Boundaries For Gettysburg National Military Park
DOC.TEXT: The House approved legislation Tuesday that establishes boundaries for the Gettysburg National Military Park, where President Lincoln delivered his historic address and the Union and Confederate armies fought a key battle of the Civil War. By voice vote, the House adopted the bill that allows the Interior Department to acquire land and interests in land within the established boundaries by purchase, donation, exchange or other means. The park, which was transferred from the War Department to the National Park Service in 1933, includes approximately 3,900 acres of Pennsylvania land, including about 3,700 that are owned by the federal government. The bill also establishes an 11-member advisory commission to join with local jurisdictions in managing the park and the Gettysburg Battlefield Historic District. The measure also calls on the Interior Department to take steps that encourage conservation of the park. The House Interior Committee said the bill will result in only a minimal increase in federal spending. It did not provide specifics.

DOC.HEAD: Metzenbaum Says S&L Deals Should Be Renegotiated
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS penultimate graf with 2 new grafs of First Gibraltar response
DOC.TEXT: The purchasers in the biggest savings and loan bailout of 1988 are enjoying millions of dollars of risk-free profits and regulators should renegotiate the deal, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum said Tuesday. The Ohio Democrat said a Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas memo obtained by his Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust shows taxpayers likely would have been better off if regulators liquidated First Gibraltar Bank of Houston rather than bailing it out in December 1988. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, then the chief regulator of thrift institutions, estimated it would have cost $5 billion to shut down the five bankrupt thrifts that were combined to form First Gibraltar. However, a memo prepared in February 1989 by analyst Jeff Potter in Dallas said the liquidation cost was ``grossly overstated'' by about $1.6 billion, Metzenbaum said, indicating the sale may have been unnecessary. Instead of liquidating, the bank board pledged $5 billion in future aid and $1.2 billion in tax benefits to New York financier and Revlon chairman Ronald O. Perelman and other investors, who put up $315 million. Including the tax benefits, First Gibraltar, now the largest thrift in Texas and among the 20 largest in the nation, enjoyed the best return on investment of any thrift in the nation last year, according to Metzenbaum's aides. It received $461 million in federal assistance in 1989, enabling it to post a profit of $129 million, the senator said. ``These overly generous payments are government guarantees that give little incentive to manage the assets of the S&L profitably. They also suggest that the government ... drove a very poor bargain for taxpayers,'' Metzenbaum said in a letter to L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., which has assumed responsibility for reviewing the 1988 bailouts. Metzenbaum said the findings of his staff, which reviewed 35,000 documents related to the 1988 deals, ``dramatically underscore'' the need to renegotiate the First Gibraltar sale and other transactions. ``Our investigation has found evidence that bidding on several ... deals was irregular and done in haste. Billions in federal subsidies and thrift assets were juggled in a rush to close as many deals as possible before the end of 1988,'' he wrote. First Gibraltar Chairman Gerald J. Ford defended his institution's deal with the government, saying it was concluded after a ``vigorous and highly competitive auction.'' He said his S&L has restored stability and depositor confidence to the Texas thrift industry through ``a forward-looking program of assets management, branch consolidation and operating efficiencies.'' Federal regulators, at the time of the 1988 deals, defended the transactions as the best they could do. Because they lacked the cash to pay off depositors, they were forced to keep insolvent institutions afloat by pledging future assistance, they said.

DOC.HEAD: 10,500 Soviets Immigrate To Israel In April
DOC.TEXT: About 10,500 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel in April, the largest monthly figure since the start of a mass Soviet immigration to the Jewish state last year, an official said Tuesday. It was the first time Israel published a figure for Soviet arrivals since early March, when such statistics were censored in response to Arab guerrilla threats to attack immigrants. Gad Ben Ari, the spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which is partly responsible for resettling the immigrants, said 10,500 arrived in April. He added Israel's goal is ``to bring the maximum amount of people in the minimum amount of time.'' Before April, the monthly immigration figure for Soviet Jews was between 4,000 and 6,000, Israeli and foreign reports said. In 1989, 12,000 Soviets settled in Israel, and in 1988 only 2,000 arrived. The relaxation in the censorship of immigration statistics appears to be a result of pressure from overseas fundraisers, particularly those in the United States. Fundraisers say they need the immigration figures in their drives to raise money to absorb the newcomers. Israeli officials estimate up to 300,000 Soviet Jews will emigrate to Israel in the next few years. The influx comes because of a loosening of immigration procedures in the Soviet Union and tighter restrictions on U.S. immigration.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Gabor Gets 60 Extra Hours of Community Service
LaserPhoto LA2
DOC.TEXT: An angry judge ordered Zsa Zsa Gabor to perform 60 extra hours of community service Tuesday, saying fund raising at her Bel-Air mansion was not the way to serve time for slapping a policeman. ``If there is any violation of probation, County Jail will be the sanction,'' warned Municipal Court Judge Charles Rubin. He asked Miss Gabor if she accepted his decision. ``Yes, what can I do?'' Miss Gabor said. ``You could go to jail. Do you want that?'' the judge shot back. ``Yes, I accept,'' Miss Gabor said, referring to the community service hours. ``It's outrageous,'' the former Hungarian beauty queen later told about 80 reporters. Miss Gabor, 72, was sentenced last year to 120 hours of community service on her conviction of slapping a Beverly Hills motorcycle policeman who stopped her Rolls-Royce last June for expired registration tags. Rubin originally ordered her to do the service at the Lower Income Elderly United Community Assistance Program in Venice, with the time to be completed by March 30. Rubin ordered Tuesday's hearing after he received a sparse account from the shelter's executive director, Vera Davis, about how Miss Gabor spent her time.
