Davis said Miss Gabor spent about 50 hours at the shelter and the rest of the time working from her Bel-Air mansion, organizing a June 8 fund-raiser for the shelter. ``It's clear to me the defendant had a rather lax attitude about it,'' Rubin said. ``(It) means nothing to Miss Gabor, buying community service hours. She is a wealthy person,'' Rubin said after meeting with Miss Gabor and her attorney, Harrison Bull for 3{ hours. ``The primary motive was Miss Gabor's promotion, and not fund raising. ``I repeated numerous times (at the original sentencing) that she perform community service at the center.'' Miss Gabor later told reporters: ``I served food. Why do I have to promote myself? I'm so damned famous it's sickening.'' Rubin gave Miss Gabor credit for 34{ hours of community service time from her 120-hour sentence. He ordered her to serve the remaining 85{ hours, plus 60 penalty hours. ``Miss Gabor must now document her community service time and there will be random, in-person verification,'' the judge said. The remaining 145{ hours must be completed by Sept. 28 and the hours will be served at several agencies. ``You may not do any fund raising'' as a part of the community service, the judge ordered. ``I don't have any qualms with Miss Gabor's assistance and fund raising,'' said Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox, but ``there is an aspect of humility that goes along with this.'' He said community service usually includes handling telephones or serving food.

DOC.BYLINE: Group Wants Commitment to Math ^By TAMARA HENRY
DOC.TEXT: Millions of students interested in mathematics have dropped out for other careers, a National Research Council report said Tuesday in calling for renewed commitment to math education. ``The attrition rate for students in the mathematical sciences is 50 percent per year, the highest among all scientific fields,'' said the report, ``Renewing U.S. Mathematics: Critical Resources for the Future.'' ``Bright young people are discouraged from pursuing careers in the mathematical sciences because they find their career prospects are dim.'' The report said there were about 3.6 million ninth grade mathematics students in 1972. By the time they entered college as freshmen in 1976, the number had dropped to 294,000. In 1980 11,000 won bachelor's degrees in mathematics; two years later 2,700 master's degrees were awarded and 400 doctorates were bestowed in 1986. ``Professors must show students that the mathematical sciences offer both intellectual excitement and attractive career prospects,'' said the report. ``Providing intellectual excitement is the responsibility of the mathematical sciences community. ``To perceive attractive career prospects, students must see in their own mathematics departments active, successful research enterprises that involve graduate students, young faculty, and senior researchers, all supported at levels competitive with those in the other sciences and engineering.'' A key recommendation of the report is that federal support of mathematics education increase to $250 million annually from $133 million over the next three years. The report is a follow up to a 1984 study which called for $180 million a year. The committee that produced the report said that inflation had pushed that amount to $225 million. The money should be used mostly to increase the numbers of senior, junior and postdoctoral researchers and graduate research assistants, the committee said. Edward David Jr., chairman of both the 1984 and the present study committee, said that ``I think we would be much closer'' to realizing the goal of President Bush and the nation's governors of becoming first in math and science if all of the 1984 suggestions had been carried out. ``The chances are very good'' that the new report will be fully supported ``because of the attitude of the president, Congress and the governors,'' said David. ``We got everybody on our side and chances are very good.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Premier Says Cities of Moscow, Leningrad Will Help Republic
With AM-US-Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said Tuesday that the cities of Moscow and Leningrad have agreed to help Lithuania ease the pressure of the Soviet Union's economic embargo on the rebellious republic. She did not say what practical help was offered, but the Baltic republic of 3.8 million people sent a delegation to Leningrad last week to talk with local officials about a direct exchange of goods either for hard currency or barter. Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters outside the Ontario legislature that reform municipal councils in Leningrad, Moscow and elsewhere in the Soviet Union offered to assist Lithuania because they rely on it for food supplies. ``Because of the Kremlin's blockade we have taken the intiative for direct contact with these cities,'' she through an interpreter. ``These people think the way we do and we consider them our friends. Not only do they support our independence initiatives but they also want to cooperate with us in practical terms because they receive many of their food supplies from us.'' Mrs. Prunskiene is in Canada as part of a North American swing to ask for more economic ties with her republic. She is to meet Thursday with President Bush at the White House. Lithuania has struggled for two weeks since the Soviets cut supplies of fuel, medicine and other goods following Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. The Kremlin does not recognize the declaration, saying Lithuania must follow Soviet law on secession. Lithuania was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. Mrs. Prunskiene said she is confident Lithuania will get help from other Soviet republics and regions. ``The only way that this could be prevented or stopped would be by armed intervention, but it is very doubtful whether any nation can solve its economic problems with the use of force,'' she said at a luncheon of Ontario government officials, with Ontario Prime Minister David Peterson. Mrs. Prunskiene said she is in Canada with a trade delegation seeking to establish closer economic ties, not to look for charity. Peterson said the province will likely send a trade delegation to Lithuania this year. On Monday in Ottawa, Mrs. Prunskiene said her government is prepared to suspend some items in its independence declaration to open negotiations with the Soviet Union. She made clear on Tuesday that Lithuania will not sacrifice its goal of independence. ``The act of independence ... is untouchable,'' she said. Since Lithuania declared its independence, Canada has urged negotiations and dialogue between the two sides. Mrs. Prunskiene returns to Lithuania on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Allows Videotaped Testimony From Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fransico in 6th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said Tuesday he would allow sworn videotaped statements from two key defense witnesses in the Philippines to be introduced at Imelda Marcos' fraud trial. Mrs. Marcos' attorneys say one of the witnesses, Orlando Dulay, will testify that he was present when Ferdinand Marcos recovered a hoard of gold known as the Yamashita treasure, and that he helped transport the gold to Marcos' home. The Yamashita treasure was a huge cache of gold supposed to have been hidden in the Philippines by Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, the Japanese military commander stationed there in the closing days of World War II. Marcos, who died in exile in Hawaii last September, claimed that the gold was the primary source of his wealth. No evidence of the gold has ever been found. ``Proof of this serendipitous discovery would be offered to refute the government's contention that Marcos amassed his wealth through systematic plundering of the Philippine treasury,'' U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan said in a written ruling. The judge also approved the taking of a deposition from Fransico Tantuico, who was in charge of the Philippine Audit Organization between 1976 and 1986. Tantuico will testify that reports prepared by his department disprove allegations of corruption by the Marcoses. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband loot the Philippine treasury of more than $220 million to buy New York properties and support lavish living. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with helping the Marcoses conceal their ownership of four New York buildings and artworks purchased with the allegedly stolen funds. Keenan said lawyers for Mrs. Marcos can interview the witnesses in the Philippines during the second week of June, when the trial will be in recess. The videotaped statements will then be shown to jurors. The judge denied a motion to allow Mrs. Marcos to go to the Philippines with her attorneys. He also ruled against allowing her lawyers to interview President Corazon Aquino, who ousted Marcos, and numerous other potential defense witnesses. Keenan said defense claims that the U.S. and Philippine governments were ``hectoring'' and intimidating potential defense witnesses in the Philippines ``appear exaggerated.'' The Aquino government has refused to let Mrs. Marcos return since she and her husband left the country after Marcos' defeat as president in February 1986. Testimony Tuesday focused on the alleged embezzlement of funds in the Philippines. One witness said the chief of the agency that handled Japanese war reparations to the Philippines took ``commissions'' that were deposited into Swiss bank accounts held by Marcos. Andres Genito, a former employee of two Japanese trading companies, said he made the payments to Gen. Eugenio Balao, a close Marcos associate who was in charge of the War Reparations Commission from 1966 until it expired in the mid 1970s. ``I jokingly told him, General Balao, that this is a large sum of money. Is it for you? He said, `Are you kidding, this goes to President Marcos,''' said Genito, who now owns a liquor store in Los Angeles. The witness testified that he accompanied Balao on numerous occasions to Hong Kong, where the general converted the commissions from Japanese yen to U.S. dollars. Genito said Balao told him he deposited the money into Swiss accounts held by Marcos. Genito said he made the payments during all the years Balao served on the reparations commission, but he did not say how much money was involved.

DOC.HEAD: Threatening Letters Sent To Ex-Beatle George Harrison
DOC.TEXT: Police said Tuesday night they are investigating threatening letters sent to former Beatle George Harrison. Harrison, 47, received the letters at his mansion in Friar Park near Henley 35 miles west of central London, where he lives with his wife, Olivia, 42, and their 12-year-old son, Dhani. Inspector Patrick Wilmore of Thames Valley police said: ``We are looking into a matter of certain threatening letters to George Harrison.'' He did not elaborate. Another ex-Beatle, John Lennon, was slain outside his New York apartment by a deranged gunman on Dec. 8, 1980. The rock music group broke up in 1970 after eight years of success. A London newspaper, the Daily Mirror, said the singer-guitarist had received five anonymous, handwritten letters in recent weeks threatening him with death. The tabloid said each of the five bore postmarks indicating they were mailed in south London. It said one of the letters stated ``Time you went'' and another said ``Goodbye George.'' The paper said Harrison has been haunted by fear of an assassin ever since Lennon was slain and is constantly accompanied by a bodyguard.

DOC.HEAD: House Embraces Democratic 1991 Budget That Spurns Bush Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new grafs 3-5: ``Meanwhile, Senate,'' with Senate Budget Committee lining up support for $43 billion deficit-reduction plan; deletes penultimate and antepenultimate graf pvs as outdated
DOC.TEXT: The House on Tuesday adopted the Democrats' $1.2 trillion federal budget for next year, making deep cuts in President Bush's defense plans and channeling much of the savings into social programs. Before the vote, Democrats taunted the Republicans for abandoning the administration's own spending plan. Meanwhile, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser finally lined up enough votes for his committee to approve a budget of its own, a congressional source said. Until now, solid GOP opposition and several balking Democrats have prevented the panel from drawing up a spending package. But Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., told Sasser he would support a plan that claims to reduce next year's deficit by $43 billion, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. That would produce a majority on the panel for the proposal, which could approve a budget as early as Wednesday. The plan would allow $294 billion for defense spending, officials said. On a 218-208 largely party-line vote, the Democratic-controlled House adopted a plan that would provide $295.5 billion for next year's military programs. That is $8.3 billion less than Bush proposed and $11.5 billion below the amount needed to keep pace with inflation, a step supporters said was merited by eased tensions with the Soviet bloc. ``The budget here provides for a transition from a Cold War economy to a peacetime economy, and that is what we need to do for the future,'' said the plan's chief architect, House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Republicans opposed the package en masse, with all 174 GOP lawmakers who cast ballots voting against it. They criticized it as weak on defense and argued that any budget will be meaningless unless negotiations with the White House first yield agreements on its components. They were joined by 34 Democrats who voted against the measure. ``This is the Dukakis platform. This is the Mondale platform. This is the Carter presidency. This is the McGovern movement,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the No. 2 GOP leader, recalling the ghosts of the recent Democratic past. But much of the debate centered on the Republican decision not to offer Bush's own spending blueprint for a vote, reversing a customary practice. Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, revealed the change of heart late Monday, saying the president's package had been ``passed by by economic and political events.'' ``Perhaps that speaks louder than even offering the president's budget,'' said Panetta. ``To govern is to choose, not to run and hide, not to cop out.'' Frenzel replied, ``In our judgment, leadership required meeting with the president two months ago'' to negotiate a compromise budget. Realizing they would not be able to rely on any GOP support, Democrats brought Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., to the floor. He rallied his members by asking them to show that ``we can march, not drift into the next century.'' Aiming to reshape Bush's defense plans, the Democratic budget places long-range constraints on Pentagon spending. The plan shrinks defense budget authority to $283 billion, $24 billion less than Bush. Budget authority is the amount of spending the Pentagon can commit itself to for programs that may last several years, such as the purchase of a warship. Limiting that figure would necessitate future cuts in defense. The House package would spend $224.3 billion _ $5.6 billion more than Bush _ on dozens of domestic and foreign aid programs ranging from grants to scientists to protecting abused children. The plan seeks to slash $36 billion from next year's deficit, the same amount proposed by Bush but with a different mix. Both sides would rely on $13.9 billion in new tax receipts, but the president wants higher savings from benefit programs while Democrats rely more on defense cuts. This year's shortfall is expected by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office to reach $158 billion. But under the budget process's peculiar mathematics, the proposed cuts would enable lawmakers to meet the Gramm-Rudman law's requirement for a 1991 budget gap of no more than $64 billion. The 1991 fiscal year begins Oct. 1. The government will have to pay $183 billion in interest next year on the $3 trillion national debt, nearly 15 percent of all federal spending. Before final passage, the House rejected by 334-90 a budget offered by the liberal Congressional Black Caucus. It would have limited defense spending to $279.5 billion and boosted spending for housing, education and other domestic programs. The budget maps the government's fiscal plans for the year, but leaves binding spending and tax decisions for later bills.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Season To End On May 23
DOC.TEXT: ABC's surreal ``Twin Peaks'' series, slipping in the ratings despite critical acclaim, will end its season on Wednesday, May 23, instead of its usual Thursday slot, ABC says. The shift was made because the network wanted to have the show's finale included in the May ratings ``sweeps'' that end on May 23, a network spokeswoman said Tuesday. ``Twin Peaks'' was the nation's fifth most-watched show in the week it premiered last month. But it has steadily declined in ratings, and was 45th in the national Nielsen standings for last week. ABC said in a statement that it won't comment on whether the series has a future until May 21, when it announces its fall program schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Food Rationing in Lithuania; Warnings on Latvian Independence
DOC.TEXT: Food rationing began Tuesday in Lithuania, the target of a Kremlin economic embargo, and about 4,000 pro-Moscow Communists derided the republic's independence-minded leaders at a sedate May Day rally. The republic's prime minister said city governments in Moscow and Leningrad would help Lithuania ease the pressure of the embargo. In neighboring Latvia, the head of the Communist Party warned of ``tragic consequences'' if the republic follows Lithuania's secessionist course _ a move that may come this week. While unofficial May Day demonstrators in the Kremlin's Red Square were shouting ``Freedom for Lithuania,'' the pro-Moscow faction of the Baltic republic's Communist Party rallied on Lenin Square in the capital of Vilnius and unfurled banners that read ``Workers Say No to Lithuania's Secession from the U.S.S.R.'' Lithuania's Communist Party has split into two factions _ a pro-independence party and a smaller, pro-Moscow party. The official Tass news agency said mass media in Lithuania blacked out coverage of the May Day rally, and it noted speakers at the rally protested what it called the ``hasty decisions'' made by the republic's parliament, the Supreme Council, which declared independence March 11. Vilnius Radio said the May Day rally lasted about 20 minutes, was neither ``noisy nor disorderly,'' and was attended by ``those people who cannot think differently, who are unable to cross the certain framework of thinking because of the ideology which had been enforced on them during all these years.'' Soviet TV's national newscast ``Vremya'' showed a sparse parade of mostly older people marching along the streets of Vilnius. Rationing on certain foodstuffs went into effect Tuesday but the coupons themselves won't be distributed until Wednesday because of the holiday, said Daina Kalendra, a worker at the Supreme Council's information office. May Day was an official holiday in the republic of 3.8 million people, despite the independence drive, and most stores were closed. Ms. Kalendra said that for the months of May and June, each person is limited to the following: sugar, 4.4 pounds; macaroni, 2.2 pounds; grains, 4.4 pounds; salt, 2.2 pounds; flour, 4.4 pounds; grease or margarine, about a half-pound. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev halted shipments of oil, natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania last month because the republic refused to reverse some of the laws it enacted to bolster its independence. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis sent a congratulatory message to Gorbachev on the occasion of the May Day workers' holiday, Ms. Kalendra said, and noted with irony that some Lithuanians had lost their jobs because of the economic sanctions. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, who is visiting Canada to try to establish closer trade ties, said she hopes neighboring Latvia will declare its independence soon. ``We're particularly sensitive to see what will occur in Latvia,'' she said in Toronto. ``Our fight would be almost impossible without the support and help of republics within the Soviet Union. Later Tuesday, she said new reform city governments in Leningrad and Moscow have offered to help Lithuania with the embargo. ``Not only do they support our independence initiatives but they also want to cooperate with us in practical terms because they receive many of their food supplies from us,'' she said through an interpreter. The leader of Latvia's pro-Moscow Communist Party, Alfred Rubiks, told a May Day rally that the party was alarmed at recent calls for secession from the Soviet Union, Riga Radio reported. On Monday, the Latvian Citizens' Congress _ a shadow parliament representing 700,000 of Latvia's 2.7 million people _ demanded the Baltic republic declare independence. On Thursday and Friday, Latvia's official Supreme Soviet parliament will consider emulating Lithuania's declaration of independence. The Citizens' Congress claims the right to replace the Supreme Soviet. Tass reported Tuesday that the congress adopted a package of documents aimed at restoring the regime that existed prior to Moscow's forced annexation of Latvia in 1940. According to the radio report, monitored by the BBC in London, Rubiks said the congress and ``other anti-socialist organizations and their leaders are heedless of the tragic consequences of such a step for the fate of the peoples of Latvia. They are heading for an overthrow of the existing state system.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe Hails May Day Free of Communist Ritual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to INCLUDE South Korean violence. Picks up 8th graf, `Citizens in ...' with minor editing to trim. DELETES 29th graf, `The common ...' as outdated.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER1,BEL1,MO1,BAI3,MOS24,BEJ2,ADN11
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe ignored violenceelsewhere and quietly celebrated its freedom from decades of stagnant Communist ritual on May Day, substituting music fests and picnics for the proletarian parades of the past. Turbulence marked May Day demonstrations in South Korea, West Berlin, Mexico, Turkey and the Philippines, however. And in Moscow, a brief burst of the popular rage that has swept hard-line Communists from power across Eastern Europe erupted in Red Square Tuesday, where the traditional parade was open to all for the first time in decades. Taunting Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top leaders with cries of ``Shame!'' demonstrators waved Lithuanian flags and banners bearing fierce anti-Kremlin slogans. With their Stalinist leaders already overthrown, thanks in part to Gorbachev's reforms, East Europeans rejoiced more peacefully, marking May Day as they wished. In Leipzig, East Germany, however, leftist youths brawled with young neo-Nazis in the market square, the government news agency ADN reported. West Berlin suffered an annual surge of May Day violence as bands of mostly leftist radicals hurled firebombs and rocks Tuesday night and police responded with tear gas and truncheons. More than 50 people were arrested, police said. But the common traditions of Western and Eastern Europe also found symbolic expression in May Day celebrations in West Berlin as 60,000 Germans, including thousands of East Berliners, came through the Brandenburg Gate. Stormy street protests broke out in Seoul, South Korea's capital, and at least 17 provincial cities on the labor holiday. Tens of thousands of students and workers at auto plants, subways, shipyards and broadcast stations held rallies or clashed with police. The protests were over police raids that crushed strikes at a state broadcast network and South Korea's largest shipyard. Citizens in Nepal for the first time celebrated May Day legally, in keeping with the democratic reforms implemented last month by King Birendra. Workers in Mozambique marched through downtown Maputo demanding higher wages and lower prices and celebrating their first May Day since the ruling party dropped its Marxist philosophy. And in Santiago, Chile, President Patricio Aylwin marked the nation's first May Day in democracy in 17 years, asking workers for patience in their economic demands and announcing changes in restrictive labor laws issued by the previous military regime. In Mexico City, riot police on horseback and on foot charged a holiday march of independent unions, swinging clubs and leaving several demonstrators bleeding from head wounds. Rocks and bricks were hurled at police in reply. The marchers reached the main plaza as a larger demonstration by pro-government unions was dispersing. About 40,000 demonstrators attended a rally in Buenos Aires, cheering leftist leaders who denounced Peronist President Carlos Menem's bills to restrict the right to strike and to regulate employment. The government's economic program is ``anti-people,'' Vicente said, and ``dictated by the International Monetary Fund.'' Pro-Sandinista labor groups threw chunks of concrete at a May Day demonstration by a rival organization in Managua, Nicaragua, injuring at least one demonstrator and leading to arrests. About 40,000 marchers in San Salvador, capital of El Salvador, demanded serious talks between the government and leftist guerrillas. Istanbul Gov. Cahit Bayar said police detained 1,048 people trying to hold illegal May Day celebrations. Nine people were wounded in clashes, officials said. Turkish news agencies said other demonstrators were detained throughout Turkey, where May Day celebrations were banned in 1980. In the Philippines, troops beat dozens of protesters outside a U.S.-run air base and clashed with demonstrators elsewhere in rallies nationwide to demand removal of U.S. military bases. Scores were reported injured. Thousands of Hungarians turned out for a trade union picnic in a Budapest park. The once all-powerful Communists, soundly defeated in last month's polls, were reduced to running a single beer stand. In Prague, American poet Allen Ginsberg received a raucous welcome 25 years after he was crowned ``King'' of a student festival but then expelled by the Communists. Ginsberg warned a nationally televised rock and folk fest against blind imitation of the West as Czechoslovakia returns to democracy. Romanians, demanding the resignation of interim President Ion Iliescu because of his Communist past, continued a 10-day-old protest in Bucharest. At least 1,000 anti-Iliescu protesters gathered in a second city, Timisoara. In Warsaw, Poland, 200 supporters of a leftist, anti-Communist group marched to protest the Solidarity-led government's austerity policies. The May Day holiday has deep popular roots across much of Eastern Europe, where Socialist traditions predate Stalinism. May Day is a traditional spring festival. ``The meaning of May Day changed in step with history,'' Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski said. In France, both the far-right and unionists marched in separate rallies to celebrate the holiday. The only East European capitals where the once all-powerful Communists staged rallies were Sofia, Prague and Tirana, Albania. Albania's state news agency ATA quoted Communist leader Ramiz Alia as reiterating the refusal of his nation _ Europe's last bastion of Stalinism _ to follow Eastern European reforms. ``They are heading into a blind alley,'' he reportedly told a workers' rally, ``jumping out of the frying pan into the fire.'' In China, a holiday mood prevailed. But an armed police cordon around the monument to revolutionary heroes in Beijing's Tiananmen Square emphasized official determination to avoid any repeat of the pro-democracy demonstrations, which spread last spring from the monument to much of the country before being brutally suppressed in June.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 158.62 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Wednesday, down from Tuesday's close of 158.90 yen.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Urged to Help `Keep the Lights Burning' in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: The United States needs a policy to help ``keep the lights burning'' in Hong Kong because Chinese leaders want firm control over the city rather than prosperity when they take over from Britain, outspoken Hong Kong legislator Martin Lee said Tuesday. When Chinese leaders feel insecure, as now, ``they want to control the country first, and likewise to control Hong Kong ... so the economy becomes of secondary importance,'' he said in a speech at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative policy research and advocacy group. Lee, a member of the Hong Kong legislative council, has been giving a pessimistic forecast on Hong Kong's future at meetings with U.S. government officials and members of Congress and in lecture and television appearances. Britain and China in 1984 agreed that the British colony will rejoin China in 1997, when Britain's lease expires, but retain its private enterprise economy and certain other autonomy for at least 50 years. With British influence waning and emigration from the colony swelling, ``there needs to be a U.S. policy'' upholding democracy, human and economic freedoms for Hong Kong, he said. ``If you allow the lights to be switched off in 1997, I'm afraid it will affect not only Hong Kong and China but also the Pacific Rim,'' he said. ``It would be better for the free world to keep this international city afloat, to keep the heart beating in Hong Kong well beyond 1997, rather than being faced with having to take our people as refugees, because that is a distinct possibility.'' The Chinese democracy movement, crushed last June, and the collapse of communist regimes in Eastern Europe have prompted grave concern by the Chinese leadership for its own security, already reflected in a hard-line stand in framing the post-1997 basic law for Hong Kong recently approved in Beijing, he said. ``China is quite happy to see Hong Kong being an outlet for her products and a window to the free world where she can convert her currency,'' he said, but in Beijing's view, ``that's good enough _ Hong Kong need not be such an important place'' as today, when it ranks as the world's 11th largest trading entity. In the view of the Chinese leadership, ``If Hong Kong should lose its prosperity it doesn't matter provided it doesn't pose a threat,'' said Lee.

DOC.HEAD: A 39-Year-Old `I Love Lucy' Pilot Beats New Shows in Ratings
DOC.TEXT: America still loves Lucy _ particularly the pilot for what became CBS' classic ``I Love Lucy'' series. No matter that the show was made during the Korean war, when Harry S. Truman was president. By a CBS estimate, 40 million viewers saw ``I Love Lucy: The Very First Show,'' a Monday special featuring the 34-minute pilot, which Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz filmed in black and white at their own expense on March 10, 1951. Despite the years, it was the first time the show had been broadcast. The one-hour CBS special easily trounced its modern network rivals in the ratings, according to national Nielsen estimates Tuesday. It had a 21.2 rating and got 37 percent of the audience in its time period. In contrast, NBC's ``Shannon's Deal'' got a 10.7 rating and a 19 percent share of the audience. ABC's ``Capital News'' was a distant third, averaging only a 4.8 rating and a minuscule 8 percent share of the audience. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The special was hosted by Lucie Arnaz, the daughter of early television's most famous couple. Monday's CBS special was the premiere of the ``I Love Lucy'' pilot, made on kinescope when Ball, who died last year, was five months pregnant with her daughter. Produced by Ball and her husband for $5,000, the show was never broadcast. CBS preferred a different version, which it used as the basis for its first 26-show order for the series. The pilot, once thought to have been lost, was rediscovered last year by former CBS Entertainment president Bud Grant, now an independent producer. He found that a copy of it was in the posession of Joanne Perez, the widow of a vaudeville performer, Pepito the Spanish Clown, who appears in the show. Grant worked out the deal for the pilot to be shown as a CBS special. ``I Love Lucy'' ran on CBS from 1951 to 1961. Arnaz and Ball were divorced in 1960. The Cuban bandleader, credited with pioneering the use of three cameras and live studio audiences in making TV sitcoms, died in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Alleges Torture Of Political Prisoners In Burma
DOC.TEXT: Torture of civilians by Burma's security forces is widespread and anyone criticizing or even suspected of opposing the military government is at risk, Amnesty International said Wednesday. The worldwide human rights organization said it had new evidence from recently released political prisoners, refugees and other sources that torture thought to have been limited to areas of armed ethnic conflict is rife throughout the country. In its May newsletter, Amnesty International said at least six military and civilian security agencies operating in more than a dozen centers have been routinely torturing detainees for two years. ``The security forces seem to have almost unrestricted authority to carry out arbitrary arrests, to detain prisoners incommunicado for months without charge or trial and to interrogate them using torture,'' Amnesty International said. It said thousands of people have been killed in pro-democracy demonstrations and, following the September 1988 military coup, thousands more were arrested for non-violent political activities. Burmese authorities have not responded to repeated requests by Amnesty International to visit the country to discuss its concerns, the organization said. Amnesty International said the torture usually takes place early in a prisoner's period of detention during the initial questioning. Prisoners often do not have any contact with relatives or lawyers for weeks or months, by which time their injuries may have healed, it said. Even then, prisoners may not be authorized to see their visitors privately and therefore cannot openly describe their treatment, it said. Victims have ranged from young students to prisoners over 80 years old, it said. Beatings are the most frequent form of torture, including punching, kicking, and blows with wooden sticks or truncheons, it said. Amnesty International renewed its previous calls for an inquiry into reports that security forces deliberately killed several thousand demonstrators as the pro-democracy movement gathered momentum between March and September 1988 and after the coup.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Officially Announces Bid For Second Term
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mike Sullivan said Tuesday he's averted the ``doom and gloom'' scenarios predicted four years ago and wants another term as the state's chief executive to heal Wyoming's ailing economy. The Democrat's re-election announcement was long anticipated, yet until Tuesday he overlooked charges from Republican gubernatorial candidate Mary Mead that he lacked the leadership to pull the state out of its economic quagmire. ``The record speaks to that,'' Sullivan said in answer to a reporter's question on how he would defend himself from Mead's attacks. ``Leadership in any race always seems to be what is grabbed on and run with.'' The governor, who is expected to face only token opposition in the Aug. 21 primary, said he expects Mead to challenge his statements that the economy has improved. In making his re-election announcement, Sullivan said economic progress has been made, if for no other reason than that the economy hasn't been the ``economic wasteland'' some predicted. ``There is no question that we've made sacrifices, that it's been a lot of hard work, and it's been difficult times in Wyoming,'' Sullivan told a crowd of supporters who gathered in his office to hear his announcement. ``But some of the dire predictions, the doom and gloom that was predicted four years ago, has been averted,'' he said. ``By hard work, by sacrifice in a lot of areas ... There is progress being made. It shows in the real numbers, it shows in the attitudes as you go throughout the state.''

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Killer Scheduled to Die in Missouri
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with judge granting stay of execution, quotes, further details. Picks up 11th graf pvs: `Missouri has ...
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday night halted the scheduled execution of two-time killer Bobby Lewis Shaw, a few hours after the U. S. Supreme Court declined to intervene in the case. Shaw had been scheduled to die by injection at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday at Potosi Correctional Center. However, U.S. District Judge Edward L. Filippine issued a stay at the request of Shaw's lawyer, Don Wolff. The judge said Wolff's petition contained 12 grounds for relief and that he needed time to review the issues. ``Given the unique circumstances surrounding the filing of this petition, the nature of the issues raised and the volume of the material that must be reviewed, a stay of execution is necessary,'' he said. The nation's highest court earlier voted 5-4 against stopping the execution. On Tuesday afternoon, the Missouri Coalition Against the Death Penalty asked Gov. John Ashcroft to give Shaw a reprieve ``because the prisoner does not comprehend the charges against him,'' said the group's spokeswoman, Martha Schieber. ``It's in the interest of the common good that no death penalty be imposed on a person that suffers from a mental disease or defect,'' Ms. Schieber said. ``There is evidence that Mr. Shaw suffers from a mental disease or defect.'' Ashcroft's spokesman, Bob Ferguson, said his boss referred the application for a reprieve to the state parole board. Ashcroft supports capital punishment and has not previously stopped an execution. Wolff said a psychiatrist and a psychologist who examined Shaw at the Potosi Correctional Center on Monday agreed that the 38-year-old St. Louis man ``suffers from mental disease or defect.'' They found Shaw suffers from dementia, memory loss and doesn't understand the penalty he faces or the arguments in his case, the attorney said. Wolff had prepared briefs for state and federal courts incorporating the psychological findings and other arguments. ``I am so busy I haven't had time to be optimistic or pessimistic,'' Wolff said. Shaw would have been the 124th person executed since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume carrying out the death penalty. Missouri has executed two people since that ruling. Sixty-nine other men and two women are under death sentence in Missouri. Elsewhere, an execution in Florida scheduled for Wednesday was delayed for a man convicted of the 1976 slaying of a Florida Highway Patrol trooper and a Canadian constable. U.S. District Judge Lenore Nesbitt on Tuesday issued a 48-hour stay for Jessie Joseph Tafero, 43. The governor's office immediately rescheduled the execution for 7:01 a.m. Friday. Shaw had no visitors scheduled Tuesday, and he had not asked for any family or friends to serve as witnesses to the execution, prison spokesman Dale Riley said. ``He is very quiet, almost what I would call a flat personality,'' Riley said. ``He hasn't made any real expressions at all, no statements for public release.'' Lawyers have argued that Shaw has an IQ of 73 and has spent most of his adult life behind bars. ``He has a history of borderline intellectual functioning,'' Wolff said. But courts ruled Shaw was fit to stand trial for the July 16, 1979, stabbing death of Walter Farrow, 61, a guard at the Missouri State Penitentiary in Jefferson City. During the attack on Farrow with two butcher knives, Shaw injured a second prison employee. He was already serving a life sentence for the 1975 murder of a man who had been his sister's boyfriend.

DOC.HEAD: New Arrested in Iraqi `Super Gun' Case
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents investigating the development of a suspected ``super gun'' for Iraq made further arrests Tuesday, British Customs officials said. Two British companies involved in the investigation, Sheffield Forgemasters Ltd. and Walter Somers Ltd., both confirmed that employes had been picked up for questioning. The questioning and arrests sparked an outcry in the House of Commons by lawmakers from all parties and there were several calls for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government to make a statement. A Customs Office spokesman, who spoke on condition he was not identified, said the arrests took place in northern England but refused to identify those arrested or to say how many people were detained. Government sources said four people were arrested. In the House of Commons, opposition Labor Party lawmaker Richard Caborn said he understood 14 people from Forgemasters and Walter Somers were taken in for questioning, three were arrested and six other Forgemasters executives were in police stations giving statements. Conservative lawmaker Sir Hal Miller said he had been told that Peter Mitchell, managing director of Walter Somers, had been arrested and initially denied access to a lawyer until his wife intervened. ``I should like a government minister to make a statement on how this comes to pass,'' he said. Eight giant tubes manufactured by Sheffield Forgemasters were seized by British Customs officers on April 12 at the port of Middlesbrough and military experts later said they could be used as the barrel of a giant gun. The Iraqi government and the company have said they were intended for a petrochemical plant. The company has said it had government permission to sell the pipes to Iraq. Trucks heading for Iraq with steel forgings from Walter Somers were stopped in Turkey and Greece late last month, and Greek authorities arrested the British driver. Caborn said the contracts they were being questioned about ``were cleared by the Department of Trade and Industry'' and demanded the government answer a series of questions about the affair. Miller said he had evidence supporting both firms' claims of being innocent in the affair. A week before the April 12 seizure of the steel tubes, Iraq placed an urgent order with Walter Somers for a component that the company fears may have been an aiming device. The order was refused. Britain imposed an arms embargo on Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and has not lifted it because no formal cease-fire has been signed. Customs officers have said the tubes built by Sheffield Forgemasters could be assembled to make a 131-foot long gun barrel with a 39-inch bore. The company has said that 44 sections of tubing have already been delivered to Iraq, and there has been speculation that an even longer barrel may have been intended.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Law Could Cause Embargoes on Shrimp Imports
DOC.TEXT: Current law aimed at protecting endangered sea turtles could cause widespread embargoes of imported shrimp next year, a Bush administration official told Congress Tuesday. The law approved last year forbidding shrimp imports after 1991 from countries that are lax about turtle protection may be unrealistic, said Edward E. Wolfe, deputy assistant secretary of state for oceans and fisheries affairs. ``There is little chance that these countries will be able to meet the standards required by the law in the time allowed, no matter how genuine the effort,'' said Wolfe in testimony before the subcommittee on fisheries and wildlife conservation and the environment of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. Wolfe told the panel ``widespread embargoes may be inevitable'' without an extension of the May 1, 1991, deadline requiring foreign countries to be as tough on shrimpers as the United States. Panama, Honduras, Guatemala and Costa Rica are sure to be affected by such an embargo, Wolfe said. ``It has long been the bipartisan policy of the United States ... to support efforts aimed at promoting economic development and political stability in Central America,'' he said. ``Now, when the region will be looking more than ever to the United States to support its democratic efforts, we are preparing to impose trade sanctions totaling more than $115 million for these four countries alone.'' Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela likely would be hit by an embargo also, Wolfe said. But shrimpers support such action against countries that do not have strict conservation laws, said Harris Lasseigne, president of the Texas Shrimp Association. Imported shrimp worth $1.7 billion accounted for more than 75 percent of all shrimp consumed in the United States in 1988, Wolfe said. The largest suppliers are Mexico, China and Ecuador. Lasseigne said imported shrimp are a ``severe problem'' for U.S. shrimpers. ``Dumping of foreign shrimp into the U.S. market directly affects the price the American producer receives for his product,'' Lasseigne said. ``The U.S. producer is forced to compete with much lower operating costs in foreign countries.'' Lasseigne and other shrimpers called for a loosening in regulations that require the use of turtle excluder devices in their nets, which they say cause them to lose up to 70 percent of their catch. Last year, the enforcement of regulations requiring those devices prompted shrimpers to blockade ports in Texas and other states.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony Reveals Attempts to Get Money From Elderly Millionaire
DOC.TEXT: A former Playboy model charged with tax evasion discussed a staged kidnapping and palimony suit as ways to elicit money from the elderly millionaire who paid her expenses and gave her gifts, a witness said Tuesday. William G. Domer was the first prosecution witness to testify in the federal trial of Lynnette Harris, 35, who is charged with failing to pay taxes on more than $1 million she and her twin sister reputedly received for sex from David Kritzik, who died last year at age 89. Domer, a former accountant, testified under examination by U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson that he first met Ms. Harris when she consulted him about her taxes in February 1985. He said she was concerned about not having filed returns for several years and about $130,000 she had received from Kritzik. During the 1{ years Ms. Harris retained Domer as a financial consultant, she inflated expense bills she reported to Kritzik and discussed other ways to get money _ including staging a kidnapping with Al Hoffman, a weightlifter with whom she had an affair, Domer testified. ``There was one discussion that there was a remark made about having her kidnapped by Mr. Hoffman ... to be held for ransom,'' Domer said. Also Ms. Harris ``talked about suing Mr. Kritzik for a large amount of money using a palimony suit as a means of doing that,'' he said. Ms. Harris, a former actress and model, faces two counts of tax evasion and two counts of failure to file income tax returns. The charges carry a maximum penalty of 12 years in prison and $625,000 in fines. Her identical twin, Leigh Ann Conley, of Milwaukee, is charged with four counts of failing to file federal income tax returns in the same alleged scheme. She will stand trial in June. The blonde twins have appeared nude in Playboy and two films. Kritzik of Shorewood founded General Merchandise Co. in the 1930s, which grew to become one of the largest mail order companies in the world. He later created the Treasure Island discount store chain, which was sold to J.C. Penny Co. for $11 million. Defense attorney Dennis Coffey maintains the money Ms. Harris received was a gift and therefore not taxable. A second prosecution witness, John Ebert, testified he was hired by Ms. Harris in late 1984 or early 1985 as a general contractor on a project to remodel a house she owned in East Troy. He said he received $51,000 in payments from Kritzik. Ebert was asked about Ms. Harris' relationship with Kritzik. ``What did she say her occupation was?'' Johnson asked. ``More or less a prostitute,'' Ebert said. ``She said it in a roundabout way.'' Julie Drigot, who worked as a housekeeper for Kritzik from 1977 until his death, testified Ms. Harris told her she viewed her sexual relationship with Kritzik as a job and didn't enjoy contact with him. In other testimony Tuesday, Milton Sattell, Kritzik's accountant of 25 years, said he had prepared gift tax returns for money Kritzik gave Ms. Conley between 1982 and 1986, but none for money given to Ms. Harris. Thomas Walz, a special agent with the Internal Revenue Service's criminal investigation unit, testified as the government's chief investigator of Ms. Harris' case. He cited documents he said indicated Ms. Harris had an ``express oral agreement'' with Kritzik to pay her in exchange for ``cohabitating'' with him. ``He was 84 years old, there wasn't a whole lot of sex,'' Walz said, reading Ms. Harris' statements from the deposition. ``Sex wasn't a major portion of the relationship.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sends Overhaul Proposal to Congress
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent Congress legislation Tuesday to overhaul the federal civil service pay system. If enacted, the Bush initiative would scrap the current ``General Schedule'' of pay scales and erect a new, two-tier pay system for professional and clerical jobs. It would install a new, higher pay scale for the professionals and others in hard-to-fill administrative posts, and allow the government to vary pay for clerical jobs by the prevailing wages in different regions. It would eliminate automatic ``step'' increases for the professionals and top administrators, substituting instead pay increases on merit. The Office of Personnel Management planned to release full details of the pay plan at a news briefing Wednesday. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a written statement the proposal ``will provide several interim measures to address the most serious recruitment and retention problems and then, over the next several years, will initiate broader reforms of the pay-setting machinery.'' Fitzwater said, ``These changes will help make the system more flexible in responding to the labor market and will strengthen the ties between pay and performance.''

DOC.HEAD: President Pays Tribute To Korean War Veterans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 to reflect speech as delivered; INSERTS new grafs 7-11 with details.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid tribute Tuesday night to Korean War veterans, saying their fight ``laid the foundation for the march of democracy'' around the world today. Bush delivered the speech before a black-tie audience of 550 at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner for the Korean War Veterans Memorial. ``It was a war in which we turned the tide against communism for the first time, in a victory regretably sometimes ignored by history,'' Bush said of the conflict that claimed 54,246 American lives. Bush said that a Korean War Memorial planned for the Mall in Washington will help ensure that Korea does not remain ``the forgotten conflict.'' ``America must remember that struggle, from the Pusan perimeter to the landing at Inchon to the recapture and brave defense of Seoul,'' said the president. ``Looking back at the Korean conflict, our defense of freedom laid the foundation for the march of democracy we're seeing today around the world,'' Bush said. The dinner included a salute to the five senators and 18 members of House who fought in Korea. Bush said, ``Because of these brave soldiers and so many others, South Korea is now on its way to becoming one of the world's economic powers, with a freely elected democratic government and secure borders.'' Several South Korean industrialists made major contributions to the fund to build the $10.5 million memorial, including Lee Kun Hee, chairman of the Samsung Group, who was singled out by Bush for his sponsorship of the dinner. Other major contributors included Hyundai Motor America, IBM and the AFL-CIO. Congress authorized the memorial in 1986, and the organizers have until October 1991 to raise the funds and commence work. The dinner was expected to net about $300,000 and boost the total raised to date to $6 million. Bush left after his speech without staying for dinner or to hear comedian Bob Hope. Bush unveiled the winning design for the Korean War Memorial last June 14 in a Rose Garden ceremony. The memorial, which will rise near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, will consist of 38 life-size statues of combat troops moving down a path toward the U.S. flag. It will not have the names of each serviceman killed in the conflict.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Capitalism Remedy for Argentina's Decline
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem of the Peronist party, which for decades advocated a blend of capitalism and socialism, said Tuesday that capitalism is the only solution to Argentina's economic problems. His comments came as 40,000 May Day demonstrators rallied and cheers leftist leaders who denounced Menem's recent bills to restrict the right to strike and to regulate employment. In opening a session of Congress, Menem said: ``We hope to construct capitalism that is humanized. Decent. Efficient. Competitive.'' Menem's open support of capitalism was his clearest break with his party's traditional support of state control of industry. He argues he has no choice. Argentina is beset by triple digit inflation and more than 30 percent unemployment. The national currency, the austral, has lost nearly all of its value against the dollar in recent months and foreign aid was unobtainable. Menem, 59, was elected in May 1988 promising pay raises for workers and a ``productive revolution'' that would spur employment and economic growth. But since taking office in July, Menem has presided over budget cuts, layoffs, the lifting of controls on prices and foreign exchange, the partial deregulation of the oil industry, and the pending sale of state companies. ``Let no one be mistaken,'' Menem told the senators and deputies gathered under the immense stained-glass dome of the Congress. ``The transformation of the state, the sale of public companies, the elimination of regulations ... (And) the cleaning up of fiscal accounts ... Are necessary to recover the sovereignty of our state.'' Applause was modest. Menem's proposals are radical in a nation where one-quarter of all workers are public employees. Historically, wages and prices were controlled, imports restricted, foreign investment discouraged and domestic investment subsidized. Tax evasion was widespread. Virtually every government since that of party founder Juan Peron in the 1946 had supported government regulations and control of industries. Peron nationalized major industries and created state enterprises, but also permitted private businesess to operate. Since the 1940s, Argentina has fallen from being one of the world's richest nations to an economic nightmare. At a rally on the city's broad Avenida de Mayo, the Communist Party and other leftist groups rallied to celebrate Labor Day, a national holiday, and comdemn Menem. ``Down with the economic plan of Menem and the International Monetary Fund,'' read one banner. Thousands cheers Nestor Vicente of the United Left coalition when he called Menem's economic plan, ``anti-people.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Concerned Over Friction With U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Officials expressed concern Tuesday over Israel's growing friction with the United States, which stems from disagreements over Middle East peace policy, Jewish settlements in the occupied lands and U.S. hostages in Lebanon. Referring to the State Department's sharp criticism of Israel for rejecting U.S. proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said, ``It has to worry me, and it has to worry all of us.'' On Monday, the State Department accused right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of missing an important opportunity for peace by refusing to agree to U.S. terms for talks with Palestinians in Cairo. The Shamir government rejected the talks, saying they could lead to backdoor negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Adding to the strain is Washington's pressure on Israel to stop building Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and to free Shiite Moslem prisoners to help win the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon. Israel has resisted both demands and Shamir's caretaker government has even stepped up settlement construction in recent weeks. The Haaretz daily reported Tuesday that Shamir agreed to push plans to create settlements approved by previous governments and listed 14 sites under consideration. The U.S. has repeatedly said that settlements are an obstacle to peace. President Bush made an indirect appeal for a prisoner release, saying he ``certainly had no objection'' if Israel made such a move as a goodwill gesture. But Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner said Israel had not received any request for a prisoner release and said the United States was ``certainly not'' pressuring Israel over the issue. He stressed that Israel was seeking the release of three Israeli servicemen held by radical Shiite Moslems in Lebanon. But Pazner and other officials gave no indication that Israel would free abducted pro-Iranian Shiite cleric Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid or about 300 Arabs, most Lebanese Shiites, held by an Israeli-backed militia in south Lebanon to encourage the release of U.S. hostages. Shamir is now trying to form a right-wing coalition government without the center-left Labor Party. Labor collapsed the joint Labor-Likud government in March when Shamir refused to endorse U.S. peace proposals. Arens, a close Shamir ally, said Tuesday that Shamir would stick to a peace initiative adopted by the Likud-Labor coalition in May 1988. ``You will find that in the policy guidelines (of the new government) it will be written that we have to advance the peace program of May 1988. And it will be advanced,'' Arens said in an interview with Israel television. The government peace program calls for Palestinian elections and limited autonomy in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Chief Says U.S. Troops Needed for Influence in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The United States will suffer a sharp loss of influence in Europe if it withdraws its troops from the continent, West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said Tuesday night. Nuclear forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should remain in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, but that their numbers should be greatly reduced, he said. All nuclear weapons in West Germany belong to and are controlled by the United States, though France and Britain have nuclear-armed forces elsewhere. NATO officials might move toward replacing ground-based nuclear weapons with air-launched missiles when they meet next week in Canada, he said in a speech to the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies of the Johns Hopkins University. Stoltenberg rejected Soviet opposition to a unified Germany remaining in NATO and said he saw hope that the Soviet Union would agree to it. He said it was conceivable for NATO troops to be restricted to what is now West Germany after unification and that other German forces not assigned to NATO could then be present in what is now in East Germany. ``It gives me great satisfaction to add that the foreign ministers of Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary supported this position at the latest meeting of the Warsaw Pact foreign ministers,'' Stoltenberg said. Their support might help persuade Moscow to accept German membership in NATO, he added. Stoltenberg said the United States might be able to reduce its forces on the central European front beyond the 195,000 troops proposed by President Bush, but Americans should maintain a substantial military presence in Europe, he said. ``In the past American cooperation and influence on European policy was helpful and in future American policy and influence in Europe can be helpful,'' Stoltenberg said. ``But without any soldiers or significant (numbers of) soldiers, your influence in all matters of security policy will sharply decline,'' he added. ``And I doubt whether this is desirable.'' Stoltenberg laughed at a suggestion that the American dominance of the security structure of NATO was an infringement on German sovereignty and thus was comforting to France. ``To avoid war between Germany and France we don't need NATO,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Natal Leader Talks of Firing Squads
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A provincial leader of the African National Congress said Tuesday that police and members of white right-wing organizations would face firing squads or imprisonment when the ANC takes power, the South African Press Association reported. The independent news agency quoted Harry Gwala, of Natal province, as also saying, ``Those vast tracts of land that are currently owned by white farmers should be returned to those who own it and are living on it.'' In one of the most militant speeches by any ANC leader since the organization was legalized in February, Gwala was quoted as warning ``warlords, hit squad members, AWB (Afrikaner Resistance Movement) members and police'': ``When we are free, our prison doors will be open for you. ``If you are lucky, you will end up serving long prison sentences, but for the hardened criminals ... the only place for them is in front of the firing squad.'' He gave a May Day speech to a crowd of about 10,000 in Edendale, in the heart of Natal. More than 500 Zulus have died in the province this year, mostly from battles between supporters of the ANC and members of Inkatha, a political party headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. More than 10,000 people, mostly ANC supporters, became refugees in Edendale and hundreds of people on both sides died in fighting since February. He urged the gathering to defend their homes and families against Inkatha. ``Let us wipe them out if they attack us,'' Gwala was quoted as saying. He also asked removal of all police and soldiers sent to quell the violence. Gwala attacked South Africa's commercial press in his speech, and promised that an ANC government would subsidize education and provide schoolchildren with free breakfast and lunch. Gwala spoke on the eve of talks between the government and ANC leaders attempting to eliminate obstacles to formal constitutional negotiations. The government says continuing violence and ANC calls for armed struggle hinder the negotiation process. ``While the government continues to harass our people, the armed struggle will continue,'' Gwala was quoted as saying. ``If it arises that the future of our country can be settled peacefully, we will negotiate with the government. But if the negotiations break down, F.W. de Klerk's government must not be deceived, we will continue the struggle in all ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Lawyers Killed for Advocating Justice
DOC.TEXT: The Lawyers Committee for Human Rights said Tuesday that 68 legal professionals were murdered worldwide in 1989 and at least 209 others were tortured, detained or harassed because they advocated justice. ``The lawyers and judges with whom this report is concerned stand as symbols of the struggle for justice and human rights,'' said committee Chairman Marvin E. Frankel. The report chronicled abuses against lawyers, judges, law students and law professors in 48 countries. It did not include Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Albania, North Korea and other countries where lawyers and judges do not or cannot challenge abuses committed by governments or security forces, the committee said. The Lawyers Committee for Human Rights is a 12-year-old organization based in New York. Its data was gathered by a worldwide network of lawyers, which shares information and appeals to authorities in certain cases. Colombia headed the list with 58 abuses, one-fourth of the total cases reported. The committee said the abuses included the killings of 17 lawyers and 10 judges in 1989. More than 225 judges, magistrates and court workers have been murdered since 1980 in Colombia, where political and drug-related violence is commonplace. ``In countries like Brazil, Colombia, El Salvador, the Philippines and Sri Lanka, among others, the threats to the due process of law, and to the professionals devoted to administering the process, come from a frightening array of diverse forces,'' the report said. Twelve legal professionals were killed in Peru last year, including Marcial Capelleti Cisneros, a professor and former president of the Committee for the Defense of Human Rights. Cisneros was murdered May 29 while giving a test to law students at the University of Huamanga. The report cited 25 cases of detention, torture and harassment in Israel, mostly involving Palestinian lawyers who represented detainees in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In China, seven lawyers and law students were detained. Xiong Yan, a law student who met with Premier Li Peng to discuss student demands during the pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square, was arrested June 14 and charged with organizing and inciting a counter-revolutionary rebellion.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose $1.52 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Wednesday, opening at $371.39. It closed at $369.87 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Agrees to Permit Opposition Parties
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Democratic Party has asked the government to tolerate the establishment of opposition parties, a statement read on national television Monday night said. The former French colony has been ruled since independence in 1960 by the Democratic Party. The nation's constitution permits opposition parties, but opposition groups have always had their requests to form political parties rejected on technical grounds and their leaders have been harassed. The statement said the country had remained a one-party state because the people preferred such a system. But the communique added that the government was ``invited to authorize the formation of new political parties.'' ``Today, the national consensus on which the Democratic Party's leadership had been built seems broken ... since some of our compatriots have demonstrated to show their desire to create their own parties.'' the statement said. The government usually approves party decisions. Last week, the government indicated opposition parties would be tolerated when it said ``anything is possible,'' as long as order is maintained. Several opposition groups have already applied to form political parties. The government has been under growing pressure to accept opposition parties since mass student demonstrations in March protesting austerity measures and following democratic reforms by several other West African and Central African nations. The March riots forced the closing of the nation's schools for the rest of the year and led to calls for the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. The traditional May Day parade was also canceled Tuesday because of the March demonstrations, said the government newspaper, Fraternite-Matin.

DOC.HEAD: New Fighting in Chad Leaves 70 Dead, Embassy Says
DOC.TEXT: Chadian officials said Tuesday that government forces killed 70 Libyan-backed rebels and took another 45 prisoner in an attack on a guerrilla refuge. The battle Monday came during what the Chadian Embassy to France described as ``mopping-up operations'' against the Islamic Legion rebels opposed to the Chadian government. A communique released by the embassy made no mention of government losses. It claimed that the government troops captured several pickup trucks equipped with rocket launchers. The statement did not say where the fighting took place. The rebels launch attacks into its territory from bases in the sparsely populated Darfur province of western Sudan, where the Khartoum government exercises virtually no control. Chad claims the Islamic Legion is armed and trained by Libya. Tripoli denies the force exists and terms the conflict a purely Chadian affair. In a statement from the official Libyan news agency JANA, Libya accused Chad of ``hostility'' and said President Hissene Habre hopes to distract attention from a failing economy by stirring up war hysteria. ``Libya has no connection with the armed confrontation between Chadians and we have no intention of aggression,'' said the JANA communique, monitored in Rome. ``We are still hoping for dialogue and depending on it.'' The latest round of battles in the sporadic civil war was touched off in March, when rebels seized two border posts. France, the former colonial power, added a company of paratroopers, an extra transport plane and a medical unit to its military contingent after the takeover. Chadian Foreign Minister Ibn Oumar said in Paris last week that attempts to negotiate its long-standing territorial dispute with Libya over the mineral-rich Aouzou Strip have failed. The two countries agreed last year to confirm a cease-fire. They also agreed to exchange prisoners of war and submit the territorial dispute to international arbitration.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives Get Welcome Phone Calls From Freed Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-12, `Langston said ...' with 15 grafs to UPDATE with details of Reed's reunion with wife and son; picks up 13th graf pvs, `At the...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ex-hostage Frank Reed said Tuesday he had been separated from Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland about a year ago, and was surprised to find out they had not been released, according to Reed's daughter. ``He said he had been with them, but that he hadn't seen Terry Anderson or Mr. Sutherland for about a year,'' said Marilyn Langston, 33. ``He was disturbed that they weren't out. He thought for sure they would have been released.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was abducted on a Beirut street in 1985. Sutherland, acting agriculture dean at American University of Beirut, was abducted later that year. Reed's wife, Fahima Reed, said her husband was ``very, very angry'' when he learned that Anderson and Sutherland were still hostages. Fahima, known as ``Fifi,'' and Reed's 9-year-old son, Tarek, were reunited Tuesday with Reed in West Germany. In an interview from Wiesbaden with television station WHDH of Boston, Mrs. Reed said of the reunion: ``Nobody spoke a word, we just hugged each other. Then he started breaking up. He cried. He broke down and cried.'' ``We were there to cheer Frank. But Frank was cheering Tarek, trying to make him laugh, and we ended up laughing, the three of us.'' Reed could not sit still and his concentration was erratic, she said. ``That's because he was chained and sitting constantly so he wanted to move around. I had to keep following him with my eyes,'' she said. She said Reed told her: ``I have to be talking because I was kept for three years, confined by myself, couldn't talk to anybody, and now I just feel like talking.'' But Reed was able to joke about some of his experiences. ``He has a terrific sense of humor,'' Mrs. Reed said. ``He was relating some of the stories of things he went through and I just broke down with laughter. I was laughing like I never laughed in my life.'' Langston, Reed's daughter, said he called her early Tuesday from a military hospital in West Germany. ``He said, `Hi dear,' and my heart just started beating fast,'' Langston said. ``It seemed unreal seeing him on television, but hearing his voice, everything seemed brighter.'' Langston said her father said he had been blindfolded for much of his 42 months in captivity, and had lost 60 pounds during the ordeal. ``And he said he hadn't been able to talk for 3{ years,'' Langston said. ``He talked most of the time. He just wanted to talk. I could barely get a word in edgewise. ``But he sounded pretty good, pretty lively, considering what he's been through,'' she said. Monday night, Reed made a brief call to his mother, 91-year-old Leota Sprague. ``He said `hi mom.' I said, `hi Frankie,''' Sprague said. ``I knew his voice right away. I was thrilled. I said, `it's so good to hear your voice.''' Mrs. Reed and Tarek share an apartment with Sprague. A Malden native, Reed converted to Islam before marrying his wife. He made two trips to Lebanon before leaving his post as school principal in Whitefield, N.H., to become director of elementary education at Beirut's International College in 1977. At the time of his abduction Sept. 9, 1986, Reed was running the private Lebanese International School, which he founded after the International College had been bombed out. After his abduction, a caller to a Western news agency claimed he was a CIA spy and was taken by Islamic Jihad, which also is believed to be holding Anderson and Sutherland. That Shiite fundamentalist organization denied holding Reed. Later, a group calling itself the Organization of Arab Revolutionary Cells-Omar Mukhtar Brigade claimed responsibility for Reed's abduction. Reed's release came a day after kidnappers issued two statements saying he would be freed, one signed by the previously unknown Organization of Islamic Dawn. Reed's family called the espionage charge ridiculous.

DOC.HEAD: `Prelude to a Kiss' by Craig Lucas Moves to Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Prelude to a Kiss,'' the bewitching fantasy by Craig Lucas, has made the journey from off-Broadway to Broadway with most of the magic intact. The big question for the play, which opened Tuesday at the Helen Hayes Theater, was what would happen to it once leading man Alec Baldwin left to do a movie and was replaced by Timothy Hutton. Well, the verdict is not yet in on Hutton. He undoubtedly will get better in the role. But right now, the actor is giving a tense and tentative performance, concentrating more on his lines than on his character. Once Hutton relaxes, he should do fine. He has a boyish bewilderment that seems exactly right, considering the odd but sweet plot. The play itself is just as charming as ever, and the rest of the original cast is even more accomplished than when ``Prelude to a Kiss'' first opened in March at off-Broadway's Circle Rep. The story is a modern New York romance, boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl and then boy-finds-girl _ in the strangest of circumstances. It starts as a romantic comedy with Peter, played by Hutton, meeting Rita (Mary-Louise Parker) at a party. They fall in love, visit her parents in New Jersey and then get married. The play builds to the wedding scene where the bride is kissed by a mysterious old man, played by Barnard Hughes. Suddenly, they have exchanged souls. Much of the evening's pleasure comes from the realization that Hughes, in a funny, touching performance, is now the young woman, and Parker, the elderly gent. And Lucas' dialogue is unerring, perfectly capturing the cosmic transfer of these two very different personalities. But there is a darkness around the edges of this fairy tale. Lucas also deals with the transitory nature of life and love, especially as Peter begins to realize the girl he has married is not the woman he thought she was. It makes him wonder just what love is, merely a physical attraction or something more. Parker is especially endearing, particularly in the early scenes when she displays a goofy, off-center sense of comedy. Larry Bryggman and Debra Monk excel as her understandably worried parents, and there is an expert comic cameo by John Dossett as the young man's sardonic best friend. Director Norman Rene, a long-time Lucas collaborator, handles the play with a light, playful touch that never turns preachy. Even in its more serious moments, ``Prelude to a Kiss'' celebrates the unexpected nature of romance. It's that sense of adventure that makes the play such a delight.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Weapons Buildup Worries Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Ambassador Alexander Zotov said Tuesday the Arab-Israeli conflict and the buildup of weapons in the Middle East would be a ``top priority'' issue at the May 30 to June 3 superpower summit. He told reporters, ``The situation in the Middle East is dramatic. There are many weapons stockpiles of the most destructive kind, and much violence, too, and something must be done about it.'' Speaking at a news conference two days after President Hafez Assad returned from talks in Moscow with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Zotov reiterated Moscow's support for Syria. The threat by Iraq, another Soviet friend, to use chemical weapons against Israel in the event of an Israeli nuclear attack has added to tension in a region already bristling with advanced weapons. Zotov said Washington and Moscow have conducted ``very constructive'' contacts on the subject of peace in the Middle East prior to the coming talks between President Bush and Gorbachev. He did not elaborate. But he said peace in the region was being held back by ``Israeli reservations'' to entering into a peace process, and complained ``the United States has not shown enough firmness'' with the Israelis ``to push matters forward.'' Zotov stressed Moscow's continuing commitment to bolster Syria's armed forces but added: ``It is the general policy of the Soviet Union to reduce the level of military conflict everywhere, including the Middle East, and the emphasis is on a reasonable defensive capability.'' Assad says Middle East peace is impossible unless Syria achieves ``strategic parity'' with Israel. Assad concluded an agreement in Moscow for continuing Soviet military aid. No details have been divulged. Western reports say Moscow has been stressing to Assad that he abandon his drive for stategic parity with Israel and has reduced the volume of advanced weapons it traditionally supplied Damascus. The London-based Flight International magazine reported last month that the Kremlin turned down a Syrian request for SA-10 and SA-11 anti-aircraft missiles. Zotov did not deny this report or similar ones, but again stressed Moscow's continuing commitment to Syria's security. Analysts estimate that Syria owes the Soviet Union $15 billion. Soviet officials in Damascus have said the debt is only $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: British Court to Review Charge of Helping Spy
DOC.TEXT: Two men who say they helped Soviet master spy George Blake break prison in 1966 won a High Court order Tuesday to delay their trial. Lawyers later said they could not recall any recent similar exercise of the High Court's powers to suspend a criminal trial. Judge Sir Derek Hodgson ordered the trial of Patrick Pottle and Michael Randle halted while their application proceeds for a judicial review. The trial was to have started at the Old Bailey central criminal court Wednesday. His ruling overturned Judge Sir William Macpherson's decision Friday at the Old Bailey against granting a permanent suspension of the trial. Pottle, 52, an antiques dealer, and Randle, 56, a researcher, said it would be ``oppressive'' and ``an abuse of the process of the court'' to prosecute them for something that happened 24 years ago. Their plea raised an important legal issue as to whether decisions of crown court judges in such circumstances are open to judicial review. Hodgson said their plea should be considered quickly by the High Court's Divisional Court. The hearing will be on May 16. Blake, now 67 and living in Moscow, was a double agent jailed for 42 years in 1961. He admitted spying for the Soviets while working for British intelligence. Blake escaped from London's Wormwood Scrubs prison in 1966. Pacifists Pottle and Randle said in their 1989 book, ``The Blake Escape,'' that they helped him because of the ``cruel and inhuman sentence.'' They say authorities knew of their involvement by 1970 but prosecution began only when their book appeared.
