For Release Sunday, May 6, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Western Europe's ``Night Of Barbarism'' Began May 10, 1940
DOC.TEXT: Western Europe waited for the Germans in spring 1940, but France felt safe behind the Maginot Line and Holland hoped to stay neutral. The Dutch army drafted Cornelius Stam and gave him an 1895 rifle. ``We didn't do a damn thing, really,'' Stam recalled last month. ``We were just sitting in the sun'' when Adolf Hitler's death machine rolled west on May 10, 1940, casting Western Europe into what Winston Churchill called a ``long night of barbarism.'' The onslaught by bombers, tanks and 2 million Wehrmacht and SS soldiers caught the victims unprepared. Nazi Germany needed only four days to conquer the Netherlands, which had been neutral in World War I. Hitler's legions swept the patchwork defenses aside and destroyed the Dutch fighting spirit with carpet bombing of Rotterdam. Two decades of peace in Europe had ended nearly eight months earlier with the German invasion of Poland. Britain and France declared war on Germany as a result, but there had been little combat in the west. When the Germans invaded, officers ``had us march around at 4 in the morning, toting our rifles on our shoulders, out of sheer madness,'' Stam said in an interview. At dawn May 10, German bombers destroyed major military airfields in Holland and Hitler's troops poured across the border. Tanks directed by Field Marshall Gerd von Rundstedt began a sweep through Belgium, Luxembourg and northern France to the Atlantic, meeting little resistance. Belgium surrendered May 28 after 6,552 civilians and 6,236 soldiers had been killed. Luxembourg's government fled to London on the invasion's first day. Unlike Wilhelmina, the Dutch queen, King Leopold III of Belgium decided to remain in his country under German occupation. Leopold ultimately became so deeply compromised that he was forced to abdicate in 1950. Soon after Belgium capitulated, German troops turned south toward Paris. About 70,000 French soldiers were killed in the futile, six-week-long attempt to halt the German advance, more than all the Americans killed in Vietnam. France relied on the Maginot Line along the German border, a static defense system based on the tactics of World War I. The tanks of German panzer divisions swept around the northern end into France by cutting through the Ardennes forest. The Dutch depended on the Water Line, last used successfully in the 16th century war for independence from Spain, which involved a ring of flooded land around Amsterdam, Rotterdam and The Hague. The Germans sent waves of paratroopers, against whom flood was no defense. ``It was a very fine morning,'' said Arie Dekker, who was a 15-year-old office boy near Rotterdam when the paratroopers came. ``The pilots were waving at us. ... They'd been told they were protecting us from the British.'' Queen Wilhelmina and her government fled to London on May 13. The next day, when organized resistance was all but crushed, the Luftwaffe returned to Rotterdam for a pre-announced bombing raid that leveled its central district and killed about 800 people. ``The sun totally vanished,'' said Dekker's wife, Cornelia, whose family lived in Krimpen aan de Lek, a nearby town. ``At first, we thought it was a thunderstorm.'' In four days, the German offensive had killed 2,600 Dutch civilians and 2,000 soldiers. It began a five-year occupation horror of starvation, slave labor and deportations to death camps. As Holland fell, von Rundstedt's tanks linked up with another German army group from the north to encircle British and French troops near the port of Dunkirk in northern France. Despite concentrated German air and artillery attacks, 340,000 Allied soldiers escaped to England over a 10-day period, most of them in small boats commandeered for the rescue. Brig. Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who later commanded the Free French forces from England, led one of the few French counteroffensives, near Abbeville in the northwest. The Germans bombed Abbeville to rubble May 20. ``There was nothing left after the bombing,'' said Louis Werheim, who was 6 at the time. Werheim and his family fled before the raid. When they returned, he said, ``There were bodies of French soldiers in our courtyard. They'd been shot by the Germans.'' On June 22, France agreed to an armistice. Two-thirds of its territory was occupied and a collaborationist government under Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, the World War I hero, ran the unoccupied southeastern sector. About 1.5 million French soldiers were taken prisoner and held until the end of the war. Civilian hardship followed military surrender. Men were shipped from the occupied countries to work as slave labor in the German war industry. The Netherlands, then primarily an agricultural economy, was gradually stripped of food to feed the conquerors. Starvation spread through the country. The ``hunger winter'' of 1944 is one of the Dutch people's strongest collective memories. Nazi officials used the Dutch penchant for keeping meticulous records to track down the country's 150,000 Jews, and shipped them to death camps. Only 6,000 survived. The most famous war victim in the the Netherlands was Anne Frank, a Jewish teenager born in Germany whose diary, written in hiding with her family, is perhaps the most poignant memorial to the death camps. Most of the Jews in Belgium, Luxembourg and France also died in the camps. Anti-Nazi underground movements were organized in the occupied countries. After the Dutch surrender, Stam used his position with the Nazi-run Amsterdam Labor Bureau to obtain ration cards for Jews and resistance fighters in hiding, and to hamper deportation of workers for slave labor. Dekker, the office boy, was 18 when the Germans sent him to Hamburg to work in a shipyard. He spent three years there and returned after the war with a busload of Dutch Jews who survived the Neuengamme concentration camp near Hamburg.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6
$Adv06
For Release Sunday, May 6, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Germany's Once-Conquered Neighbors Now Its Partners
With Invasion Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Fifty years ago, Hitler's blitzkrieg overran Belgium, the Netherlands and France. Now they are partners of Germany, but cautious about the prospect of a unified powerhouse next door. The French, whose Maginot Line could not stop the Germans, now lead an effort to guarantee them a central role in a single-market Western Europe. French, Belgian and Dutch officials say the closer the ties the better, suggesting a non-aligned Germany would cause greater concern. ``I have always believed the arbitrary division of Germany was senseless,'' said Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, ``but the situation inherited from the war cannot be improved without the participation of other countries.'' West Germany is the largest trading partner of all three countries conquered by German forces in a six-week onslaught that began May 10, 1940. Its relationship with France is particularly close, encompassing everything from military cooperation to cultural television programming. ``French-German friendship is more alive than ever,'' President Francois Mitterrand, once a German prisoner of war, said at the end of a harmonious two-day summit in late April with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. In Normandy, which was devastated by the battles that followed the Allied invasion of June 1944, dozens of towns have established ``twin city'' relationships with German municipalities. State-owned Aerospatiale of France recently began a joint helicopter production project with Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm, which made many of Hitler's warplanes. Among the most vivid symbols of French-German reconciliation is a joint army brigade, 2,100 soldiers from each country, being deployed in West Germany. Brigade officers have overcome language difficulties and even a potential wardrobe dispute. The men will wear French-style blue berets, but tilt them to the right in accordance with German custom. Klaus Becher and Ingo Kolboom, of the Research Institute of the German Society for Foreign Policy, have proposed stationing additional French-German brigades in East Germany after unification, to replace Soviet troops. The French-German relationship dates to a treaty signed in 1963 by President Charles de Gaulle and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. The governments have closer and more systematic consultation on political, military and economic matters than any other two in Western Europe. Polls indicate the French and Germans consider each other their closest foreign friends. Kohl and Mitterrand embodied this sentiment in 1984 when they joined hands at Verdun, the World War I battle site, in dedicating a plaque consecrating the reconciliation of France and Germany. There appear to be few plans for marking the 50th anniversary of the German entry into Paris, June 14, or the French surrender June 22. ``The French don't like to celebrate defeat,'' said Dominique Moisi, associate director of the French Institute of Foreign Relations. He suggested the French would focus on De Gaulle, who on June 18, 1940, made his first radio appeal from England to his countrymen to resist the occupation. Moisi said in an interview that fear of a powerful united Germany is based ``more on the French lack of confidence in their ability to compete than mistrust of Germany.'' Political analyst Pierre Lellouche wrote in Le Point magazine: ``In Paris, where they officially pretend to rejoice at German unity ... they worry in private about its consequences,'' Some French officials anticipate the development of a German superpower that would ``reduce France to a secondary role,'' he said. Wolfgang Bergsdorf, a Kohl adviser, cited a poll recently indicating 68 percent of French people favored German unification. ``Unhappily, the politicians in France, in contrast to the general population, are reticent now that German unity has become more than a sacred wish,'' Bergsdorf said. The Belgian and Dutch economies are even more intertwined with West Germany than the French. The Dutch guilder exchange rate closely follows the Deutschmark and Holland's interest rates are virtually based on the West German central bank's prime rate. Queen Beatrix and her mother, Juliana, are married to Germans. Both husbands gained acceptance by learning Dutch and trying to understand the country, but the Dutch tend to view Germans as arrogant and authoritarian. Resentment of the wartime occupation is largely responsible, and German tourists who assume everyone speaks their language and accepts their currency reinforce the attitude. Shopkeepers in the border city of Enschede asked West Germans to stay away May 5, the anniversary of liberation from the Nazis. ``We don't think it's appropriate to be confronted with Germans then, especially for older people who have been through the war,'' a spokesman, B.A. Sassen, told the Amsterdam newspaper De Telegraaf. Holland's European Cup soccer victory over West Germany in 1988 inspired much anti-German emotion. Teen-agers born decades after the war took to the streets chanting ``How the Krauts are silent!'' and ``Revenge at last!'' A reporter asked a Dutch official at a European Economic Community meeting in December why his delegation seemed reluctant to mention World War II. ``We have certainly not forgotten the war,'' he said, ``but you must understand that, with Germany being a major partner, we cannot say these things publicly. So we let the Russians say them.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6
$Adv06
For Release Sunday, May 6, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: German Tanks Rolled Around French Fortifications
With Invasion Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The French thought the next war would be as static as the last and built the Maginot Line to be an impregnable defense, so the Germans changed the rules and bypassed it with tanks and planes. A generation of officers on both sides learned in World War I that unprotected infantry had little chance against artillery barrages and machine-gun fire. The French decided they needed fortifications against which German divisions would hurl themselves until they weakened and could be driven back. The Germans decided to go around and over fortifications with new forms of attack: paratroops, dive bombers and, above all, the battle tank. France's line was named for Andre Maginot, defense minister in 1929-32, and stretched along 200 miles of the border with Germany. It included artillery protected by concrete 10 feet thick. Railroad tracks sunk into concrete formed barriers to stop tanks until gunners could blow them to pieces. Many fortifications were underground, connected by a subterranean railway. Tens of thousands of soldiers could live in the vast bunkers. ``We are always the invaded, we are always the ones who suffer, we are always the ones to be sacrificed,'' said Maginot, who was wounded in World War I. He died after eating bad oysters at a New Year's banquet in 1932. His fortifications were strong, but not long enough. An agreement made before World War I committed France to defend Belgium if it was attacked. French politicians felt extending the line to the English Channel would imply their generals preferred hiding in bunkers to defending Belgian territory. That left a doorway 200 miles wide, including some of the most tank-friendly country in Europe, if Hitler chose to violate Belgian neutrality. When France and Britain declared war on Germany after it invaded Poland, most of France's army waited in the Maginot bunkers for a German attack that never came. Nine months of ``phony war'' eroded morale and readiness. A politician who visited the Maginot Line wrote of being greeted by a senior officer wearing bedroom slippers. French headquarters fell into despair after Belgium and the Netherlands collapsed. The subsequent evacuation from Dunkirk left the coastal plains of northern France wide open. Field Marshal Heinz Guderian's panzers breached the Somme in force June 5. Within a week, 49 German divisions had crushed virtually all defenses in northern and eastern France. On June 13, the Wehrmacht turned on the Maginot line and captured it from the rear. More than 500,000 men were taken prisoner, most without firing a shot at the enemy, and France signed an armistice June 22. Some of the bunkers now are open to the public, as relics of military history. Others are used as mushroom farms.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6

DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court gave state governments and consumers a potential pocketbook victory, saying they may use federal antitrust law to try to break up corporate mergers. The unanimous decision announced Monday empowers California officials to challenge a $2.5 billion merger of the Lucky and Alpha Beta supermarket chains. If the state wins its lawsuit and splits up the business deal, officials said California consumers could save $440 million a year in grocery bills.

The Belzberg family of Canada claimed to have won a seat on the board of Armstrong World Industries Inc., the company that prompted Pennsylvania's tough new anti-takeover law. The disclosure came at the Armstrong's annual shareholders meeting Monday just three days after the state enacted the law designed to stymie corporate raiders. Armstrong Chairman William H. Adams said he was confident at least three of the four incumbent board members seeking re-election were retained.

Michael Milken may be entitled to a tax break on at least part of $400 million the fallen junk bond king is placing in a government fund to compensate injured investors, legal experts said. Such a deduction may appear startling for an admitted felon _ Milken pleaded guilty last week to six criminal securities and tax law violations _ but the experts said Monday it could be perfectly legal under Internal Revenue Service guidelines.

Americans' savings rate rose to 5.8 percent of their disposable income in March as consumer spending failed to match the increase in personal incomes, the government reported. Consumer spending rose 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion, the Commerce Department reported Monday. The department said personal incomes grew 0.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.67 trillion.

High mortgage interest rates continued to hammer new home sales in March, driving them down 5 percent in the fourth consecutive monthly decline, the government said. The Commerce Department said Monday new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 574,000 units in March after dropping a revised 1.5 percent in February. Sales originally were reported to have risen 3.1 percent in February.

Ames Department Stores Inc., which filed for federal bankruptcy protection last week, replaced its chief executive officer with a merchandising veteran likely to trim staff and close stores to revive the ailing discounter. Stephen L. Pistner, former chairman at Montgomery Ward & Co. and president at Dayton-Hudson Corp.'s Target discount stores, was named Monday by the board of directors to replace Peter B. Hollis, who resigned as CEO and vice chairman.

Western Union Co. announced a plan to restructure $530 million in debt in an effort to avoid a bankruptcy court filing. Under terms of the plan disclosed Monday, the company would exchange up to $530 million in principal amount of outstanding debt for new debt securities and common stock. Western Union faces a June 15 deadline to make a $51 million interest payment.

A federal judge extended a court order barring a Manhattan securities brokerage from penny stock sales activities that regulators allege are illegal. U.S. District Judge Kevin T. Duffy in New York issued an opinion Monday that temporarily bars Wellshire Securities Inc., two of its top officers and two former employees from further alleged securities law violations.

General Motors Corp. signed a three-year agreement with the National Broadcasting Co. that NBC executives called the largest commitment any advertiser has ever made for TV commercial time. The automaker and NBC refused to disclose the value of the deal, but one executive familiar with it and speaking on condition of anonymity said it was for slightly less than $700 million. The agreement involves GM advertising for its cars, trucks and automotive services on prime-time programs and National Football League games on the NBC TV network and on the cable networks CNBC and Sports Channel America.

The stock market was mixed Monday with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rising 11.71 to 2,656.76 while other indicators fell. The dollar ended mixed against key foreign currencies. Bond prices were mostly higher. Gold futures prices fell moderately while grains, soybeans, oil futures, livestock and meat futures all were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says Networks Skirting Ad Ban
DOC.TEXT: A congressman who opposes smoking says television networks are breaking the law against broadcasting cigarette advertisements by showing billboards at sports events. ``Somewhere someone decided that Congress didn't mean it and that this is not a statute that is going to be enforced,'' Rep. Thomas Luken, D-Ohio, said Monday. ``Nobody seems to care. ``The Justice Department has said in the past they don't believe it is the best use of scant prosecutorial resources to run these things down.'' Luken's comments came after a hearing at which he accused the networks of colluding with the cigarette industry to skirt the law. ``Capital Cities-ABC and RJR Nabisco (makers of Winston, Salem and Camel cigarettes) jointly own ESPN cable television,'' he said. ``Loews, which owns all of Lorillard Tobacco (makers of Kent, Newport and True) also owns about 25 percent of CBS.'' The networks make a lot of money broadcasting sporting events sponsored by cigarette companies whose logos continually show up on the screen, said Luken, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on transportation and hazardous materials. If the TV camera can't avoid the logo, the network shouldn't broadcast the event, he said. Executives from NBC, CBS and ABC all said that displaying billboards during sports coverage is often unavoidable and they don't consider it against the ban on television cigarette advertising that has been in effect since 1971. In auto racing, for example, arenas are adorned with ads that the vehicles continually drive by, said Richard Gitter, NBC vice president of standards and practices. The tobacco companies make the deal to display their logos with the arena and the network must either accept the event with the advertising or not broadcast it, said Gitter. Alfred Schneider, ABC vice president for policy and standards, said his network tries to keep such billboards off camera. ``The only references to the cigarette company which we permit are for the purpose of identifying the event by its proper name,'' said Schneider. Luken also said the television industry isn't doing enough to publicize the health hazards of smoking, even when the public pushes for it. He noted that the excise tax on cigarettes in California was raised on public demand to pay for anti-smoking advertisements on television. ``These ads are controversial, and one network, Capital Cities-ABC, has refused to run one of these ads,'' Luken said. All the executives said their networks had broadcast warnings about cigarette smoking. But Gitter said NBC's priority right now is alcohol and drug abuse. Schneider said ABC is concentrating on anti-drug abuse and literacy messages. Beth Waxman Bressan, a CBS vice president, said her network fed affiliates 2,200 public service messages last year on a wide variety of topics including alcohol abuse, AIDS, the environment and smoking and health. Under questioning from Luken, however, she said she did not know how many actually aired.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 1,929,000 net tons during the week ending April 28, 1990, down 1.3 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The week's production represented 85.8 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,044,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 32,309,000 net tons, 4.4 percent below last year's production at this time, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses). North East Coast 230,000 tons (234,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 314,000 tons (319,000 tons); Lake Erie 152,000 tons (157,000 tons); Detroit 160,000 tons (161,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 488,000 tons (496,000 tons); Midwest 193,000 tons (194,000); Southern 284,000 tons (285,000 tons); Western 108,000 tons (108,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Up, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices closed higher today despite early losses, while the dollar declined against the Japanese yen in thin holiday week trading. The dollar closed at 158.90 yen, down 0.18 yen from Friday. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, which lost 45.21 points in the morning session, closed at 29,689.83, up 105.03 points, or 0.36 percent. The index gained 160.22 points Friday. Japan's markets are open only Tuesday and Wednesday this week because of the ``Golden Week'' series of holidays . As a result, said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., trading was extremely thin and ``almost nothing was happening.'' Volume on the first section was estimated at 230 million shares, down from Friday's 480 million shares. Dealers said the foreign exchange market also was inactive because of the holidays.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Prices Up 0.7 Percent in April
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Prices received by farmers last month rose 0.7 percent from their March average, according to preliminary figures released by the Agriculture Department. The April increase lifted the department's ``prices received'' index 2 percent above the year-earlier average. But revisions reported Monday also showed the index has declined about 2 percent from the record level set in January. A month ago, preliminary figures for March showed an increase in the price index. Instead, there was a decline from February to March. John Buche of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said the downward swing in the March index instead of the increase initially reported a month ago was due primarily to price declines for vegetables and some other crops in the last half of the month. Preliminary prices are reported mostly on the basis of mid-month averages and then updated the following month. Thus, the preliminary April figures will be revised in the May report. According to the latest revisions, the index rose 3.4 percent in January from its December average before dropping 1.3 percent in both February and March. Prices of raw agricultural products can swing widely during a single month, and for that reason and others are not considered reliable indicators by themselves of overall food price trends at the consumer level. Higher prices for oranges, corn, potatoes and cattle were mostly responsible for the overall price increase from March, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. Lower prices for tomatoes, milk, eggs and broilers partly offset the gains for the other commodities. Most prices are mid-April averages that will be revised next month. New quarterly figures showed prices paid by farmers to meet expenses were up 1.1 percent from January and averaged 3.4 percent more than in April 1989. ``Since January, higher prices for feeder pigs and feeder cattle and calves were moderated by lower fuel and energy prices,'' the report said. Prices of cars and trucks, farm chemicals, tractors and self-propelled machinery were generally up from last year's surveys. Most retail seed prices were lower than a year ago. USDA economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $54 billion to $58 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. Another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $45 billion to $49 billion, compared with $49 billion last year. Consumer food prices are forecast by USDA economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Based on the preliminary figures, the April price index for livestock and poultry dropped 1.2 percent from March but still averaged 9.7 percent more than a year earlier. Milk prices dropped an additional 60 cents in April to an average of $13.10 per l00 pounds. Even so, the preliminary April price was up 70 cents from April 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 per hundredweight in December. Crop prices, overall, rose 3.1 percent from March but averaged 7 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices, led by oranges and grapefruit, were up 11 percent from March and by the same margin of 11 percent from a year ago. The index for commercial vegetables dropped 13 percent from March and averaged 28 percent below the year-earlier level, reflecting abundant tomato supplies and low prices. Tomato prices were reported at $16 per 100 pounds, down from $32.80 in March and $55.80 in April 1989. Onions, however, rose to $23 per 100 pounds from $19.60 in March and $10.90 a year earlier. Prices of potatoes and dry beans, which are measured collectively, increased 14 percent from March to April and were up 13 percent from a year earlier. The report said: _Cattle averaged $75 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $74.20 in March and $70.10 in April 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $52.90 per 100 pounds, compared with $51.30 in March and $36.90 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.52 a bushel, was up from $2.37 in March but was just short of the $2.56 year-earlier average. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.51 per bushel, compared with $3.49 in March and $4.03 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.26 per 100 pounds, compared with $7.50 in March and $6.74 in April 1989. _Soybeans were $5.62 per bushel, compared with $5.65 in March and $7.29 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 64.8 cents per pound, up from 64.1 in March and 58.7 a year earlier. _Eggs were 71.4 cents per dozen, compared with 79.3 in March and 66.1 in April 1989. _Milk was $13.10 per 100 pounds, down from $13.70 in March but above the average of $12.40 a year ago. _Broilers were 33.2 cents per pound, live weight, down from 36.4 cents in March and from 39.1 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Japan Announces Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of Japan announced a major restructuring Tuesday aimed at strengthening the central bank's monetary operations and its ability to monitor financial institutions at home and abroad. The reorganization, which goes into effect on May 28, will reduce the number of departments at the central bank from 18 to 16. The reorganization is designed to help the Bank of Japan better cope with the continued globalization of financial markets. The central bank said it will set up a ``market operations'' division to monitor both money and capital markets and to execute daily monetary operations in a comprehensive manner. The central bank said two divisions _ the bank relations division and the capital markets division _ will ``oversee the activities of financial institutions both at home and abroad in their daily monitoring of banks and securities houses, respectively.'' In addition, the central bank said a new financial and payment system department will be set up to cope with the increased risks to the financial system posed by the trends toward financial deregulation, globalization and computerization. A new international department will combine the current foreign department with the overseas research function of the research and statistics department. To expand the central bank's international network, the Hong Kong office will be made the Bank of Japan's third chief representative office serving Asia and Oceania, joining New York for North and South America, and London for Europe, Africa and the Middle East. Another representative office will be added to Washington, D.C., bringing the number of representative offices to six.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Supplier Escapes Arab Blacklist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Baxter International Inc., a hospital supply company that was on the Arab League's blacklist, was taken off the list after selling a plant in Israel and opening another in Syria, a newspaper reported today. Baxter executives have denied that the company sought to curry favor from the League by selling the plant in Israel, a move that would violate a U.S. law forbidding American companies from participating in a foreign boycott, The Wall Street Journal said. The plants in Israel and Syria both synthesize intravenous body fluids. Jewish leaders are demanding an explanation from Baxter. A memorandum on file in the Arab League's boycott office in the Syrian capitol of Damascus suggests the sale and the delisting were linked, the newspaper said. A Washington businessman and former Baxter official, Dr. Richard Fuisz, gave the Journal a copy of the memo and documents about Baxter's Middle East operations. Fuisz had sent another memo copy to the Baxter directors. The memo says Baxter sought removal from the blacklist through its Swiss subsidiary, Baxter AG. It also says that another subsidiary, International Medical Technologies, provided documentation of the sale of Baxter's Israel plant and promised not to do any more business with Israel, the Journal reported. Baxter senior vice president and general counsel, G. Marshall Abbey, said International Medical Technologies did not supply information directly to the League's committee. He also said the company has not violated the law. The company said it never contacted the boycott committee to ask to be taken off the list, the Journal said. Abbey said the directors' audit committee has hired a lawyer from the New York firm of Calwalader, Wickersham & Taft to conduct an independent investigation. Neither the Commerce Department nor the Securities and Exchange Commission, which are reviewing the company's Middle East activities, would comment. Jess N. Hordes, Washington director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said the circumstances ``raise serious questions about the process Baxter went through'' in getting off the blacklist.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler First-Quarter Earnings Down 80 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said today its earnings tumbled 80 percent during the first quarter as it wrestled with budget cuts, heavy incentive costs and slumping market share. The No. 3 automaker said it earned $71 million, or 32 cents a share during the quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $351 million, or $1.50 a share in the year-ago period. The earnings came on revenues of $7.56 billion, down 22 percent from $9.66 billion reported in the first quarter of last year. Chrysler's stock slipped 25 cents a share to close at a 52-week low of $14.50 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading on Monday. Wall Street analysts had predicted marginal earnings for the company. No. 1 General Motors Corp. and No. 2 Ford Motor Co. are expected to report first-quarter earnings later this week. ``We posted a profit in our automotive operations despite lower volumes and incentive costs nearly double what they were a year ago,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said in a statement. In January, Chrysler offered a first-time, $1,000 incentive on its popular minivans. That offer pumped up sales of the most popular line of minivans in the United States, but ate into profits. At the end of the first quarter, Chrysler held 11.4 percent of the domestic car market, down from 12.9 percent a year earlier. Through the end of March, automakers had sold about 1.7 million domestically made cars, a 1.3 percent decline from a year earlier. Chrysler is in the midst of a $1.5-billion cost-cutting program, which Iacocca said is aiding profitability. The earnings statement did not disclose how much of the cost-cutting target has been realized, but Chrysler officials have said the bulk of the cuts were made shortly after the program began in October. It should be completed by the end of this year. Chrysler Financial Corp., which handles the automaker's consumer and dealer financing and insurance among other things, reported an $89 million profit, up from $86 million posted during the fourth quarter of last year. As a whole, the corporation lost $664 million during the final quarter of 1989, mostly because of a $577 million one-time charge for plant closings, discontinuation of some cars and pension and severance expenses under the cost-cutting program. The company also said today that it had $1.85 billion in cash and cash equivalents on hand at the end of March, down from $2.01 billion last year. During the first quarter, Chrysler bought about 1.4 million shares of its own stock in efforts to reduce the number of outstanding shares to 200 million. At the end of the quarter there were 221.4 million shares of common stock outstanding, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Falls in March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: a

Construction spending fell in March for the first time this year, the government said today, down 1.4 percent as the weather returned to normal and mortgage interest rates continued to rise. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $432.5 billion after jumps of 3.2 percent in February and 2.4 percent in January. The decline was the largest since a 1.5 percent fall in February 1989. Despite the drop, spending was 3.8 percent above that of March 1989, when it totaled $416.8 billion. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, had said after the February report that construction spending would begin to lose its seasonal benefit in March. ``We expect it to start leveling off, if not decline, because it will no longer have the seasonal boost and also because of increasing interest rates,'' he said. After the fourth coldest December on record, January broke the record as the warmest. February also was unseasonably warm and temperatures during both months induced builders to get construction under way early. Mortgage rates, which started the year in the single digits, ranged between 10.22 percent and 10.34 percent during March, when temperatures also returned to normal. Residential building continued to rise in March, up 1.8 percent to an annual rate of $203.2 billion on top of gains of 1.5 percent in February and 3.8 percent in January. Single-family building edged up 0.2 percent to $122.5 billion after a 3.6 percent advance in February and a 2.3 percent gain a month earlier. Apartment construction was unchanged at $20.7 billion after falling 2.4 percent in February and 1.0 percent the previous month. Non-residential building also was off, down 4.7 percent to $101.1 billion after gains of 5.8 percent in February and 5.5 percent in January. The volatile government sector dropped 4.8 percent to $90.7 billion after rising 5.0 percent in February and falling 3.2 percent in January. Spending on highways and streets was down 11.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Wants Seidman Out, Says Published Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: By DAVE SKIDMORE=

President Bush wants Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman to resign, The Washington Post reported today, quoting unnamed administration sources. Bush, in a meeting with the top S&L bailout official two weeks ago, reportedly suggested now would be a good time for the 69-year old Seidman to leave, the newspaper said. He had been appointed by President Reagan in 1985 and his term expires in 1991. Seidman, in a telephone interview from Michigan, declined to comment on the story today and said he had promised not to divulge what he discussed with the president. However, he noted that in the past he has said he planned to leave his post after getting the bailout agency off to a good start. A month ago, he announced ambitious plans to sell or close 140 S&Ls by the end of June and, Seidman said today, ``That would be a good start.'' An industry source, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said White House officials confirmed that they would not stand in Seidman's way if he leaves. The chairman of the FDIC serves independently and cannot be fired by the president. But the Post, quoting ``two administration sources familiar with the meeting,'' said Bush wants to name his own chairman. ``It's no secret we would not be upset if he leaves. It's not like we're trying to talk him into staying,'' the newspaper quoted a source present at the meeting as saying. White House press spokesmen did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Seidman, who enjoys strong support from both Democrats and Republicans in Congress, has been dropping hints for nearly a year that he would not serve out his term. He has feuded with Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu over the conduct of the bailout. However, he also has given no indication of leaving immediately. The chairman of the FDIC is considered the most powerful banking regulator, although the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board has more influence over the economy. The five-member FDIC board administers deposit insurance funds for both commercial banks and savings and loans. The agency is the chief federal regulator of state-chartered banks and back-up regulator of S&Ls and federally-chartered banks. The board also manages the Resolution Trust Corp., which supervises the sale and closing of insolvent thrifts. Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, said a leading candidate to replace Seidman is Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke. Clarke's office regulates national banks and he sits on the FDIC board.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Aiming for Two Directors on Texas Air's Board
DOC.TEXT: A group that holds a large chunk of Texas Air Corp. bonds said it plans to elect two additional directors to the company's board after it failed to pay a dividend for six quarters in a row. PaineWebber Inc., which holds about 30 percent of Texas Air's 6.75 percent junior preferred stock, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday that it will exercise its right to add two directors to the 11-member board. The director rule takes effect after six consecutive dividends are missed, according to Texas Air, parent of Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines. PaineWebber is the second party to give such notice to the SEC. Last week, Mark Schwarzman, a Connecticut investor, said he controls 6.8 percent of the same class of preferred stock and may seek representation on the board. Analysts said the continued non-payment of dividends would have little effect on the already low-rated debt. Texas Air's own financial picture is overshadowed by troubles at its Eastern subsidiary. A federal bankruptcy judge recently appointed a special trustee to take control of Miami-based Eastern away from Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo. In a recent financial report, Texas Air said it had not paid dividends on three of its four preferred stock issues since the third quarter of 1988. At the end of 1989, the airline company reported it was $25.3 million behind on payment of its preferred dividends. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent said Monday the company will propose its slate of directors by May 7, the mailing deadline for proxy statements to be sent to shareholders. Texas Air's annual meeting is scheduled for June 6. Houston-based Continental reported first-quarter earnings Monday of $21.3 million, compared with a net loss of $16.5 million in the same period in 1989. Continental normally reports its earnings as part of the quarterly financial statement of Texas Air. But Kent said Texas Air's financial report was being delayed while company officials assess the effect of the bankruptcy judge's decision to shift control of Eastern.

DOC.HEAD: Partnership Seeking to Install Own Nominees on Pic 'N' Save Board
DOC.TEXT: A partnership interested in taking over Pic 'N' Save Corp. said Tuesday it has started the process of trying to have its own nominees elected to the retailer's board of directors. Girard Partners, a Texas limited partnership, said it is seeking ``to remove five of the seven incumbent directors of the company, to elect three nominees of the partnership to constitute a majority of the board and to adopt a stockholder resolution to facilitate that effort.'' The group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has begun soliciting proxies from the retail chain's shareholders. Representatives of Girard Partners met with Pic 'N' Save on April 28, the filing said. The partnership representatives said at the meeting that ``they believe a sale of the company is the most desirable alternative'' to nhance value to stockholders. At the meeting, the partnership ``delivered a letter requesting that it be granted access to nonpublic financial and other information'' regarding Pic 'N' Save ``in connection with formulating an acquisition proposal, and stating that it would be willing to enter into appropriate confidentiality arrangements ...'' The filing made no reference to the size of Girard Partners' stake in Pic 'N' Save stock. In an April 11 SEC filing, the partnership had said it owned 6.6 percent of Pic 'N' Save and planned a takeover bid for the close-out chain. Girard Partners is led by David H. Batchelder, who served as T. Boone Pickens chief strategist until 1988. Another member of the group is Robert H. McNulty, president and chief executive of the HQ Office Supplies Warehouse retail chain and a founder of the Home Club chain. The April 11 filing said Girard Partners would seek control of the Pic 'N' Save board. Pic 'N' Save, based in the Dominguez suburb of Los Angeles, had about $400 million in sales last year and has about 5,000 employees. It buys manufacturers' close-out merchandise and sells it at deep discounts to customers.

DOC.HEAD: Inside Trader Recounts Downfall in Magazine Article
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 4:30 pm EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Admitted inside trader Dennis Levine, whose arrest led to the fall of Ivan Boesky and other Wall Street figures, said his values eroded in the deal-crazy 1980s, when million-dollar profits seemed ``insignificant.'' ``I will regret my mistakes forever,'' the former investment banker said in a first-person article in the May 21 issue of Fortune magazine, which was released Tuesday. ``No one led me down the garden path,'' Levine said. ``... For the hard work and creativity I brought to my investment banking career, I was well rewarded. When I broke the law, I was punished. The system works.'' It was Levine's first public comment on the illegal dealings that ended with his 1986 arrest since he was released from federal prison last year. Levine repeatedly has refused interview requests. Levine has set up his own mergers and acquisitions advisory firm and has lectured on ethics at top business schools including Columbia and New York universities and the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. A Fortune spokeswoman said Levine was paid to write the article. She declined to specify the amount but said it was a ``normal freelance fee.'' In the article, a repentant Levine traces his rise from a middle-class Queens, N.Y., neighborhood to a managing director's suite at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., from which he helped major takeover deals. Levine was involved in some of the 1980s biggest deals, including Ronald Perelman's takeover of Revlon Inc. and Carl Icahn's proxy fight against Phillips Petroleum Co. ``The daily exposure to such deals, the pursuit of larger and larger transactions and the numbing effect of 60- to 100-hour work weeks helped erode my values and distort my judgment,'' Levine said. ``In this unbelieveable world of billions and billions of dollars, the millions I made by trading on nonpublic information seemed almost insignificant,'' he said. In his illicit dealings, Levine parlayed $39,750 _ much of it borrowed from family members _ into $11.5 million over seven years using illegal tips on upcoming deals. He set up offshore bank accounts and left instructions on how his trades were to be handled to avoid detection. Levine had a network of sophisticated insiders with whom he would swap deal information. Levine said Boesky, the former stock speculator, would call him at home ``well before 6 a.m.'' to ferret out information before trading. Levine said he would have gotten $2.4 million for supplying Boesky with information, but ``never received a penny'' because he was arrested first. Levine served 15 months in a federal prison camp in Pennsylvania. Using information supplied by Levine, federal investigators nailed Boesky, who paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle insider trading charges. Boesky was released from federal custody in April after serving two years of a three-year term. Levine said his scheme began crumbling when several bank executives were detected mimicking his trades, which were executed via a Swiss bank in the Bahamas. With the government in hot pursuit, Levine said he drove around Manhattan in his BMW, frantically calling his family and lining up an attorney on the car phone. His unsuspecting wife, Laurie, was ``furious,'' he said. Pleading guilty to four criminal charges before a federal judge was a ``humbling experience,'' perhaps as difficult as watching his daughter learn to walk in a prison waiting room, he said. Levine said he has formed Adasar Group, an advisory firm he named after his children, Adam and Sarah. Though barred for life from working for a securities firm, Levine is allowed to advise companies. Levine said his clients are ``smaller than they used to be,'' but he said his re-entry into the business world has been met with ``fairness and compassion.'' The magazine hits newsstands Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Break After Strong Rally; Grains Follow
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of grain and soybeans closed mostly lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by a late break in the soybean market after a technically inspired rally drove prices to new nine-month highs. The heavy trading volume and whipsaw action recalled the drought summer of 1988, when soybean prices swung wildly after each new bit of weather data, said Jerry Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade. But unlike two years ago, Tuesday's rally was driven almost entirely by bullish technical patterns, he said. ``I haven't heard any good fundamental explanations for why we ran up,'' Zusel said. Soybeans for May delivery touched $6.55 a bushel, the highest price for a near-month soybean contract since July 28, before the rally ran out of steam. ``The buying dried up, the selling picked up and the lower you got the more selling you ran into,'' Zusel said. He said the grain markets basically followed soybeans higher, then retreated as soybean prices fell. At the close of trading, wheat futures were 6\ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.68 a bushel; corn was 2\ cents lower to 3 cents higher with May at $2.84 a bushel; oats were } cent to 1} cents lower with May at $1.63{ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5 cents lower with May at $6.29 a bushel.
