DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Manufacturing Sector Showed Slight Growth In April
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. industrial sector expanded slightly during April for the first time in a year, led by sharp gains in new orders and exports, the nation's purchasing managers said in a survey released Tuesday. Economists said last month's data, although stronger than expected, hardly pointed to an economic rebound. Most of the surveyed manufacturers remained reluctant to add new jobs or expand their inventories, they said. In addition, a government report released Tuesday showed the recent rise in interest rates was depressing construction, a major component of economic growth. Spending for residential, non-residential and government building fell 1.4 percent in March to a 13-month low, the Commerce Department said. ``I still think we're dealing with an economy that is kind of sputtering,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief financial economist for Nikko Securities Co. International. ``It may not look like a recession but you have to draw the line well short of calling it vibrant.'' The National Association of Purchasing Management said its economic index rose to 50.2 percent in April from 48.8 percent the previous month. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy generally is expanding; below 50, that it is generally contracting. The April reading followed 11 straight monthly declines and was the highest since last April's 52.7 percent level, the group said in a news release from its Tempe, Ariz., headquarters. The index has averaged 48.1 percent for the first four months of 1990, consistent with a 1.3 percent rise in the gross national product, the group said. Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the trade group's business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc., said the improvement reflected a significant gain in new orders, particularly in exports. ``The rebound should be sufficient to sustain solid production growth for several months and buoy the entire economy over the balance of the second quarter,'' he said. Some economists weren't as optimistic. ``We think growth in the second quarter could be less than it was in the first,'' said Carol Stone, a senior economist for Nomura Securities Inc. ``Businesses are still showing a cautious attitude.'' Stone said manufacturers have kept their inventories low and have been reluctant to permanantly fill jobs. Brusca said a significant portion of the growth reported in the April purchasing managers' report came from the volatile automobile sector. The report said new orders expanded for the third consecutive month during April. The new orders index jumped to 55.5 percent from 50.4 percent in March. New export orders were up for the 28th consecutive month, as the seasonally unadjusted index rose to 60.5 percent from 59.5 percent. The report said 74 percent of the group's members exported last month, up from 71 percent in March and a three year high. Imports increased for the fourth consecutive month but at a slower pace than March. Seventy-six percent of all members imported in April, down from 78 percent, the group said. The production portion of the survey gained ground for the third consecutive month during April, although growth was at a slower level than the previous month _ 53 percent vs. 54.4 percent. Declining for the 14th consecutive month was the employment portion of the survey, with the index falling to 45.1 percent from 45.2 percent. Members continued to report they were hiring temporary workers and working overtime to handle increasing production activity rather than hiring new employees, the group said. Inventories weakened for the 17th straight month. That index was unchanged from March at 41.6 percent _ the second-lowest level since December 1986. Supplier deliveries were faster in April for the 12th consecutive month. But 12 commodities were in short supply, including bearings, electric motors, timber and some chemicals, the group said. Meanwhile, prices of goods rose after falling for 10 consecutive months. About 17 commodities had higher prices, up from 11 in March, the group said. The purchasing managers' report is based on a monthly survey of purchasing executives at over 300 industrial companies. Most of the figures are adjusted for seasonal factors.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Formula Measure Loses But Will Stay on Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Bristol Myers-Squibb Co. shareholders on Tuesday overwhelmingly defeated a proposal that would have banned the consumer products giant from peddling infant formula directly to the public. But the measure received enough votes to remain on the agenda next year. The infant formula resolution, sponsored by 11 religious investors and supported by many pediatricians, received 16.56 million votes, or 4.9 percent of the total, at the company's annual meeting in Wilmington. More than 320.9 million votes were cast against, with 31.12 million absentions. The measure needed to gain at least 3 percent of the votes to remain on the ballot at the next annual meeting. A substantial part of the three-hour meeting was dominated by debate over the infant-formula resolution, which has aroused considerable interest as a contentious shareholder activist issue in the 1990 annual meeting season. The measure's supporters said Bristol Myers-Squibb is misleading the public by suggesting that its infant formula, marketed though Gerber Products Co., is as nutritious as breast milk. They say it departs from the industry tradition of promoting formula only to physicians. Since last October, television ads for the formula end with the phrase, ``If it doesn't come from you, shouldn't it come from Gerber?'' ``How can you persist in this commercially driven charade?'' said Dr. Frank A. Oski, chairman of the department of pediatrics at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and a representative of the American Academy of Pediatrics. He urged adoption of the resolution, which would make Bristol Myers-Squibb and Gerber stop marketing the formula directly to mothers. Richard Gelb, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, defended the marketing campaign by saying the advertisements make it clear that breast milk is superior to baby formula. ``We support breastfeeding as we have said, but we don't believe it's quite as cut and dried,'' Gelb told reporters after the meeting concluded. Shareholders also defeated measures that would have forced the company to provide information about animal testing, sever all ties to South Africa and create one-year terms for directors. Bristol Myers-Squibb, based in New York, is the result of the merger of the Bristol Myers and Squibb companies last year. It is the nation's 50th largest industrial corporation with revenue of more than $9.4 billion in 1989.

Prices advanced on Wall Street today as the stock market shrugged off an economic report that raised the specter of higher interest rates. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks the economy in the manufacturing sector by surveying its members each month, said its index rose to 50.2 percent in April from 48.8 percent in March. A reading above 50 generally indicates the economy is expanding. The news reawakened concerns in the financial markets that a stronger economy would allow inflation to accelerate, forcing the Federal Reserve to push interest rates higher. Bond prices, which had been up in early trading, surrendered their gains in response to the purchasing managers report, and the stock market initially followed suit. However, during the afternoon, blue chip issues regained ground and secondary stocks then caught on. Analysts said Wall Street was repeating what is becoming a classic performance _ losing ground after a negative report and then recovering as traders have second thoughts about how bad the news really is.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Profits, Sales Up at Emerson Electric
DOC.TEXT: Emerson Electric Co. said Tuesday that profits and sales both rose 5.6 percent in its second quarter, but that earnings were reduced because of the company's guilty plea to overcharging the Pentagon. The increases came from continued strength in Emerson's capital goods markets, which include assembly line machines, motors and drives, and gains made by various foreign subsidiaries and in overseas sales, the company said. Profits for the period ending March 31 were $156 million, or 70 cents a share, up from $148 million, or 66 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Sales were $1.9 billion, up from $1.8 billion for the same period in 1989. Emerson officials said earnings were reduced by more than $14 million because of Tuesday's guilty plea to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold to the Pentagon. The settlement, which included a $40,000 fine and a $14 million civil settlement, is about twice the amount that Emerson's subsidiary, Electronics & Space Corp., overcharged the Pentagon from 1983 to 1987. The guilty pleas to four counts of filing false statements ended a two-year investigation by the U.S. Attorney's office in St. Louis, the Defense Criminal Investigative Service, the Defense Contract Audit Agency and the Defense Logistics Agency. ``The settlement ... resolves a number of open issues, many of which preceded the investigation,'' company chairman and chief executive Charles Knight said in a statement. Emerson owns companies that make tools for Sears Roebuck Co., Skil power tools, ceiling fans, ladders and other products. The company is also a leading supplier of compressors for refrigerators, computer power systems and electric motors. For the first six months of 1990, Emerson's profits were $298 million, or $1.34 a share, up 4.7 percent from $285 million, or $1.27 a share, for the first six months of 1989. Sales for the first half were flat, $3.55 billion this year vs. $3.52 billion last year. ``Our capital goods-related businesses have record level backlogs and expect continued good sales performance, as do our international operations,'' Knight said. ``We are concerned, however, about the prospects for rising interest rates and softness in the domestic economy which will continue to impact our consumer-related businesses,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Texas Petroleum May Go on Block
DOC.TEXT: Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc. is considering putting itself on the auction block or taking other action to enhance the value of the nation's second-largest independent oil company. If sold, analysts say, the company could fetch $2.25 billion. The announcement Monday of a possible sale came after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., a leveraged buyout specialist, said it may sell its 40 percent holding in Union Texas Petroleum. If the oil company is sold for $25 a share, Kohlberg Kravis could earn a profit of about $750 million on stock it bought five years ago for $7.50 a share. Analysts speculated that Kohlberg Kravis agreed to the sale because it needs to shore up some souring investments. Kohlberg Kravis owns Safeway, Duracell and RJR Nabisco, which it took private last year in a $25 billion leveraged buyout, the largest in history. Allied Signal Inc., an aerospace and automotive parts conglomerate which owns 40 percent of Union Texas Petroleum, has previously said it wanted to sell its holding in the oil company. If it decides to put itself up for sale, Union Texas Petroleum said it does not expect the sale to be completed before November. A sale could mean lost jobs for many of the company's 1,900 employees, including 900 in Houston, if a major oil company buys it and consolidates operations or if Union Texas Petroleum assets are sold separately. High prices paid recently for oil and natural gas assets are the key to the board of directors' decision, said Carol L. Cox, a spokeswoman for Union Texas Petroleum. Houston oilman Roy M. Huffington last month sold his extensive Indonesian natural gas interests for an estimated $600 million to an affiliate of Taiwan's national oil company. The deal also included about $50 million in Houston real estate. Huffington was a partner with Union Texas Petroleum in an Indonesian partnership that is the largest gas producer in Indonesia _ one of the hottest exploration areas in the world. Union Texas Petroleum owns about 38 percent of the partnership. Union Texas Petroleum also has crude oil production and exploration operations in the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico, and a 42 percent interest and joint operation of an ethylene plant in Geismar, La.

DOC.HEAD: Cuts Two-Thirds of Jobs in British Equities
DOC.TEXT: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said Tuesday it was eliminating 20 of the 30 jobs in its British equities operation due to deteriorating trading conditions for London securities. ``Market conditions in the United Kingdom have quite simply forced us to re-assess commitment to the U.K. equities market,'' a Prudential-Bache spokesman in London said. ``We aren't abandoning the market, but are consolidating our efforts to allow us to continue providing a service in U.K. stocks on a cost-effective basis,'' said the spokesman, who requested anonymity. The job losses will be spread among sales, trading and research positions in the company's equities unit, known as Prudential-Bache Capital Funding (Equities) Ltd. The firm said it will retain a sales and trading capacity in its London office and will continue as a market maker in some British stocks. Prudential-Bache now serves as market maker in charge of trading for nine British stocks, including Hanson PLC, Glaxo Holdings PLC, British Petroleum PLC and Reuters Holdings PLC.

DOC.HEAD: Chevron Subsidiary To Sell Some Oil Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. said Tuesday it has agreed to sell certain Gulf of Mexico oil reserves for about $150 million to a New Orleans-based partnership. Chevron U.S.A., the domestic oil and gas subsidiary of Chevron Corp., said it will sell its Main Pass 299 shallow oil reserves to avoid the costs and other problems tied to co-development of oil, gas and sulphur resources. The reserves, estimated at 35 million to 50 million barrels of oil, will be bought by Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners Limited Partnership, an affiliate of Freeport-McMoran Inc. Chevron U.S.A. said it will receive $137 million, plus reimbursement for about $13 million in costs connected with the development of the reserves. A final contract is expected by the end of the second quarter, the company said. The reserves are located about 90 miles southeast of New Orleans, in the same reservoir as Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners' sulphur reserves. Chevron said it will continue its oil and gas operations on other portions of the reserve. The company also has the right, under certain circumstances, to take part in proceeds of future production if the price of volumes exceed certain levels. Frank Robin, eastern region vice president for Chevron U.S.A., said the sale agreement is not related to previously announced asset sales by the corporation.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Issues New Incentive Program for May
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Tuesday announced a new car and light truck incentive program with cash rebates ranging from $500 to $4,000 and financing rates from 6.9 percent to 10.9 percent. The program, in effect until May 31, applies to 20 1990-model cars and trucks, the 1989{ Mercury Tracer and 1988 and 1989 models of the discontinued Merkur XR4Ti. Rebates range from $700 for the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz to $4,000 for the Merkur. Two-year loans on the 1990 Escort and the Tracer carry 6.9 percent interest. Most two-year loans on other vehicles covered by the program carry 7.9-percent interest rates. Rates go up, depending on the length of the loan, to 10.9 percent for five-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Earnings Down Just 80 Percent; That's Good News, Analysts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Chrysler stock... to UPDATE with closing stock price. Picks up 7th graf, Last October...
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Tuesday its first quarter profit tumbled 79.8 percent from last year, and Wall Street analysts said that without a company cost-cutting program the slide would have been even worse. A slumping auto market and the soaring costs of incentives aimed at reviving sales helped push Chrysler's net income down to $71 million, or 32 cents a share, in the first three months of the year. That was down from $351 million, or $1.50 a share, in the year-earlier quarter but it bettered analyst estimates that Chrysler earnings would be around the break-even point. ``It shows the leanness and meanness of management hammering home on the cost-cutting front,'' auto analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York said of the earnings report. First-quarter revenue dropped to $7.56 billion from $9.66 billion in the same period last year. Chrysler stock finished up 75 cents at $15.25 a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. Monday's close had been a 52-week low. Last October, Chrysler began a program to slice $1.5 billion from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year, partly by eliminating about 2,500 white-collar jobs. Some of the expense stemming from the cuts, such as severance pay, was written off in the fourth quarter. Chrysler lost $664 million during that quarter due largely to a $577 million writeoff that covered plant closings and some of the cost-cutting expenses. Analysts have predicted that earnings would fall more than 75 percent for General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., which report their results later this week. Chrysler appears to be heading toward its cost-cutting target, analysts said, estimating the automaker had cut $200 million in costs during the first quarter. In a statement, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca said the company's cost cutting ``is certain to become a major competitive advantage for Chrysler.'' He said the company spent nearly twice as much on buyer incentives in the first quarter than it did a year ago. Chrysler offered a $1,000 rebate on its popular minivans during January, the first time for an incentive on the vehicles. That boosted the sales rate for minivans but cut into profits. Furthermore, since the January sales surge sales of Chrysler's cars and trucks, including minivans, have nosedived. Through the first quarter of the year, Chrysler's domestic car and truck sales were 5.6 percent behind last year's pace. Despite that, analysts said they were encouraged by the long-range effects of the company's budget-cutting program. ``I think it is encouraging to see how successful management has been in controlling costs,'' Kirnan said. ``People still want to see the product side improve.'' Chrysler's next major product change comes to market in the fall when the company's new minivans hit dealer showrooms. Chrysler derives much of its profit from minivan sales. This summer, Chrysler will be shutting down both of its minivan assembly plants for four weeks apiece for retooling. That could spell trouble for the company's second- and third-quarter profits. ``I would not be surprised to see a red number for the third quarter,'' said analyst David Healy of Barclays-BZW of New York, ``but the second quarter should be profitable, probably a good bit better than the first quarter.'' The company said its Chrysler Financial Corp. subsidiary posted an $89 million profit for the first quarter, up from $86 million in the fourth quarter of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Rally
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices strengthened Tuesday, pumped up by a moderate rally in refined oil products. Analysts said traders bought in case any bullish news emerges from an OPEC meeting Wednesday. In addition to precautionary buying, prices were pushed aloft by demand in the spot market for gasoline, which spurred buying in the gas pits on the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``It was a product-led rally today,'' said Jerry Samuels, a vice president and energy broker at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``It was not heavy volume.'' The contract for June delivery of unleaded regular gasoline jumped 1.19 cents to 61.03 cents a gallon after slipping 0.33 cent on Monday. Contracts for later delivery also posted significant gains. The May contract expired Monday. Among other refined products traded on the New York Merc, home heating oil for June delivery advanced 1.52 cents to 52.97 cents a gallon following Monday's rise of 0.70 cent. Subsequent contracts ended with slightly smaller gains. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 27 cents to settle at $18.81 a 42-gallon barrel. The contract had ended unchanged Monday at $18.54. Contracts for delivery during July through September finished 20 cents to 25 cents higher. Natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.565 per million British thermal units, the same settlement price as Monday. Later months finished with minor gains and losses. The OPEC meeting Wednesday preoccupied oil traders. As ministers gathered in Geneva for the emergency session, the cartel's president said OPEC might need to cut output by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to shore up sagging world crude prices. The cartel's president, Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, called the meeting to discuss curbing production. Prices have dropped by more than 20 percent since January. Energy analysts doubt OPEC will achieve enough of a production cutback to have a significant impact on prices. Gasoline demand, meanwhile, firmed at cash markets on the Gulf Coast and in the Houston area reflecting temporary needs of refiners, Samuels said. This boosted futures buying interest.

DOC.BYLINE: Cartel President Calls For Output Cut Of As Much As 1.5 Million Barrels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 10th graf, The June... to UPDATE with Texas Intermediate settlement price. Picks up 11th graf, Boussena said...
DOC.TEXT: OPEC needs cut to oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide, OPEC's president said Tuesday as cartel ministers arrived for an emergency meeting. The cartel's president, Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, called the meeting for Wednesday to try to curb overproduction and boost prices that have dropped by more than 20 percent since January. At issue is whether the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should lower its official production ceiling or alternatively cut its output, thus officially acknowledging violations of individual member quotas. Another issue is whether quota violators should bear the burden of any reduction or whether all 13 members should contribute equally. Analysts say violations by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have pushed OPEC output above the cartel's self-imposed ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day for the first six months of the year. On arriving in Geneva, Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Al-Chalabi said OPEC's daily output currently was between 23.7 million barrels and 24 million barrels. Overproduction has caused a glut during a time of seasonally slackening demand in the second quarter. That has depressed prices well below OPEC's minimum reference price of $18 a barrel. The average price of seven crudes monitored by OPEC stood at $15.37 per 42-gallon barrel last week. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fetched a spot price of $16.45 a barrel late Tuesday in London, unchanged from late Monday. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, settled at $18.81 a barrel Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-month contract traded at more than $24 in late January. Boussena said: ``The single target is clear, how to eliminate the surpluses existing in the market in order to allow a price recovery. It is a single target and I'm certainly hopeful we can achieve that target.'' Asked how much output needed to be cut, he responded: ``It certainly is something between one and one and a half million barrels a day.'' When asked if such a cut would come from current production, he replied affirmatively. Chalabi said he was willing to consider reducing the official production ceiling through the end of June, and that all members should contribute to an output cut. He added, ``We are not exceeding our quotas. We are good guys.'' The United Arab Emirates Oil Minister Mana Saeed Otaiba maintained that his country was observing its daily quota of 1.095 million barrels. Analysts believe the UAE is producing about twice that. The ministers hadn't been expected to grapple with their official quotas and minimum reference price until they held their full, regular midyear conference on June 25. Indonesia's oil minister, Ginandjar Kartasasmita, said, ``OPEC needs to solve its problem of overproduction quickly. Those overproducing will have to cut.'' One oil trader, who didn't want to be identified, said he wasn't optimistic that decisive cuts would be achieved. The meeting could give prices a psychological boost of 50 cents a barrel, but they then should fall back a dollar a barrel, he said. Officially, the gathering is for OPEC's eight-member monitoring committee, which only reviews markets and makes recommendations. But all 13 members are expected to attend, which means a full emergency conference can be called immediately. OPEC's members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman: Defense Company Will Take Large Write-offs
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of troubled defense group Ferranti International PLC said Tuesday the company will write-off ``very substantial'' assets during the year because of fraud at a U.S. subsidiary. Recently appointed chairman Eugene Anderson said the charges against earnings on the 1989-90 accounts would affect trading and extraordinary items, but he did not specify an amount. Ferranti is expected to release full-year results in June. The British electronics and defense equipment maker is struggling to recover from an alleged $353 million fraud involving phantom contracts at its U.S. subsidiary International Signal and Control Ltd., based in Lancaster, Pa. Discovery of the fraud led Ferranti to write off about $300 million and forced the company to arrange special, short-term credit facilities with its bankers. In January, Ferranti agreed to sell its most-prized defense business, its radar division, to its main rival, General Electric Co. PLC for $508 million. GEC is not affiliated with the similarly named U.S. company. At the company's general meeting, Anderson said the majority of the write-offs will have ``no immediate cash-flow implications.'' ``We will diligently pursue recovery of past losses arising from the alleged ISC fraud through appropriate legal processes,'' he said. Ferranti has filed suit against four former ISC executives seeking $198.5 million the British company alleges were illegally siphoned off. It has also filed suit in Britain's High Court against its former auditors, KPMG Peat Marwick Mclintock, for negligence. Anderson, who replaced Sir Derek Alun-Jones in February in an attempt to turn the company around, said Ferranti's performance over the past few years ``has not been satisfactory.'' He told shareholders that a ``thorough strategic review'' was under way. Anderson said the company's board was reviewing stock values, reassessing profits or losses and making adequate provisions for future liabilities, including reorganization costs.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Tuesday in light trading as many European markets were closed for the May Day holiday. Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for May delivery settled at $370 a troy ounce, up $1.60 from late Monday. Republic National Bank of New York also quoted a late bid for gold at $370 an ounce, up $1.30. Bob Morrissey, a trader with Bank of Boston, said the dollar traded in a narrow range, with little news affecting the market. The dollar gained after the release of the monthly index figure from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which indicated the U.S. industrial sector expanded slightly during April for the first time in a year. News of an upturn in economic activity is good for the dollar since it makes it more likely interest rates will rise. Higher interest rates make the dollar more valuable relative to other currencies. But the dollar was not able to sustain its gains and soon gave them up, Morrissey said. Many European markets were closed for May Day, and trading in the United States was thin, he said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 158.90 Japanese yen from 159.08 yen on Friday. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a holiday. Later Tuesday, in London, the dollar fell to 158.80 yen. In New York, the dollar bought 158.85 yen, down from 158.90 late Monday. In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6385 to buy one pound, cheaper than $1.6390 late Monday. In New York, the dollar lost ground, with the pound trading at $1.6445, more expensive than $1.6405 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday quotes, included: 1.6805 West German marks, up from 1.6795; 1.4555 Swiss francs, up from 1.4530; 5.6370 French francs, up from 5.6330; 1,231.75 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50; and 1.1646 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1644. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's late rates included: 1.6785 West German marks, down from 1.6787; 1.4562 Swiss francs, up from 1.4512; 5.6450 French francs, up from 5.6335; 1.8927 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8884; 1,232.50 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50, and 1.1645 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1649. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $368.50 a troy ounce, up from $367.75 bid late Monday. Zurich gold markets were closed for the holiday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.72 to close at a bid $370.83. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.013 per troy ounce, up from $4.932 late Monday. In London, silver bullion rose to a late bid price of $4.97 a troy ounce, from $4.92 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor to Pay $14 Million for Overcharges
With BC-Earns-Emerson Electric
DOC.TEXT: Emerson Electric Co. pleaded guilty Tuesday to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold the Pentagon and agreed to pay $14 million in fines and penalties. The company pleaded guilty in federal court to four felony counts of filing false statements, U.S. Attorney Thomas Dittmeier said. The company admitted that between 1983 and 1987 it gave false and inflated cost estimates for equipment it sold the Defense Department as a sole-source contractor. As a result of inflated estimates, the government was overcharged for equipment it bought from Emerson, Dittmeier said. Emerson's plant, located in suburban Ferguson, was raided by federal agents in February 1988. Emerson said it was told the action was related to the alleged use of parts for U.S. military vehicles on equipment that it was selling to Egypt. Emerson had contended following the raid that it transferred equipment to vehicles it was assembling for Egypt under a ``borrow and pay back'' agreement with the government. The claim, however, was disputed by prosecutors. Dittmeier said Emerson's plea agreement called for the payment of double damages for overcharges rather than the triple damages that normally would have been assessed. Under an agreement, Emerson subsidiary Electronics & Space Corp. will pay $40,000 in fines in addition to the $14 million settlement. The false statements were on four military contracts for automatic test equipment. Dittmeier said no Emerson officials were penalized individually because of ``what appears to be a very institutionalized way of doing business.'' He said the settlement ``lets the public know that we did the right thing and lets the defense industry know that we're looking at them.'' The guilty plea caps a grand jury investigation of fraud allegations against Emerson, which makes electronic components for several weapon systems. Emerson entered its plea before U.S. District Judge John F. Nangle, who ordered the company to pay the $14 million within five days to the Justice Department. The probe was conducted by the U.S. attorney's office in St. Louis, the Defense Criminal Investigative Service, the Defense Contract Audit Agency and the Defense Logistics Agency. The Justice Department also said it found evidence that Emerson charged the government for parts it used on other contracts but that this activity was not covered by the plea. Under the agreement, Emerson is required to submit accurate, complete and current cost and pricing data and its best estimates of future costs in order to enable the government to negotiate fair and reasonable prices.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Shrug Off Purchasing Managers Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced on Wall Street Tuesday as the stock market shrugged off a purchasing managers report indicating strength in the manufacturing sector. The Dow Jones industrial average picked up 12.16 to close at 2,668.92. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 820 up, 679 down and 467 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 149.02 million shares, up from 122.75 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 176.15 million shares. The market opened higher but began to lose ground after the National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks the manufacturing economy by surveying its members each month, said its index rose to 50.2 percent in April from 48.8 percent in March. A reading above 50 generally indicates the economy is expanding. The purchasing managers report reawakened concerns in the financial markets that a stronger economy would allow inflation to accelerate, and that the Federal Reserve would in turn push interest rates higher. Bond prices, which had been up in early trading, surrendered their gains in response to the purchasing managers report, and the stock market initially followed suit. But while the credit markets went on to close lower, Wall Street took its own path, with blue chips first moving higher in the afternoon and secondary stocks catching on later. Tuesday's session repeated what has become a familiar stock market response to a negative report. Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., said traders realized that much of the bad news had already been discounted by the market. Once the initial shock wore off and prices did not drop further, buyers came back into the market, he said. The most actively traded issue on the NYSE was Security Pacific, which closed unchanged at 36. Both Security Pacific and the second-most active issue, Chase Manhattan, were involved in dividend-related trading. Chase was off { at 24~. First-quarter earnings reports gave some stocks a boost. Chrysler rose } to 15\ after issuing a somewhat better-than-expected earnings report Tuesday, and Boeing was up 2{ to 72\ after announcing Monday that its sales jumped 60 percent and its profits rose 87 percent. Pepsico fell { to 65} and Coca-Cola rose { to $76.75 after Burger King announced it was switching to Coke from Pepsi in its U.S. fast-food outlets. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $13.116 billion, or 0.41 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.73 to 182.22. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.64 to 387.08, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 1.45 to 332.25. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.78 to 421.85. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 343.32, up 0.22.

DOC.HEAD: Radiation Approved to Kill Bacteria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to DELETE reference to low-dose, INSERT FDA detail, INSERT industry comment and ADD approved dosage; PICKS UP 11th graf pvs, `In its...
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday approved irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that cause food-borne illnesses. But the industry said it had no plans to use the procedure. The FDA said irradiation is safe and effective in eliminating most bacteria in chicken, turkey and other fresh and frozen birds, making poultry safe for longer periods under refrigeration. Poultry companies, however, said they do not plan to use the technology because of consumer opposition and because ``the consumer can achieve the same thing by cooking the chicken,'' said Stephen Pretanik, science director at the National Broiler Council, which represents the commercial broiler chicken industry. ``There does not appear to be wide consumer acceptance for any food irradiation,'' he said. Although cooking chicken thoroughly kills illness-causing bacteria, ``a lot of the sickness coming from chicken is coming from cross-contamination'' when raw poultry comes in contact with other food, said George Pauli, consumer safety officer at FDA. Irradiation of food was first approved in 1963, when the FDA allowed its use to control insects in wheat and wheat flour. Later, the FDA approved its use to control insects, spoilage and parasites in other grains, fruits, vegetables, spices and pork. Irradiation of poultry is the first approved use aimed at controlling bacteria in food that cause illness in humans. So far, the process has been used infrequently because of consumer opposition, food industry officials said. When foods are irradiated, they must be labeled that have been treated that way. The FDA on Tuesday emphasized that ``the process does not make the food radioactive and, as a result, does not expose consumers to radiation.'' But Michael Colby, director of Food and Water Inc., a group that researches food safety and environmental issues, said the FDA's action was ``an outrage to consumers and to anyone who cares about safe food products.'' He said scientific evidence that irradiation is safe is lacking, and that by approving irradiation, the FDA is allowing poultry growers and processors to speed up their operations without having to clean up their facilities. ``The problem with salmonella comes from the condition of poultry facilities, and they're filthy,'' Colby said. ``The FDA is proposing a toxic solution to a toxic problem.'' Colby also said the states of New York, New Jersey and Maine prohibit the sale of irradiated foods. In its approval, the FDA limited the amount of radiation that can be used on poultry to 3 kiloGray. Doses of 1 to 10 kiloGray are considered medium levels of radiation. Approval of irradiation for poultry was sought by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, which is responsible for inspecting meat and poultry products, and Radiation Technology Inc. of Rockaway, N.J., a firm providing radiation treatment. From 1973 to 1987, poultry accounted for 9.6 percent of the food-borne illnesses in outbreaks for which a food source was reported, the FDA said. Officials said there were no estimates on the incidence of food-borne illnesses in the United States, but some estimate that nearly everyone gets sick from food every couple of years. These illnesses range in severity from a stomach ache to death. Radiation could be used to control such bacteria as Salmonella, Yersinia and Campylobacter, which are common in poultry and can cause gastrointestinal illnesses. Contamination can occur through other foods or when the poultry is not cooked thoroughly. The FDA said it based its approval on studies in which laboratory animals were fed diets containing irradiated poultry. The study found the treatment to be effective and the treated foods to be safe.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Fall After Strong Rally
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell moderately Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a sudden reversal in a technically inspired rally that had driven prices to new nine-month highs. Grain futures followed the soybean market and ended mostly lower. On other commodity markets, energy futures rose sharply; copper futures surged; precious metals advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 4{ cents to 6} cents lower with the contract for delivery in May down 5 cents at $6.27{ a bushel. Wheat futures settled 6} cents lower to 2{ cents higher with May at $3.67{ a bushel; corn was 2 cents lower to 2{ cents higher with May at $2.83} a bushel; oats were } cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $1.64} a bushel. Soybeans for May delivery touched $6.55 a bushel, the highest price for a near-month soybean contract since July 28, before the rally ran out of steam. Analysts linked the early runup to chart patterns that indicated to many traders that prices were likely to continue their recent strong advance. The upswing in prices that began about two weeks ago was underpinned by strong demand and relatively tight supplies, but those factors had been known for long enough that analysts discounted them as a reason for Tuesday's action. Prices peaked before noon, then fell amid heavy selling that accelerated in the final hour of trading. ``The buying dried up, the selling picked up and the lower you got, the more selling you ran into,'' said Jerry Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s grain trading operations. The unusual volatility may have been a function of thin market conditions due to the May Day holiday in Europe. With European markets closed, there were fewer players in the soybean market and prices fluctuated more freely. Oil futures rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange, largely on speculation that OPEC ministers meeting Wednesday in Geneva will agree on measures to firm up crude-oil prices. As cartel ministers arrived Tuesday for the emergency meeting, OPEC president Sadek Boussena of Algeria said OPEC needs cut to oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide. Crude oil values have fallen more than 20 percent since January. U.S. supplies of crude oil and refined products fell last week, according to the weekly American Petroleum Institute stocks report released after the close of trading. The trade group reported a relatively modest decline of 473,000 barrels of crude oil and steeper drops of 1.5 million barrels of gasoline and 2.1 million barrels of petroleum distillates. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 13 cents to 27 cents higher with June at $18.81 a barrel; heating oil was 1.03 cents to 1.52 cents higher with June at 52.97 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .85 cent to 1.19 cents higher with June at 61.03 cents a gallon. Copper futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting continuing concerns about tight supplies. Copper settled 2.9 cents to 5.2 cents higher with May at $1.221 a pound. Gold futures rose moderately, nearly erasing Monday's losses, while silver and platinum futures posted strong gains. On the Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1.30 to $1.60 higher with May at $370 a troy ounce; silver was 8 cents to 8.4 cents higher with May at $5.013 a troy ounce. Platinum futures ended $5.60 to $5.90 higher on the New York Merc with July at $479.70 a troy ounce. Cattle futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures rose sharply, reflecting strong cash markets and bullish technical signals in the pork bellies, which climbed the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the second straight day. Live cattle settled .30 cent lower to .27 cent higher with June at 73.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .42 cent higher with May at 82.55 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .78 cent higher with June at 63.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent to 2 cents higher with May at 68.65 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Again Promises To Fight for Cut in Capital Gains Tax
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told small business owners Tuesday he will keep fighting to cut the capital gains tax and keep government from trying to ``swallow a third'' of their businesses. ``Limited government must mean limited taxes,'' Bush told almost 200 members of National Small Business United and the National Association of Women Business Owners. Bush, who wants the top tax rate on capital gains cut from 33 to 19.6 percent, said the government should not discourage people ``from investing in small businesses, nor should it swallow a third of the business you've spent your life building. ``But that's what our taxation of capital gains does,'' Bush said. The groups gave Bush a plaque and also introduced the president to Elena Medvedkova, a leader of a newly affiliated Soviet Association of Women Business Owners. The Sovet woman thanked Bush for the ``great opportunity'' to visit the White House ``at this turning point'' in U.S.-Soviet relations.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Becoming Hot Spot for Corporate Moves
DOC.TEXT: Dallas and Houston were the top two cities for corporate relocations in 1989, as cheaper costs made the Southwest a hot spot to move companies, according to market research by a top relocation firm. According to a study of 37,000 corporate moves handled by PHH Homequity, Chicago slipped to fifth place from third and New York to fourth from second last year. New York lost the most families to other cities, the company said. ``One of the things is the cost of doing business there for different types of industry. They'll find that moving to Dallas will be better for them. It just makes sense,'' said Keith Bisogno, a spokesman for PHH Homequity. He said the average appraised value of house home in New York was $295,513, compared to $142,590 in Dallas, $117,057 in Houston and $116,379 in Denver. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. moved 1,200 employees to Dallas from New York in 1988, while Exxon Corp. announced last year it was moving 200 to 300 people to Dallas. Both cited costs as a factor. ``Basically it was a variety of reasons: the nearness of a major international airport, the favorable business climate in Dallas ... and the various amenities in terms of lifestyle, cost of housing and such,'' Exxon spokesman Bill Smith said. ``We're saving about $60 million a year in administrative costs,'' J.C. Penney spokesman Duncan Muir said. ``We owned the building (in New York), but just occupancy costs and labor costs (were high).'' Mobil Oil Corp. also cited the high cost of living in New York in its 1987 decision to move 1,200 people to Fairfax, Va. PHH Homequity, which bills itself as the nation's largest corporate relocation firm, said it moved 1,294 families into Dallas and 1,180 into Houston in 1989. Rounding out the top 10, Washington ranked third, Atlanta sixth, followed by Denver, San Francisco, Philadelphia and Los Angeles. New York lost 1,592 families last year to rank first on the list of departures for the second year in a row. Dallas, Houston and Denver were second, third and fourth, but Bisogno said a significant number of those workers were transferred to other Southwest cities.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Lets Torchmark Continue Insurance Proxy Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with circuit court appeal, quote from judge's ruling; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Representatives of...
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday allowed Torchmark Inc. to continue a proxy fight aimed at gaining control of its bigger insurance rival, American General Corp. U.S. District Judge Thomas A. Wiseman said a Tennessee state commissioner overreached his authority when he ordered an end to the proxy battle Monday. The state immediately appealed the ruling to the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati. The judge said the order by Revenue Commissioner Joe Huddleston interfered with the rights of stockholders to vote their shares at Houston-based American General's annual meeting Wednesday. ``Regulating insurance companies is one thing, regulating how people vote their stock is quite another,'' Wiseman said in the ruling. Representatives of Torchmark, based in Birmingham, Ala., also said an Indiana Superior Court judge, R.L. Milan, had delayed an administrative hearing on the proxy battle in that state until next Monday. Huddleston said Torchmark violated state law by soliciting a majority of proxies designed to elect five new members of the 15-member American General board of directors. Torchmark attorney William Leech said Torchmark wants five directors on the board who will listen to discussions about merging the two companies. He said election of one-third of the directors falls short of a takeover. Tennessee is one of 10 states in which American General is considered domiciled because of operations there. Regulators in Texas and New York, as well as Tennessee, have questioned the legality of Torchmark's proxy solicitation. Missouri, California and Virginia have approved the process. American General has assets of $32 billion. Torchmark, with assets of $5 billion, has set aside $15 million for the proxy fight. Testimony during the hearing showed the proxy strategy was adopted after American General directors rejected Torchmark's offer of $50 in cash and $50 in Torchmark stock for each share of American General stock. Huddleston was designated to hear the case for state Commerce Commissioner Elaine McReynolds, who recused herself because she is a former assistant vice president of American General Life & Accident Insurance Co., a subsidiary with 1,500 employees in Nashville. Huddleston said state insurance law said no company or holding company can seek to control a Tennessee company without prior approval of the state Department of Commerce and Insurance.

DOC.HEAD: States Post New Record Number of Wineries
DOC.TEXT: The country has a record 1,338 wineries in 45 states, 136 more wineries than last year, the authoritative Wines & Vines Directory reported Tuesday. The only states that do not make wine commercially, either with grapes or some other fruit, are North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Alaska and Nebraska, the publication said. California leads all states with 676 wineries. Rounding out the top 10 are New York, 93; Oregon, 79; Washington, 77; Pennsylvania, 59; Virginia, 43; Missouri, 30; Texas, 26; New Mexico, 18; and New Jersey, 17. Among the states with new wineries, the leaders are California, 42; Pennsylvania, 23; Washington and New York, 11 each; Oregon, 10; Virginia, 6; and Ohio, 5.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador: Japanese Will Gain From Easing Trade Barriers
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Japan asserted Tuesday that Japanese consumers will be among the main beneficiaries of easing barriers against American goods. Michael Armacost also said progress has been made toward lowering Japanese trade restrictions, but the United States should continue ``to firmly press our requests'' on trade issues. ``We've covered a fair amount of business in the past six or seven weeks,'' Armacost told a news conference. ``It's been satisfying to get some of these issues laid to rest.'' Armacost, a career diplomat who was named ambassador a year ago, was in Seattle to speak to a Japan-America Society meeting. He said a developing consumerism movement in Japan has resulted in more unhappiness at trade practices that keep prices of imported goods in Japan artificially high. ``There's a growing realization that these reforms are good for them,'' he said. Lowering tariffs on wood products, for instance, raises the possibility that Japanese could buy better housing, Armacost said. ``There are enough benefits to be shared,'' he said. ``This should not be regarded as a one-way concession.'' President Bush last Friday declined to cite Japan under a section of U.S. trade law that provides for economic retaliation if offensive trade barriers are not removed. Administration officials said targeting Japan could provoke a public backlash against the United States and make it far more difficult for Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to reform Japan's trading system. Bush's decision was denounced by many members of Congress, who said the United States' $49 billion trade imbalance with Japan is bleeding American jobs and capital. The Bush administration last year cited Japan under the so-called ``Super 301'' provision of the trade laws for barriers to U.S.-made supercomputers, satellites and wood products. But in the past month, U.S. and Japanese negotiators have reached agreements toward opening markets in all three of those areas. The wood products agreement has been criticized by many Northwest lawmakers and by small mill operators in the region as not going far enough. But U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the agreement should boost U.S. wood products sales by $1 billion in 1991. Armacost said the agreements on computers, satellites and wood products undoubtedly were hastened by a deadline for action set by the Bush administration. But he said the accords are ``a gesture of good faith from the Japanese government'' that they are willing to resolve trade issues. ``It would be inappropriate to impose Super 301 now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Rally Against Joblessness, Violence Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with violence in Leipzig, West Berlin; picks up 8th pvs, `Economists have...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Germans demanded protection against unemployment Tuesday, and labor leaders warned that Western businesses are eager to exploit East Germany's low-paid work force. In the West German capital, Bonn, negotiators from both Germanys met in an effort to complete by Friday a plan for merging the economies and social institutions of the two nations. An estimated 600,000 workers held 700 rallies in both nations during May Day gatherings Tuesday. In West Berlin, bands of mostly leftist radicals hurled firebombs and rocks Tuesday night, and police responded with tear gas and nightsticks. More than 50 people were arrested after darkness fell in the tense Kreuzberg district of the city, West Berlin police reported. There were no immediate reports of injuries. In the East German city of Leipzig, a group of leftist youths brawled with a band of neo-Nazi youths in the market square, the government news agency ADN reported. Three suffered minor injuries and 21 were arrested, the agency said. Authorities have feared that the newly opened borders between East and West Germany would result in clashes that wold spread into East Berlin. As of late Tuesday, there were no reports of violence in East Berlin. In an earlier West Berlin rally attended by 60,000 banner-waving East and West Germans, speakers voiced the fears that unification could bring high unemployment and an erosion of workers' rights. Ernst Breit, head of West Germany's Federation of Trade Unions, said some West German businesses and politicians view East Germany as a ``new low-wage land with possibly less social security, fewer controls and weak unions.'' One East German listener, 19-year-old Maria Hoensch, asked: ``What sort of future will I have? Nobody knows what will happen.'' Economists have predicted that 500,000 to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs in the next two years as inefficient state-owned enterprises are closed and others are forced to compete with Western businesses. Government officials in both Germanys say the effects will be temporary as Western businesses flood into the east, creating jobs and raising living standards. The two Germanys expect to complete agreement this week on the terms of an economic and social union that will go into effect on July 2. Differences remain between the governments on how much financial protection West Germany will give East Germans during the unification process. Officials from both countries met again in Bonn to discuss the issues and planned to hold more meetings Thursday and Friday in East Berlin. Both sides say they hope to have a final plan finished by Friday for absorbing East Germany's economy, public sector and social welfare system. The negotiators want the plan ready before East Germans vote in their first free local and state election Sunday. Voters had their first democratic national elections on March 18. West Germans fear higher taxes, inflation and competition for jobs may be the cost of bailing out East Germany's decimated economy. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who faces re-election in December, denied that taxes would be raised and dismissed fears that inflation would result from replacing the nearly worthless East German mark for the powerful West German currency. In an article to be published Wednesday in the West German newspaper Die Welt, Kohl said the West German mark will remain ``the most stable and desirable currency in the world.'' East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere wants some job, housing and social subsidies retained at least temporarily to help ease his nation's transition from four decades of heavily subsidized socialism. West German officials have agreed to exchange most East German marks at a 1-1 rate for West German marks when the western currency is circulated in the country in July. The West German proposal calls for a 2-1 exchange for personal savings of more than $2,300. But East Germany is demanding a higher ceiling.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia-Pacific Plants May Be Up For Sale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Toledo, Ore., sted Toledo, Ohio.
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. said Tuesday it was considering selling some mills, box plants and timberland in the wake of its pending $4 billion acquisition of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. The company's board of directors authorized management to explore the sale of as many as 20 of its mills and plants following its annual shareholders' meeting in Augusta. Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. said timberland required to support the plants also may be sold. He said the properties ``may not fit our long-term strategy.'' The plants targeted for possible sale were chose because of a ``geographic or product redundancy'' due to the planned acquisiton of Norwalk, Conn.-based Great Northern, according to Sheila Weidman, a company spokeswoman. She said Georgia-Pacific wasn't in need of cash to complete the merger, which is expected to become final by the end of June. The acquisition, approved in March, would make Georgia-Pacific the nation's largest forest products company. Ms. Weidman declined to place a value on the assets that may be sold, although the company announced last month it would sell at least $1 billion in assets to cut costs, raise capital and reduce debts. The company said it was considering selling a linerboard mill at Valdosta, Ga.; a linerboard, corrugating medium and kraft paper mill at Toledo, Ore.; a corrugating medium mill at Tomahawk, Wis.; and box plants in East Point, Ga.; Garland, Texas; Milan, Mich.; Modesto and Los Angeles, Calif.; Newark, Ohio; Newberry, S.C.; Rutherfordton and Salisbury, N.C.; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; Olympia, Wash.; Buffalo, N.Y.; Grafton, W.Va.; Miami; Bristol, Pa.; and Gas City, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: Merc Fines Trader $50,000 For Major Offense
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said a futures trader agreed to a $50,000 fine and a six-month suspension of his floor privileges to settle charges of a major trading offense. The exchange said in a statement Tuesday that Lloyd D. Gabbert had directed the proceeds of certain trades of stock-index futures into two separate accounts, improperly creating a loss in one account and a profit in the other. The alleged offense occurred last Oct. 16, the exchange said. The Merc said Gabbert agreed to the penalty while neither admitting nor denying the allegation.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Golden Named Publisher Of Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Michael Golden, a former general manager of Child magazine, has been named publisher of McCall's magazine. The move announced Tuesday is part of a general reorganization of the monthly magazine, which has undergone changes since it was acquired last June by The New York Times Company Magazine Group. Golden, 40, will replace John Beni, the magazine's publisher since 1988, who resigned. McCall's has a new design and editorial approach, and a new editor-in-chief, Anne Mollegan Smith. Golden was credited with vastly improving Child magazine during his two years there, according to a statement from the Times company, which owns both Child and McCall's, along with 15 other magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Officials Meet With City Officials
DOC.TEXT: A Chrysler Corp. representative met with city and state officials to discuss plans to build a new sport utility vehicle in Toledo and transfer production of the Jeep Wrangler to Toledo from Brampton, Ontario. Michael Glusac, Chrysler's executive director of governmental affairs, declined comment on details of Tuesday's meeting. ``I'm very optimistic that we can get a number of issues resolved so we can build the JJ in Toledo,'' Glusac said, referring to the vehicle Chrysler plans to build as part of a $500 million joint venture with Renault of France. Mayor John McHugh echoed Glusac and said discussions with Chrysler about financial incentives would continue. ``The talks were fruitful, but I really can't disclose any details,'' he said. Chrysler said last week that it would build the JJ in Toledo and move the Wrangler line there if it can resolve a number of issues with the city and state and United Auto Workers Local 12. The company wants the city and state to provide tax abatements and financing. It also wants to renegotiate a new contract with Local 12 to replace a pact that expires in 1992. Workers will vote Friday on whether to reopen the contract, said Ronald Conrad, Jeep unit chaiman for Local 12. He anticipated that union members will approve the reopening. The city's two Jeep plants make Cherokees and Grand Wagoneers and have a combined workforce of 5,300 people. Under the company's plans, Chrysler would begin producing the JJ in July 1993, creating 700 new jobs. Chrysler also would shift production of the Wrangler to Toledo from Brampton in July 1992. That move could create as many as 900 jobs in Toledo.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.1 million tons during the week ending April 21, down 3.8 percent from the 20.9 million tons produced in the previous week, the U.S. Department of Energy reported. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.2 million tons in the same week last year, the department's Energy Information Administration said Tuesday. Kentucky ranked first among the 26 coal-producing states with 3.4 million tons produced. Wyoming was second at 3.3 million tons and West Virginia third at 3 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 323 million tons, 6 percent ahead of last year's pace. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: French Complain US Farm Plan Hits Only Export Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. plan to cut world-wide subsidies to farmers deals only with subsidies for exports and not with costly domestic price supports, French Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet complained. The 12 nations of the European Community want to negotiate on all kinds of support to farmers, Nallet said Tuesday. Subsidies on farm products cost taxpayers and consumers tens of billions of dollars a year not only in the United States and Europe but in many other countries. Governments generally agree they should be reduced, but the EC rejects the U.S. goal of eliminating them completely. Nearly 100 governments taking part in the ``Uruguay round'' of trade talks are trying to get agreements by the end of the year on many kinds of trade. Subsidizing farmers is a key issue. ``I don't think that even in 10 or 20 years _ or even when we're all dead _ that we'll be able to come to the point where there's no assistance given to farmers whatsoever,'' Nallet told reporters after a day of talks with U.S. leaders. He said U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter showed him an interesting plan for what is called ``tariffication.'' Under it, many kinds of subsidies and other barriers to trade would be converted into a single barrier: customs duties on imported farm products. Once governments agreed on such a conversion, it would be simpler to reduce the barriers. ``We can agree on tariffication, as long as all subsidies are included,'' Nallet said. ``The American plan would deal only with export subsidies, not with domestic price supports.'' He praised the work of the Organization for Economic and Cooperation and Development, which groups the governments of the major industrial countries, in calculating the value of their farm subsidies. It showed New Zealand giving the lowest subsidies, amounting to only about 10 percent of its products' value. Australia's subsidies are only a little greater, he said. Subsidies given by other major countries go from 27 percent by the United States to about 70 percent for Japan. The rate for the EC, which has a joint farm policy, was put at 38 percent. ``Every government gives subsidies,'' Nallet said. ``We're all in the same boat.'' He said he had found in Washington a new readiness to talk realistically and to put all the elements on the negotiating table. ``Agreement is within our grasp,'' he added. ``I'm against people who keep saying how difficult it all is.''

DOC.HEAD: New Zealand's Only Private TV Network Seeks Receivership
DOC.TEXT: New Zealand's only private television broadcaster asked bankers to appoint a receiver after the station failed to attract viewers or advertising. In a brief statement to the New Zealand Stock Exchange Wednesday, TV3 said Westpac Banking Corp., its principal banker, ``has withdrawn its banking facilities from the company.'' ``Accordingly, the directors have resolved to request Westpac to appoint a receiver,'' the statement said. TV3 is New Zealand's first private television network and is 14.7 percent owned by National Broadcasting Co. of the United States, the highest level of foreign ownership allowed. It began broadcasting in October 1989 in competition to the two state-owned networks and was floated on the stock exchange in November. It beams to all major cities but not all rural areas. A total of 5.5 million shares, or 15 percent of TV3's capital, were issued to the public at the equivalent of about $1.43 each. The remaining shares were held by its founders. NBC's investment totaled about $3.1 million. Stock is allowed to continue trading under stock exchange rules despite Wednesday's announcement. Analysts said the company had difficulty attracting sufficient advertising revenue in the small New Zealand market, a country of just 3.5 million people. TV3 was still broadcasting its regular programs shortly after Wednesday's announcement, and also was running promotional material for programs scheduled to air on the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Gain Sharply, Dollar Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday morning and the dollar declined against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average jumped 362.69 points, or 1.22 percent, ending the morning session at 30,052.52. The index rose 105.03 points the previous day. The dollar was changing hands at 158.48 yen at late morning. It started trading at 158.62 yen, down 0.28 yen from Tuesday's finish, and ranged between 158.40 yen and 158.70 yen during morning trading. The yen's strength encouraged investors and prompted buying of stocks, dealers said. ``Share prices were higher almost across the board, as market players expected the market's continuing uptrend after the holidays,'' said Toshiyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. Financial markets, including stocks and foreign exchange, are open only Tuesday and Wednesday this week because of a series of ``Golden Week'' national holidays in Japan. In the currency markets, the dollar's slide in Tokyo followed its downswing in New York the previous day, dealers said. They said market players were reluctant to increase their dollar positions ahead of the holidays, especially with the U.S. employment report due out Friday and the Group of Seven monetary meeting over the weekend. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 85.81 from Tuesday's close of 85.65. That dropped the yield to 7.41 percent from 7.445 percent.
